PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1985 proposes to amend the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 by extending the bounty assistance under the Act to vessels constructed or modified for export from Australia. The Government announced the export proposals on 11 October 1984 after consideration of the report of a task force on the Australian shipbuilding industry which was released in January of that year. The task force was established by the then Minister for Industry and Commerce following representation from the Australian Shipbuilders Association concerning the long term viability of the local shipbuilding industry and its grim forward order situation. The task force made several recommendations aimed at increasing the throughput of Australian shipyards. Concern was also expressed at the substantial increase in the number of yards constructing bountiable vessels since the introduction of the current bounty scheme on 1 July 1980. It was recommended to government that it explore the possibility of prescribing conditions for the registration of shipyards. This Bill proposes to extend the current bounty paid at a rate of 25 per cent of the cost of production to ships for export; to introduce new registration criteria for shipbuilders who wish to claim bounty; and to update administrative arrangements in accordance with recent bounty legislation. In other words, most of the recommendations of the inquiry were accepted by government.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the question of industrial assistance. The shipbuilding industry has long been a subject of government assistance. Up to the Second World War the industry was protected by tariffs and a bounty was introduced in 1940. However, no claims were made and it was removed during the War in 1943. Assistance by subsidy was introduced in 1947. Under that scheme the cost of construction in Australia was subsidised to equate Australian costs with those in the United Kingdom. The maximum level was set at 25 per cent of the Australian construction cost. Levels of assistance accorded the industry were reviewed by the Tariff Board in 1955, 1959 and 1963 resulting in a number of modifications to the assistance agreement. The maximum subsidy was further increased to 33 1/3 per cent in 1955 and continued at that level through to 1972. The system that was introduced in July 1972 was calculated on the lowest local tender for vessels over 200 tonnes. The subsidy was to be phased from an initial level of 45 per cent to 35 per cent after 1975 and down to 25 per cent after 1980. Restrictions were enforced since the 1940 bounty was levied to protect further the local industry.

Next, the Industries Assistance Commission was asked to report on whether any changes were necessary in the assistance accorded the industry in view of the poor order situation and the number of major shipyards which had either closed or threatened to close. The IAC's 1976 report recommended that the previous assistance package be maintained. Following further consideration of the IAC report, the Government announced on 29 November 1979 details of its assistance package for the Australian shipbuilding industry. These arrangements are still current.

Essential elements of the new bounty scheme were to operate from 1 July 1980 for vessels over 150 tonnes and fishing vessels exceeding either 150 gross construction tonnes or 21 metres in length. The bounty was to be paid as a percentage of the cost of construction and set at 27.5 per cent, to be phased down to a long term rate of 20 per cent from July 1986. The 20 per cent bounty was to apply for modifications to existing vessels where total modification cost exceeded $400,000.

I have outlined the development of Australian government shipbuilding policy over the last 40 years. This period witnessed many changes in the thrust of policy, which was initially aimed at fostering the development of the industry. However, through the late 1970s the aim of policy was significantly redefined. Part of that redefinition was oriented towards phasing down the activity geared towards the construction of large vessels and at the same time fostering the development of an industry now perceived to be closely aligned with defence requirements. During, the 1970s the concept of economic efficiency rather than technical efficiency was introduced and used as an aid to the evolution of industry assistance policies. Up to the mid-1970s the local industry built a wide range of vessels, including bulk carriers, roll-on-roll-off vessels, and ships for international trade.

Long-standing industry problems have included a lack of economies of scale, obsolete plant and equipment, low labour productivity and industrial unrest. These were exacerbated by the general economic downturn and the oil crisis of the early 1970s. Large shipbuilding ceased with the closure of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd yard at Whyalla, and the industry now consists of mainly small shipyards constructing passenger ferries, fishing boats, off-shore supply vessels, tugs, dredges, barges, and small trading vessels. Members of the industry, unions and task force have expressed concern that the skills in the industry are specialised and that any further contraction in the industry may give rise to a situation in which long term maintenance of the necessary skills is impossible. The availability of experienced high quality design expertise limits the capability of the Australian industry to undertake a major ship design task, and much of the available design capacity is at present engaged in naval work.

The depressing forward order position is exacerbated by the apparent large number of firms capable of building the small types of vessels now being constructed in Australia. Since the introduction of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, which commenced operation in July 1980, the number of registered shipbuilders constructing bountiable vessels grew from 14 registered yards with 53 bountiable vessels under construction or on firm order in October 1979 to 32 yards with 53 vessels being built or on firm order by October 1983. In the four years between 1980 and 1983, 43 firms not previously registered as builders of bountiable vessels were registered and built bountiable vessels. Of those 43, 20 are currently building vessels. The task force noted that in the IAC report on ships, boats and other vessels not existing 6,000 tonnes gross register the Commission concluded that, given the likely further market for bountiable vessels, there may be too many builders in the industry and that a rationalisation among shipbuilders may be desirable.

It is therefore clear that the industry has moved in the opposite direction to that suggested by the IAC and later by the task force, which then believed that the Commission's conclusion was even more relevant today than it was at the time it was made. The task force was of the view that the basic causes of the industry's present difficulties appeared to be low domestic and world demand, too many actual or potential participants in the industry, and the competitive finance packages offered by overseas yards. Consequently, it recommended the extension of the bounty to vessels for export, the introduction of a scrappage allowance for older vessels where a replacement vessel is built domestically, and the introduction of financing arrangements for vessels for the domestic market similar to those existing for vessels sold on the export market. The task force also found that the methods for financing the construction of vessels in Australia were inadequate when compared with the financial facilities offered by overseas yards. Local shipbuilders normally require full payment by the time the vessel is complete. On the other hand, overseas yards offer extended credit at favourable rates of interest, in some cases for domestically owned vessels as well as for export orders. To a large extent the inability of local firms to offer attractive finance packages is the result of the failure of the capital market to meet the requirements of some sections of manufacturing industry.

The task force also indicated the very pessimistic projection for local demand for shipbuilding in recommending an extension of the existing bounty to the export market. The current New South Wales Urban Transport Authority ferry replacement program is expected to be completed before the end of 1985; the tug replacement program is virtually completed; off-shore service and small trading vessel areas are suffering excess tonnage; there is generally a high level of over-capacity in world shipping tonnage, and defence shipbuilding demands are irregular and lumpy and would not inject sufficient enduring demand to reverse the current downturn in the industry.

The new assistance program has particular relevance in relation to the government's shipbuilding program. It is designed to improve the volume of production through the extension of the bounty to cover vessels built for export and new finance packages. The package includes the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty from imported goods used in the construction or modification of ships eligible for the bounty. It also covers the establishment of an industry body to monitor progress and outlines a proposed industrial agreement between the industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The major assistance to shipbuilders competing for overseas contracts is the extension to vessels constructed for export of a bounty of 25 per cent of the cost of construction which is currently provided to industry, but the bounty will be paid only to shipbuilders who have a clear and long term commitment to the industry and for the criteria which support that industry. These include that the company be an Australian registered business or organisation, that it have the financial and commercial capacity to build a bountiable vessel and that it employ directly or through sub-contractors an average of 20 people in shipbuilding. The package addresses the problem of Australian builders missing contracts because of their inability to offer competitive finance. The bounty rate is to phase down to 22.5 per cent for vessels commenced between 1 July 1985 and 1 July 1986, phasing to a long term rate of 20 per cent from 1 July 1986. There will be an annual limit on the bounty payable on ships built for export. The limit will be $6m in 1984-85 and $10m in 1985-86.

Under the present bounty system, which costs $29m a year, shipbuilders are paid 25 per cent of their construction costs for vessels in the domestic market. Extension of the bounty to cover ships built for foreign markets will enhance local industries' international competitiveness. Revitalisation and long term viability of Australian shipbuilding depends on improved industrial relations. Industrial disputes, including crippling demarcation actions, have long added to construction costs and contributed to an uncompetitive local industry. They have also played a major role in the closure of major shipyards in recent years. This Bill establishes a Shipbuilding Consultative Group consisting of a representative from the unions, industry and government to monitor progress in the industry. The SCG will also be responsible for assisting and assessing the applications for the bounty extension scheme by shipbuilders.

The Opposition supports the general thrust of this legislation to rationalise the industry and at the same time to give it wider opportunities by extending the bounty to vessels built for export. The Opposition supports the need for a viable shipbuilding industry in Australia. As the task force has indicated, the level of domestic demand, at least in the short term, is unlikely to be adequate for a viable shipbuilding industry. Export orders should clearly improve the cost efficiency of local shipyards as well as help to overcome the problems of the irregular and unpredictable nature of domestic demand for ships.

The peculiarities of Australian geography and economy have focused great importance on the shipping industry from our earliest days as a colony to our present status in international trade. The Australian economy is highly dependent on the world market, both as a buyer and a seller of goods. About 13 per cent of Australian production is sold as exports and a slightly higher proportion of total expenditure goes on imports. As most of the country's foreign trade-over 200 million tonnes of cargo each year-is in fact moved by sea, Australia is dependent on an efficient transport system. The importance therefore of a viable shipbuilding industry becomes increasingly apparent in the present balance of payments situation. The 20 per cent devaluation in the Australian dollar has caused widespread and well-founded concern throughout the Australian community, but the devaluation has also caused major disruptive repercussions on vital imports which have become more expensive, on a consumer price index which will jump significantly, and on calls for discounting of wage indexation which puts increasing strain on the prices and incomes accord.

The bounty assistance and consultation will be worthless in the medium to longer term unless the Government gets its macro-economic policies in order. The apparent ongoing devaluation of the Australian dollar provides opportunities for industries such as shipbuilding to both improve their export potential and to improve their competitiveness against imports. However, it must be noted that the costs of imports, which are a major element in the total costs of construction, have also increased. However, unless the Government is prepared to confront the threat of higher inflation from devaluation and wage indexation, this industry and most others will be back again asking for higher bounties and higher tariffs, despite the fact that all industries receiving tariff and bounty assistance are also receiving now an increased devaluation bonus of around 20 per cent which the Government has not taken into account in its policies on bounties or tariff protection.

As the task force says in its report, labour on-costs in Australian shipbuilding yards are a significant component of total wage costs-that is, about 30 per cent compared with about 18 per cent in Japan. In Japan at the moment it appears that the spring wage offensive may produce an average wage increase of around 4 per cent for 1985-86. Yet the Hawke Government is now talking about supporting wage increases of possibly as high as 8 to 9 per cent in 1985-86, including at least 4 per cent for the direct and indirect effects of devaluation. This is on top of the significant wage drift evident in the figures on average weekly earnings and the national accounts.

Both award and non-award wage increases for 1985-86 will be translated into significantly higher on-costs than in the very countries with which we are trying to compete. Succinctly put, this is economic madness, as is the Government's refusal even to consider deregulation of the labour market. How can anyone justify a policy which forces an industry such as shipbuilding to pay the same rates and conditions as a service industry which is not subject to import competition? The Government's policy gives industries competing against imports and trying to develop exports no real chance, let alone the possibility of being able to prosper. Until the Government comes to terms with the need for labour market deregulation and ends full wage indexation, all measures such as those which have been introduced will be outweighed by fundamental weaknesses in economic strategy.

Right now Australia faces a balance of payments crisis. The latest figures are stark evidence of the fact that the Australian economy is not competitive with the rest of the world. Our balance of trade for the 10 months to April 1985 is in deficit to the tune of over $1,422m, compared with the 1983-84 full year surplus of $172m. Imports have increased 29.5 per cent, while exports increased in the 10 months to April 1985 by only 18.6 per cent over the same period of the previous year. In the first 10 months of 1984-85 the invisibles deficit has already reached $7,566m. This indicates a probable full year invisible deficit of around $9 billion. The current account deficit for 1984-85 is likely to approach $11,000m. These trends cannot be allowed to continue unabated. Australia must take steps to rectify this balance of payments crisis.

One of the major components of the invisibles equation is transportation, which largely comprises freight, insurance and other costs associated with shipbuilding. In 1983-84 Australia earned $2,273m in this area, but paid out $3,849m. This left us with a transportation deficit of $1,576m. On current trends, in 1984-85 the transportation deficit will be over $2,000m, a slide of 25 per cent in a mere 12 months. This is the annual cost to the nation of having an inadequate merchant fleet.

The Opposition supports the proposed Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill, believing that it will greatly enhance the shipbuilding industry's competitive position. But, as I said earlier, it does little to overcome these underlying problems which are manifestly clear in the situation that is a result of devaluation alone. The cost to the Australian electorate is such that every person-man, woman and child-will be expected to carry a deficit of some $5,000 each this year just to pay back the level of Australia's overseas borrowings, which, in terms of interest alone, have resulted in increased costs of about $1 billion every quarter this year.

Among industry leadership there is currently optimism in relation to export potential. We certainly support that. The effects of this Bill will be to focus on additional assistance for the genuine shipbuilder. The new registration criteria will ensure that only genuine shipbuilders are eligible for bounty payments. This will reduce assistance to those firms on the fringe of the shipbuilding industry. Contrary to the intent of the 1980 Bill, the number of registered shipbuilders has increased from 30 in 1980 to the present 80 registered companies. The new guidelines should succeed in rationalisation, although further measures may be required. As stated by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in his second reading speech, registration may also be restricted to vessels of up to a specified size and, if appropriate, of a specified hull material.

However, the Government must find a set of guidelines which will result in a large majority of the bounty being payable to the specialist shipbuilding industry, not to those on the fringe. This is the only way in which the industry can obtain the reasonable company productivity and continuity of business required to justify the bounty. We welcome the consultations and co-operation with industry and with the unions outlined in the Bill, but in the end it is up to the Government to adjust the guidelines to ensure that bounty flows to the specialist shipbuilding operations best able to compete. This is the crucial need, and the Government would do better to emphasise its determination to ensure that this happens rather than to make largely empty threats on the withdrawal of the export bounty. I shall at the appropriate stage move an amendment to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was pleased to hear many of the supporting comments from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I will deal firstly with the positive aspects of that. The fact is that the Government and the Opposition are in agreement on some aspects of the shipbuilding industry, the most important one being that we as a nation have a major need for shipbuilding to continue. As has been pointed out, there has clearly been a decline in shipbuilding over the years. When the current Government came into office in March 1983, we were confronted with a number of industries in severe crisis, of which the shipbuilding industry was one.

SPEECH.PARA: The model used in the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill is similar to that used for the steel industry and the automotive industry. Firstly, it has a positive structure involving some form of regulation of the industry itself; and this bounty Bill incorporates the shipbuilding group. Secondly, it has required a renegotiated industrial relations situation in the steel industry and the automotive industry, and clearly that is long overdue in the shipbuilding industry. Thirdly, it has involved positive assistance for the industry to improve its performance further.

The most significant aspect of this Bill is the extension of the shipbuilding bounty to the export market. This is only the second area in which this has happened in Australia's history, the first, of course, being the computer bounty which was introduced last year. The intent of that is to suggest to Australian industry and the Australian community that we must turn back the view of industry that the domestic market is the be all and end all and look at the world as our market, because while we look inwards into the Australian market's potential and capacity it has been obvious for many years that that market will not sustain many of the modern industries that Australia needs. To turn to the export market and to treat it similarly to the domestic market has been long overdue in this industry.

Australia has a proud history of shipbuilding. Despite the difficult times experienced in the last 10 to 15 years, we are still amongst the world leaders in the building of smaller to medium ships, particularly tugs, dredges, fishing vessels and ferries. An industry has survived and maintained a skill base under very difficult circumstances. This Bill will allow it and encourage it to expand that base. The problems of the industry were visible long before this Government came to power and certainly long before the principal Act was passed in 1980, but they have been addressed in ways that have smacked of the short term solution and of the cop out. In fact I well remember that the shipbuilding industry in Newcastle in 1976 was in severe crisis. I have taken great interest in recent months in watching observers from the Opposition come to Newcastle, I expect or assume, to examine the corpse of the shipbuilding industry in Newcastle, once one of the proudest in Australia, which they buried in the 1970s. The industry had become uncompetitive, inefficient and undirected, and I suggest that the Opposition can accept responsibility for its current status.

In looking at the future of an industry such as shipbuilding, we must look also at two other aspects, one of which is transport. We must consider the gross distortion in the capacity of Australian shipping to carry Australian goods. Taking into account the invisibles deficit on our foreign trade account, it can be seen that the fact that most of our goods are carried by foreign ships is a major contributing factor to the problems facing the industry. The second aspect which we must look at is the ship repair industry, which is the sister industry to shipbuilding. I look forward to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) bringing forward the finalisation of a ship repair policy that will, in fact, marry the policy to the shipbuilding policy. The two do and must go hand in hand.

The unadulterated nonsense which we heard from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bradfield, regarding the Government's macro-economic policy-he tried to translate the overall Australian deficit into an electorate figure of $5,000 a person and to suggest that the devaluation will somehow make it worse-was an intrusion into an area in which there is a high level of agreement. The Opposition has put forward a sophistic view of economics which is damaging to the industry, the people working in it and the Australian community at large. This general direction of the Opposition of trying to intrude into every positive endeavour and effort a degree of polarisation which is unwarranted does not do it justice. To go much further than the previous speaker did, the devaluation of the dollar provides this industry, firstly, with a major chance to get back into the world market and to be a major force in the small shipbuilding industry of the world. Secondly, it gives Australian shipping and shipping interests a chance to extend their capacity in the transport of Australian goods. We have seen major changes in that area in recent years. The purchase of the bulk ships by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd represents the first significant shift in Australia's transport capacity in the last five years.

The current economic policy of the Government is doing exactly what is needed in Australia. It is getting us back to being competitive. The Government inherited a country which was in severe crisis. Each major industry at which one looks-the steel industry, the automotive industry, and the shipbuilding and ship repair industries-has gone through a period of great trauma. This Bill is the third in a line of reconstruction of industry. It is a major Bill. There is major agreement between industry, unions, government and opposition. It is not the time to be talking about polarisation. It is a time to talk about rebuilding. I commend the Bill in its current form to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill proposes to extend the bounty assistance provided to the shipbuilding industry in Australia to vessels constructed or modified for export from Australia. To date it has been paid only for ships sold in Australia. It is claimed by members on both sides of the House that this extension of the bounty to vessels for export is a more consistent position than we have at present. I am afraid that I have to disagree somewhat. I would have thought that it would have been more consistent to remove the bounty for the domestic market to bring it into line with the export market.

SPEECH.PARA: Assistance for shipbuilding in Australia has a history spanning several decades. Before World War II assistance was granted by way of tariff. In 1947, this was switched to assistance by way of subsidy. Between 1955 and 1972 there was a 33 1/3 per cent subsidy. In 1972-73, there were changes under the Whitlam Government whereby higher protection was given initially. However, by 1976 there were few orders and yards were closing. Two Industries Assistance Commission reports were brought down. The first recommended continuing the status quo. The second provided the basis for today's assistance. From 1 July 1980, a bounty was paid as a percentage of the construction costs for ships of more than 150 tonnes or a water length of over 21 metres. Initially there was a 27.5 per cent bounty. This was reduced to 25 per cent from 1 July last year. This will be further reduced to 22 1/2 per cent from 1 July this year and reduced to 20 per cent from 1 July 1986. We also have a 20 per cent bounty for modifications over $400,000, and we have some import controls.

Australia has under construction less than one per cent of the world's shipping tonnage. If we look at the bountiable vessels built over the last few years, in the year to 31 October 1978 we built 50 ships; in the year to 31 October 1983 we built 53 ships. There was very little change in that time. However, the number of yards operating in 1978 was 16. That has now doubled to 32 yards. It is clear that the bounty is working successfully; in fact, too successfully. The bounty undoubtedly has contributed to an increase in the number of yards building ships. The market has stayed constant at the small number of 50 ships a year, but the number of yards has doubled to build the same number of ships. In 1978, on average we were building three ships per yard. In 1983 we were building on average only 1 1/2 ships per yard. Obviously that is a situation with no viable future. No big ships have been built in Australia since the closure of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd yard at Whyalla in 1978. We now build small ships in mainly small yards-for example, passenger ferries, tugs, dredges, fishing boats, off-shore supply vessels, barges and small trading vessels up to 10,000 tonnes.

The outlook for the future is not good, either domestically or on the export market. If we look at the domestic market and the construction of tugs we see that tug operators have undertaken a major replacement program in the last few years and few tugs will therefore be required over the next six to seven years. The position with ferries is that most replacement orders have now been filled and demand will be low from now on. There is a very low demand for small cargo vessels and bulk carriers and there are unlikely to be any new orders for off-shore oil rigs. Defence shipbuilding has always been very irregular and provides a very lumpy demand.

The export position is really no brighter. Between 1981 and 1984 three Australian yards sold ships. Neumann Equipment sold a dredge to Saudi Arabia, the 'K' Shipyard Co. sold 20 fishing trawlers to Indonesia, and Australian Shipbuilding Industries (W.A.) Pty Ltd sold four fishing trawlers to Saudi Arabia. The world market is extremely depressed. There is very high competition for the few existing overseas markets, especially from countries such as the Netherlands, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea. Competition for imported vessels also is increasing. Generally imports into Australia are prohibited but some are allowed in with the approval of the Minister. For example, between 30 September 1979 and 31 October 1983, 61 vessels, new and second hand, were brought into Australia. That averages about 15 vessels a year.

We have a very low economy of scale in this country, with obsolete or outdated plant and equipment compared with overseas yards. We have very low productivity and a high level of industrial unrest. This means that we have a very low comparative advantage against overseas countries. Add to that the world downturn in shipping construction and the oil crisis and there is a low requirement for the building of new ships. The job situation is collapsing, particularly in Australia. If we look at jobs solely or mainly in ship construction, a survey conducted over 90 per cent of shipping industry activity in Australia showed that in the two-year span between 30 October 1983 and 30 June 1985 jobs in Australia collapsed by 76 per cent, from 2,269 jobs down to an estimated 553 at the end of next month. Other factors have led to this unfortunate but inevitable collapse in the number of jobs in the shipping industry in Australia. Overseas yards, apart from their better labour relations, higher productivity and greater throughput, also can offer credit to their clients on more favourable terms. In these tight times credit is really the name of the game. Overseas yards can offer extended credit and more favourable rates of interest.

However, Australian shipbuilders have other disadvantages with which to contend. Let us look at costs in terms of a breakdown of materials, labour and overheads. Of the total building costs of a ship in Australia, on average, material costs make up 57 per cent, labour costs 28 per cent-they vary from 13 to 50 per cent-and overheads 15 per cent. Lowering these costs would be one of the best ways to help shipbuilding in Australia. For example, if we look at the local material cost of shipbuilding in Australia we see that almost 90 per cent of our local materials, when priced against overseas materials, are at least 50 per cent dearer. Our labour on-costs exceed 30 per cent of the wage costs, compared with about 18 per cent in Japan. Our overheads are very high because of our low and irregular demand.

It is clear that if we want to become competitive and sell ships overseas we will never be able to do so until these costs are lowered so that our shipyards can compete on an equal footing. The only alternative method is to subsidise our yards to the hilt which, by itself, encourages inefficiency and is surely not the way we want to go.

I find it particularly hard to stomach extending this bounty at the end of a period of massive devaluation of the Australian dollar. This, in itself, will make Australian-made ships a much more attractive proposition to overseas buyers than they were only a few short months ago. Surely with a 20 to 30 per cent advantage falling into the laps of shipbuilders they do not want a 25 per cent subsidy on top of that. Let us face it. No amount of artificial help from the Government is going to get us export contracts. The world market is too depressed and has substantial surplus capacity, and our competitors are closer to the market than we are and can offer better credit facilities. We should not try to beat that with subsidies from our taxpayers. If we sell our ships at an artificially cheap price simply to get a sale it is simply a case of transferring money from our taxpayers to overseas taxpayers.

As I said earlier, we have sold a few ships to Saudi Arabia. I would have thought that the Saudi Arabian taxpayers with their oil wealth would have been the last group we would want to subsidise. The wide range of types and sizes of ships and the spasmodic demand for certain vessel types does not allow the local industry sufficient scope for achieving the levels of specialisation found in overseas yards.

The $16m of taxpayers' money that we are about to vote away here today to be spent over the next 18 months is equivalent to a subsidy of $29,000 for each worker in the shipbuilding industry over and above the subsidies it already gets. That is $16m extra of taxpayers' money that has to be collected in one way or another from the profitable sector of our economy. It is $16m worth of jobs destroyed in an efficient area to prop up an inefficient area. It is simply a transfer that must lower the overall standard of living for us all.

I guess history will judge that the decline in our shipbuilding industry was largely due to the shocking record of the industrial unrest that it has suffered in recent years. It appears that the union chickens have now come home to roost in that regard. It is such a shame that many many hundreds of workers' jobs have been lost as a result. If we are now to sort our the mess and give the shipbuilding industry a chance the worst thing we can do is grant further assistance. Instead we should address the areas of wage and labour rigidities, the fact that our inflation rate is higher than that in overseas countries and the fact that the world and domestic market situation is in a very tight position.

Short of an enormous cost to the economy we are unlikely to have success on world markets and until we do something about lowering material costs and freeing up labour costs and work patterns, the Australian shipbuilding industry is doomed to stagnate at a low level on the domestic market also. In this regard granting further assistance will not treat even the symptoms let alone the causes of the shipbuilding industry's present ills. I know that the present legislation is well-meaning; nevertheless I fear it is ill-judged and will amount to little more than another $16m of taxpayers' money going down the gurgle hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is predictable but no less regrettable that the Opposition, in talking about the shipbuilding industry, should seek to make the standard allegations that the problems of the shipbuilding industry can in large measure be sheeted home to industrial relations and excessive labour costs. If the Opposition had bothered to read the report of the task force on the shipbuilding industry, which was a tripartite task force, it would have seen that in fact the problems of the shipbuilding industry cannot be appropriately addressed by focusing on industrial relations issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I have something of a personal interest in the question of shipbuilding because the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard, which, according to the table at the conclusion of the task force's report, employed some 720 people in the shipbuilding industry, is in my electorate. It is going to be forced, in effect, to get out of the shipbuilding area, at least for the foreseeable future, and the result of that will be very substantial unemployment. We have already seen the laying off of several hundred people, mainly but not exclusively in the engineering trades. That is obviously a very major human tragedy.

By looking at what happened at Cockatoo Dockyard certain general conclusions can be drawn about the state of the shipbuilding industry. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), made some reference to the problems of industrial disputation. Therefore, I would like to look at the extent to which industrial disputation can be regarded as a source of the problems that that shipyard has suffered. Basically the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard is in the process of completing the supply ship HMAS Success. There have been some major problems with that project. There has been a massive overrun so far as time of completion is concerned and there has also been a massive overrun so far as the cost of the project is concerned. The cost has roughly doubled in real terms by comparison with the initial estimate.

I have attended a number of briefings given by the management of that dockyard, I have spoken with representatives of the union and I have familiarised myself to some extent with what the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has been up to in its investigation of that project as part of its broad investigation of defence procurement policies. According to the management and according to the PAC-they are consistent on this point-something like 30 days of the delay of some six years in the initial completion time can be attributed to industrial action. In other words, it is simply not a significant component of the delay problem. Nobody involved, including management, suggests that the major difficulty that that shipyard has faced and the difficulties it has faced with the HMAS Success project can be sheeted home to industrial relations problems. There was some industrial action for a period in relation to the 38-hour week campaign but that was not a major problem.

The fact is that the difficulties have stemmed from a number of problems that would inevitably arise in a situation where the yard was doing a one-off order without the benefits that would flow from repeat orders. The difficulties arose from mis-specification of the features of the ship. The Department of Defence, I think, must bear a heavy responsibility for that. The ship was of French design and a production package was supplied by the French designers. It included detailed drawings and other necessary elements to build the ship and there were certain components of the ship that would not be made locally. A very significant problem arose from the paucity of that production package. There were problems of translation of language. A Norwegian firm was contracted to produce a set of paper tapes that would be used to operate some numerically controlled cutting devices that would make the various components of the hull, but it was simply not possible for that firm in the first instance to produce those tapes based on the materials that were supplied by the French designing firm. Problems arose also from an incompatibility between the ultimate Department of Defence specification of the ship and the detailed drawings supplied by the French.

All of those sorts of problems were the overwhelming cause of the difficulties. It is fairly obvious that problems of that sort are going to be worse if one is dealing with a one-off order. Initially the intention was to build two such resupply ships. Unfortunately, because of budgetary constraints, it has not proved possible to go down that track. So we are not going to see a repeat order. But there is little doubt that if a second resupply ship had been financed, we would have seen the substantial elimination of the very major problems which have emerged. This just serves to illustrate the fundamental problem which arises when a shipbuilding industry is forced to operate on that basis. I would just like to quote what the task force on shipbuilding had to say about the Defence Department's requirements for shipping and what that means for the shipbuilding industry. The task force on shipbuilding, in paragraph 69 of its report, said:

Defence is the most significant Government purchaser of Australian built vessels of the size covered by this report. Defence shipbuilding contracts have tended to be irregular and are dependent for timing on budgetary constraints and the competing priorities of the three branches of the armed services.
These factors have led to an irregular lumpy demand which has not aided effective planning and investment within the Australian shipbuilding industry.

That epitomises the problems of Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard. This legislation aims to create a framework within which a more viable shipbuilding industry can be developed in the long term by facilitating the development of some sort of export industry. Obviously, if one is successful in doing that to the extent that one's potential market can be enlarged from a purely domestic market to an international market, the problems arising from one-off production are diminished. Hopefully the extension of the bounty to ships built for export will have the beneficial effect of encouraging a more export oriented industry in which economies of scale can be more effectively harnessed. I quote again from the report of the task force on shipbuilding. Paragraph 90 of the report, referring to overheads, states:
Respondents to the Department's survey provided insufficient data to enable an examination of the movement in overheads over the period 1979-1983.
The important bit is coming up:

The most significant factor affecting overheads of the major shipyards since 1980 has been the contraction in demand. Most local builders felt that significant cost savings could be achieved through repeat orders and the marketing of standard vessels. This would enable fixed costs to be amortised over a great number of vessels and may allow savings through bulk ordering of components and materials.

Again, that merely underlines the basic point I am making, that what we need to do is to get away from a shipbuilding industry which is oriented solely to the local market and try to construct a more streamlined industry based on a smaller number of manufacturers but with a more substantial export orientation. If that can be achieved, the sort of tragedy that has occurred in Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard, where we have seen the wholesale dismantling of a skilled shipbuilding work force, will be hopefully attenuated.
I am not pretending for a minute that this legislation is going to be the complete solution to the industry's problems. There are a number of facets to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or even the final solution.

—Or even the final solution. There are a number of elements that are not addressed. Obviously some aspects cannot be addressed. For example, there is a depressed world demand for new ships. The fact that there is an oversupply situation in shipping throughout the world at the moment is a problem that cannot simply be addressed by a piece of legislation of this sort.

SPEECH.PARA: I also note that the task force on shipbuilding talked about the fact that overseas shipbuilders have been able to offer more attractive financial packages than those which have been able to be offered by Australian shipbuilders who may wish to compete with them. Hopefully we will see a more innovative financial system in the years to come that will offer a partial solution to that problem. Whether the entry of new foreign banks will in practice have that effect remains to be seen. However, one would hope that that would be a consequence. I am sure that those who advocated foreign bank entry would have that sort of thing in mind.

I have to conclude my remarks at this point because speakers in this debate are limited to 10 minutes. I certainly support the objective of this legislation. I think the ideologically based opposition to it from Opposition speakers fails to recognise that the real problems of the industry stem from low level production, one-off production, dependency on defence contracts and inability to obtain export orders. These are the real problems of the industry, not the industrial relations difficulties which no doubt have existed to some extent but which, according to all observers, including the management of the firms concerned, certainly do not constitute the major problem that the industry has had to face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time constraints, I wish to limit my remarks to Part IV of the Bill and particularly to clauses 13 and 14 which seek to repeal and replace sections 10, 10A, 11 and 12 of the principal Act. Of course, these particular alterations relate to the registering of persons as prescribed shipbuilders and the registration of premises. I am concerned, of course, that this will have a deleterious effect on the shipbuilding industry. I would like to use an example from the port town of Geraldton in my electorate to show how this can happen. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in his second reading speech was at pains to point out the following:

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier that part of the Government's shipbuilding package is the introduction of registration criteria for the purpose of bounty eligibility. These criteria will ensure that bounty is paid only to those shipbuilders with a clear long term commitment to the industry.

That, of course, means that the legislation will confine the industry to full time workshops when in fact substantial employment can be created in one-off operations. Of course, employment will be lost if, as happened in my electorate, a person who proposed to build a tug literally in his own backyard finds that he can no longer attract the bounty. Consequently, he may make a decision not to build a boat at all but to buy one in Singapore or somewhere else. In my electorate, the Geraldton Tug Co., which is a family business of the Newbold and Mildwaters families, recently built a tug worth approximately $1m. This interesting high technology tug, which contains the latest innovations such as rotating propellers, was literally built in the owners' backyard. A decision was taken to build a tug because the owners were able to attract a bounty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Local design?

—It is a local design. The tug was locally manufactured with local employment. It is something which the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) should see one day. The builders have done a wonderful job. The tug does not have a steering wheel but is driven by a joy stick. The bridge of the boat looks like an aircraft control tower. It is an excellent piece of work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Newbold and Mildwaters families are unique in that they have provided tug services in Geraldton harbour for many years. It is strictly a family business. The Newbolds provide the captain and the seafaring services and the Mildwaters supply the engineer. It was quite interesting to see the families make the decision to build the tug which is in the water and operating very well at present. My concern is that these opportunities and work will be lost as a result of this legislation. I would like to illustrate the difficulties by reading a letter which Mr M. Newbold of the Geraldton Tug Co. received recently. The letter states:
Re: Schedule ''T''-Geraldton
Dear Sir,
Further to our discussions at Geraldton on 17 January, 1985, we request the following changes be made to the methods of working on the tugs in Geraldton.
1. The Tugmasters to be members of the Merchant Services Guild, as employees of the Geraldton Tug Company, not Director/Shareholders as is the case at present.
2. Each tug to have dedicated crews who are designated to act in one capacity only.
3. The manning of the tugs to be-
Wootakara is their old tug and Fairfax is the new one-
Wootakara
Fairfax
1 Master
1 Master
1 Engineer
1 Engineer
2 Deckhands
3 Deckhands
4. An 'Equal Time' leave cycle be implemented-5 weeks on 5 weeks off.
5. Master and Engineer on the 'Fairfax' to be paid category II Tugboat Industry rates of pay.
6. The appropriate Union to supply labour when required.
7. If work required on Company's vessels not normally used for towage, agreement to be reached with Unions beforehand.
We confirm that we will be meeting Geraldton Tug Company representatives at 10.30 on 30th January, 1985 at the Seamans' Union boardroom, Terminus Chambers, Packenham Street, Fremantle.
Yours faithfully,M. S. BOORMANFor and on behalf of Maritime UnionsC. C. Guild &Institute Members

That might seem to be a rather innocent piece of correspondence, but it tells the owners of the Geraldton Tug Co., to get off their tug. It tells them that they will not be able to drive it any more. As owners and drivers with a family tradition, they will not be able to drive their own tug, and that is why I am concerned about what this legislation is leading us to. It will restrict to certain major yards the business of shipbuilding, and in my mind that will mean, unfortunately, telling people that only union members may engage in the industry. It will create a closed shop situation.

The meeting to which I referred has taken place. The owners refused to take the instruction and were immediately confronted with strikes. The problem with the strikes is that already ships have stopped coming into the Geraldton port. Although these people have right on their side, the pilots have stopped bringing the boats in. They have a three-year contract for their $1m tug and if they lose that contract they will be in severe financial difficulty. It is now for the Harbour Board in Geraldton to decide whether it sees these people as so disruptive to the operation of the port that it cannot re-employ them. This has all come about because people have been told not to operate their own tugs. The honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) mentioned something about industrial disputes. That seems to me to be an industrial dispute of the most distasteful kind.

We have to look at the situation that exists in Geraldton. Geraldton is also the port for 500 cray fishermen-500 boats. Are they the next on the hit list? Are they shortly to be standing on the beach while members of the Seamen's Union of Australia take their crayfish boats out into hazardous waters and possibly do not bring them back? Is that what we are being promised? It is interesting that this situation has occurred in Geraldton, because another infamous situation of this nature also originated in Geraldton. I will not go into detail, but I mention the famous John O'Connor case of a charge of extortion against a unionist in which the defendant was eventually found innocent, having been committed for trial by a lower court on charges brought by the State Government of Western Australia. That dispute originated in Geraldton also. On both occasions a senior Minister of that Government, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, was the member for Geraldton. I just wonder where he stands on this new issue. I wonder whether he will tolerate people being told to get off their own boats and not being allowed to use it any more. It is a disgraceful situation. I challenge the local member in Geraldton to see that it does not happen. It is still going on. The people are still concerned; they are still under threat. Will someone who buys a truck to operate as an owner-driver truckie get a letter from the union saying: 'You will not drive you own truck. You are to sit at home and pay someone else to drive it.'? It is un-Australian; it is disgraceful. Unfortunately, this legislation tends to leads us in that direction. It is a recipe for a closed shop and it is most important that the Government consider that point.

The Government says that it is making what it sees as a clear long term commitment to the industry. There is no criticism of that. That is a desirable thing to do, but unfortunately things do not always come out as governments intend. I think what will happen in this case is that a large number of owners who have the ability to build a tug or a smaller vessel which still qualifies for a bounty will not be able to do so. Even the tug to which I refer was not built near the water, as required by the new registration criteria. Today we have massive cranes and pieces of equipment to move things along our roads. That requirement just makes it more difficult for people to get into the industry. More importantly, I am sure that employment will be lost through this proposal. This is a classic example of people taking the initiative into their own hands and, with the aid of the Government bounty, building a very capable piece of equipment with excellent technology which works extremely well. They have managed to do it in their back yard, creating employment in their town for local people. Under this new legislation, were they to choose to build another tug in the future they would not be able to do so. I do not think that is wise.

It is a fact that vessels of that nature can be built in other parts of the world. A large number of secondhand vessels are available which, if a person chooses to pay the duty, he can import for less than it costs to manufacture one himself. That option is open to many people. I well remember the debates about the very wealthy men getting these bounties to have luxury boats built in Queensland. People wrote to me about it and I replied to them saying: 'I am sure that the purchasers of those boats are not too worried whether the boat is built in Queensland or Singapore. It is not a bounty to them, it is a bounty to the workers who work on the boats and are unable, because of Australia's wages and conditions, to meet competitively the challenge from other shipyards around the world'. That is what we are talking about. I do not think we should remove any opportunity to construct a boat in Australia, whether it is built in what will now be called a registered yard in a closed union shop or whether it is built in someone's back yard. If a person can do the job to the proper standard he should be entitled to do it.

I am glad that the Government has allowed me to read into Hansard the letter to the Geraldton Tug Co. I feel that the situation described in that letter is one of the most disgraceful things I have ever come across. If we are going to allow that situation to continue we may as well say that unions are allowed to write to those who own or rent homes and tell them to get out of their homes and rent it to a worker. It is the same thing. A family business is a family business, and the family is entitled to run it. That instruction which is being pursued by the union at this moment is disgraceful and reflects very badly on the local member, Mr Jeff Carr.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for their contributions to this debate. A number of the issues that have been raised about particular locations and the problems of specific regions connected with shipbuilding have been noted. I will take them up with my colleague Senator Button. We are all conscious of the need to expedite legislation, so I will save any further comments for the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in his second reading speech on the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill stressed that the incentives incorporated in this Bill are to be subject to review. Senator Button, in his speech in another place, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the reports from the SCG-the Shipbuilding Consultative Group-indicate that continual progress towards rationalisation is not being achieved, the Government will review the augmented assistance package. Whether the export bounty is paid beyond the 1985-86 financial year will depend on the degree of progress achieved. Subject to the combined industry and union response the Government will consider whether the general bounty assistance should also be reviewed.

The Opposition believes that any such package of government assistance to one industry should be closely scrutinised to ensure that funds are being invested to best stimulate industrial growth and international competitiveness. We do not believe that assistance should be open-ended but that it should be subject to regular review and that that review should enable the effectiveness of any assistance program to be evaluated against the Government's own objectives for a particular industry.

The shipbuilding industry has been the subject of government assistance over a number or years, as I noted in my speech during the second reading debate. The continuance of assistance that has no limit does not necessarily lead to improved international competitiveness, nor is it necessarily in the interests of the industry as a whole. For these reasons, on behalf of the Opposition I propose to insert a sunset clause providing for the cessation of bounty payment generally on 30 June 1987 and requiring the Government to bring forward further proposals in accordance with the second reading speech. I regard this amendment as being consistent with what has been clearly stated in the Government's second reading speech as the objectives of its policy. I think it would therefore be worth while to incorporate this provision in the Bill so that the sunset clause takes effect on 30 June 1987. I move:
Page 8, after clause 7 insert the following new clause:
Bounty not payable in respect of construction or modification completed after 30 June 1987
''7A. Section 6 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following sub-section:
'(6) Bounty is not payable in respect of the construction or modification of a vessel where that construction or modification is completed after 30 June 1987.' ''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the responsibility of the Government to ensure that the interpretation of its guidelines results in the major proportion of the bounty being payable to the specialist shipbuilding industry through rationalisation. The Government has failed to outline the criteria that will be used to measure rationalisation. Either the Government does not know how it will specifically achieve rationalisation or it has failed to inform the House and industry. Either way, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should rectify his blunder immediately. Australian shipbuilders are well placed to contribute a small, but solid, stable industry to our economy. They cannot afford to be the victim of this Government's increasing trend to pay full attention to the glamorous and trendy issues such as tax, welfare and education, while other vital issues are subjected to ad hoc 'she'll be right Jack' policies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that this House notes that none of this bounty assistance would be necessary if the Government were successfully managing the economy. Indeed, if the Government cannot stop vacillating on its macro-economic policies, all the bounty assistance in the world will not help shipbuilders and other exporters. The seemingly unending devaluation of the Australian dollar provides opportunity for industries such as shipbuilding to improve both their export potential and domestic competitiveness. Unfortunately, the Hawke Government has eroded this opportunity by failing to confront the threat of higher inflation caused by devaluation and wage indexation. The result will be a catch-22 situation. Many industries will feel justified in seeking higher bounties and tariffs. This would be unacceptable to the Opposition, given our approach to deregulation and decreasing protection. As the task force said in its report, labour on-costs in Australian shipbuilding are a significant component of total wage costs. They run at about 30 per cent compared with 18 per cent in Japan. While Japan faces an average wage increase of around 4 per cent for 1985-86, the Hawke Government speaks of supporting wage increases of around 8 to 9 per cent in 1985-86--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, on a point of order: I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable member in full flight but, with respect, I think that this is a disguised second reading debate speech. He has had his opportunity.
—Order! I point out to the Minister that we are considering the Bill as a whole in Committee.
—He seems to be dealing with matters of policy rather than matters relating to the amendment.
—He is not speaking to the amendment but to the Bill, as a whole, because that is how the Committee is considering it.

—I repeat: While Japan faces an average wage increase of around 4 per cent for 1985-86, the Hawke Government speaks of supporting wage increases of around 8 per cent in 1985-86 which includes at least 9 per cent for the direct and indirect effects of devaluation. I sincerely hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) do not lie awake at night agonising over why we have slipped to sixteenth place behind our key trading competitors. The answer lies in the ongoing policy of the Prime Minister to put Australian Labor Party factionalism and union interests above that of the national interest. How can a policy, which forces an industry like shipbuilding to pay the same rates and conditions as a service industry not subject to import competition, be justified by anyone with a grain of economic understanding? If I could make the Treasurer understand this small point, I am sure Australians would gladly forgo the reflected glory of his 'Treasurer of the Year' prize.

SPEECH.PARA: There will always be problems for exporters in the labour market whilst ever the current rigidities exist. Labour decisions are being made outside the worker-manager relationship by a body which continuously demonstrates how far removed it is from the realities of the work place and the capacity of industry to pay. Far too many small unions, whose interests are very similar to those of larger unions operating in the same industry area, are causing unnecessary disruption to industry. Too often, two men are being used for jobs which require only one man to avoid the eruption of demarcation disputes. Now is the time to disband unions with membership of less than 1,000, which will pave the way for amalgamation. Last week the Treasurer ruled out discounting of wages. The need for discounting has arisen because of the judgment of the international business community on the Australian economy. The judgment has been harsh and with good reason. Exporters have waited for the Government to announce its policy response-that future national wage rises would be discounted for the inflationary impact of the dollar's devaluation. But no, when it came time to crunch the union muscle, the Hawke Government had no stomach for what it had to do and what should be done.

The Government has been saying far and wide that Australia's slump in international competitiveness is due to declining commodity prices and our inward-looking manufacturing industry. It would be more accurate to say that the slump can be attributed to the sectional and inward looking nature of the Hawke Government on issues such as flexibility in the wage structure, accountability for unions and tax reform which returns incentive to the private sector. Key requirements in each of the main areas of policy can be easily enough stated. Difficulties arise through the interaction of macro-economic instruments, such as the imbalance between monetary and fiscal policy and the inconsistency between indexation and exchange rate arrangements. Wage restraint via indexation affects the balance between fiscal and monetary policy when it depends on tax cuts unmatched by expenditure restraint. Fiscal and monetary policy have important exchange rate implications which are fundamental to the rise or fall of the export sector, although this Government has made no tangible recognition of that factor.

The Hawke Government cannot afford to allow the export sector to continue to bear a disproportionate burden of protection as a result of its failure to seize the opportunity presented by the recent exchange rate movements to reduce protection, despite the fact that effective rates of assistance now dwarf initial levels. The Opposition's concern is simply this: How far do we have to slip behind our trading partners-we are down to sixteenth place now-before the Hawke Government makes a policy response that acknowledges that until public sector spending is cut in real terms, Australia's economic potential will not be realised and perceived inadequacies of industry policy will continue to be treated with band-aids?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government cannot accept the amendment moved by the Opposition. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) argues that the provisions in this Bill are open-ended and insufficiently scrutinised and he proposes a sunset clause. We regard a sunset clause as unnecessary and argue that the Bill already provides for adequate scrutiny. As the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) observed in his speech during the second reading debate, there will be some anomalous cases involving meritorious shipbuilders who may be excluded by the legislation-that is, occasional shipbuilders rather than regular round the year shipbuilders-even when products are of high quality. The whole aim of consolidation was made clear by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) when it was widely announced in October 1984. It means reduction in numbers, consolidation of effort, and continuity and stability of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) that the criteria which have been set out to qualify for registration involve these elements. First, the body concerned must be a registered Australian company, business or organisation. Second, it must demonstrate financial and commercial capacity by way of an independent auditor's report to build a bountiable vessel. Third, it must employ directly or through nominated sub-contractors or have demonstrated clearly that an average of 20 persons will be dedicated to shipbuilding throughout the period of construction for the purpose of building the bountiable vessel. This is to be substantiated by periodic returns. Fourth, it must have an ongoing apprenticeship scheme employing a ratio of at least one apprentice to eight tradesmen directly employed by the shipyard and encourage all sub-contractors to maintain a similar scheme. Fifth, it must own or have access to shipbuilding facilities, including a waterfront site, which are assessed as adequate for building the vessel or vessels for which registration is sought.

I freely admit concern that some organisations with existing capacity will be disadvantaged. But the alternative is for the present situation to continue where capacity is dispersed so widely across the continent that none survives, and there has ceased to be a viable industry altogether. The Government would be much more subject to criticism if we let the situation deteriorate and ignored the recommendations made by a very highly qualified group to try rationalising this industry.

The decision to extend the bounty to cover export activity must be considered in the context of the discussions the Government held with the industry and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions prior to the announcement of the Government's new assistance package on 11 October 1984. One should remember that section 13, which was referred to by the honourable member for O'Connor, requires that the applicant for registration must have been on 11 October 1984-my birthday as it happens-engaged in the construction then. It is not enough to say: 'I have a great idea. I think I'll set up a new firm tomorrow'. The applicant must have been engaged in construction at that date.

It was mentioned in the second reading speech that, as part of the package, the industry and the trade unions-both sides of the table-have agreed to endeavour to achieve industrial agreement over a range of issues. On the basis of this agreement and as an incentive to industry to improve further its competitive position, the Government decided to extend the existing bounty to vessels constructed for export. Progress in the discussions between the industry and the unions on industry rationalisation will be closely monitored by the Shipbuilding Consultative Group. The Group will be required to report to the Minister on a quarterly basis. Both the industry and the unions are well aware that if continual progress towards industry rationalisation and improved industrial relations is not being achieved the Government will review the new assistance package. On the other hand, if progress is achieved the Government may wish to continue the bounty on export activity. As a consequence it is necessary to have flexibility in the package so that the assistance arrangements could be extended, if necessary, by the Government.

Adoption of the Opposition's amendment would do two things. Firstly, it would overturn the tripartite agreement and, secondly, it would remove the incentive for the industry to take positive steps to improve its competitive position, which is the central element of the Government's package. Finally, I draw honourable members' attention to the statement also made in the second reading speech where the Government indicated that, subject to the combined industry-union response, it would consider whether the previously existing bounty assistance should also be reviewed. I repeat that, for the reasons which have been indicated, the amendment moved by the Opposition cannot be accepted.
Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 8, page 9, lines 1 to 13, omit proposed sub-sections 6A (2) and (3), insert the following sub-sections:

'' '(2) If the Comptroller-General is of the opinion, in relation to a period referred to in sub-section (1), that the amount (in this sub-section referred to as the ''relevant amount'') available for payment of bounty in respect of the construction or modification of bountiable vessels of the kind referred to in sub-section (1) will be or is insufficient to meet all valid claims for bounty in respect of the vessels, amounts of bounty in respect of the claims shall, subject to the regulations, be approved for payment in such order as is determined by the Comptroller-General in writing and, when the aggregate of the amounts of bounty approved for payment in respect of the vessels equals the relevant amount, no further amounts of bounty are payable in respect of the vessels.
'(3) Without limiting the generality of sub-section (2), regulations made for the purposes of that sub-section may make provision for and in relation to-

(a) the reservation of amounts available, in relation to a period referred to in sub-section (1), for payment of bounty in respect of the construction or modification of bountiable vessels of the kind referred to in that sub-section;
(b) amounts in respect of amounts of bounty so reserved to be approved for payment before any other amounts of bounty are approved for payment; and
(c) deeming the construction or modification of vessels that are completed outside such a period to have been completed within such a period.' ''.
(2) Clause 11, page 10, line 1, insert ''but subject to sub-section 6A (2),'' after ''claim,''.
(3) Clause 11, page 10, line 41, insert ''but subject to sub-section 6A (2),'' after ''apply,''.
(4) Clause 15, page 20, lines 32 to 41, omit the clause, insert the following clause:
Stock-taking and inspection of production and accounts, &.
''15. Section 14 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting from paragraph (1) (a) 'yards; or' and substituting 'premises;';
(b) by inserting after paragraph (1) (b) the following word and paragraph:

'; or (ba) premises where there are kept any accounts, books, documents or other records relating to the construction or modification (including the cost of construction or modification) of any bountiable vessel,';
(c) by omitting paragraph (1) (e) and substituting the following:
'(e) inspect the accounts, books, documents and other records relating to the construction or modification of any bountiable vessel,
any may make and retain copies of, or take and retain extracts from, any such accounts, books, documents and other records'; and
(d) by omitting from sub-section (2) 'registered yards' and substituting 'registered premises'.''.
(5) Clause 21, page 25, line 21, omit ''or''.
(6) Clause 21, page 25, at the end of proposed sub-section 20 (2) add the following paragraphs:
''(g) if a determination has been made by virtue of sub-section 6A (2) in respect of the construction or modification of the vessel, either-
(i) set aside the determination; or
(ii) set aside the determination and make a further determination under that sub-section in respect of the construction or modification of the vessel; or
(h) if a determination has not been made under sub-section 6A (2) in respect of the construction or modification of the vessel, make such a determination.'.

The amendments to clause 8 of the Bill propose to allow for the payment of bounties on export vessels on a strict 'first come, first served' basis until the funds available in proposed new section 6A are exhausted. In other words, bounty payments will be paid in the order of the receipt of claims until the bounty funds run out. The system proposed in the Bill for the payment of the export bounty does not remove the entitlement to the bounty when funds are exhausted in a period. Under the provisions of the Bill entitlements would be deferred only to the next period in which funds become available. The amendment implements the Government's intention to remove the entitlement to bounty when funds are exhausted. The Government does not intend to provide open-ended assistance for export activity, particularly in view of the current budgetary restraints. It is therefore necessary to amend the Bill to provide for an absolute limit on assistance to the industry in relation to export activity. The proposed limitation on the bounty assistance has been discussed with and accepted by the industry.

Because of the introduction in the Bill of the concept of prescribed shipbuilders, the Government considers it necessary that the opportunity be taken here to amend the provisions in the Act relating to the inspection of records and to extend those provisions to records kept at the premises of those shipbuilders. A prescribed shipbuilder is a person who arranges to have a ship constructed or modified on his behalf. The amendments to clause 15 propose to effect this change. Amendments (5) and (6) to clause 21 are consequential upon this action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a few very brief remarks to make in relation to the Government's proposed amendments. I was wondering whether the Minister can explain proposed new sub-section 6A (3). Does it mean that the Government could raise an amendment to direct all the bounty funds to one class vessel-for example, to ferries-to the exclusion of other classes of bountiable ships? The Opposition would be grateful if the Minister could let us have some examples as to the impact of this clause, as it would seem that the regulations under this sub-section are subject to parliamentary disallowance. We naturally support the imposition of a regulation which is liable to parliamentary disallowance in this manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer to the question of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) is that only one bounty is payable per application. Because of the provision that payment will be made on a first come first served basis, that is the criterion. Philosophically, one could think of a variety of different ways in which the bounty could be paid. Preference could be given to a particular class of vessels: That would be one way of doing it. Another way would be for amounts to be paid on a regional basis. One could say, 'There are special problems in Queensland and in the West' and we pay the bounty that way. Alternatively, we could say that we will look for--
—First come, best dressed.

—'First come, best dressed' is in fact the principle we adopted. It is quite arbitrary, but there is a certain rationality in it. Provided that all players in the game are aware of it, no one will be particularly disadvantaged. If we apply that criterion, whoever gets the application in first and fits the broad guidelines will not be disadvantaged by our saying: 'We would have given you the bounty if it had been in a particular category, but we decline to give you the bounty because it is not'.
