PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1985 concurrently with the Broadcasting and Television (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendments Bill 1985 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1985. Is there any objection? There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the introduction of the service-based concept and the amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act which are proposed under this amending legislation. This introduction of the service-based concept appears to the Opposition to be infinitely sensible and would overcome some of the problems which have been noticed by the licence holders in recent times in connection with this area. Those honourable members who are in the House will be aware that it is the intention of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to gazette the precise area in which the stations can operate. Within that area the licensees will be able to conduct their business as a whole rather than having to approach the Government again for permission for a translator or other services which might be required.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I move to the many aspects of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and cognate Bills which raised some questions in the mind of the Opposition, I draw to the House's attention the Opposition's concern about the haste with which this legislation has been pushed through without adequate time being given for interest groups to pursue this matter. The Opposition feels that a proper course would have been for the legislation to have been introduced in this session and allowed to lie on the table until the Budget session. This is necessarily lengthy legislation and one would have thought that the more sensible approach would have been to have allowed for careful scrutiny by interested parties and the hearing of their views on its implementation and practicality. On the other hand, the Opposition is not unsympathetic to the Government's need to resolve the matter of licences for remote areas and to be able to go ahead immediately with the issuing of these licences when the Act is proclaimed.

The Opposition is committed to providing these services to those many Australians in the outback. But we feel that, despite some drafting problems, consideration could have been given to legislation covering the issue of licences for remote areas being given immediate assent rather than having to wait some six months for royal assent to the existing Bill after regulations have been drawn. The Opposition concedes the difficulty in this proposal. However, it feels that it would be outweighed by the advantages of allowing close scrutiny and subsequent meaningful consultation with the interested parties. The Opposition notes that the Department of Communications will be conducting a seminar on the Bill and will be inviting further opportunity for public and industry input. If such is the case, what will be the position if any anomalies are raised and substantiated by persons and organisations? Is the Minister prepared to give to the House an undertaking that these will be remedied? If they cannot be covered by the proposed regulations, will the Bill be amended? The Opposition has been approached by interested persons and organisations who refute that the Government has indeed had adequate input from them and claim that it has failed to live up to its much-vaunted consensus and consultation style of government.

The Opposition feels that the Government, in its haste to push through the legislation, is adopting the attitude that many extraneous matters alluded to in the second reading speech of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) can be tidied up in the regulations. This cart before the horse attitude will no doubt create a drafting headache in the months ahead. It seems to be another example of the Government asking the people to trust it. Honourable members are warned that, regardless of how sympathetically these matters are dealt with by the Minister's second reading speech, unless they are expressly defined by the Bill or the proposed regulations they are worthless. The Opposition adopts the view that if, after belated consultation with the public and the industry, the Bill, as opposed to the regulations, requires amendment, the argument against the undue haste of the Government in forcing this legislation through will be seen to be valid. For the Government to argue that to do so would require subsequent amendment to the Bill seems futile, as if it honours the noble words of the Minister on consultation. To further reinforce this argument, the Minister has side-stepped amending this Bill to confirm the standard setting powers of the Tribunal. The Opposition does not wish to argue the merits of this decision or the possible repercussions of the High Court decision. However, it supports our contention that the presentation has been unduly pushed.

Some of the anomalies which are concerning the industry and which are of concern to the Opposition are as follows: As to clause 8 of the Bill, proposed new section 6B refers to a program broadcast or transmitted but omits any reference to other matter, including advertising. One might assume from the Bill in its present form that the retransmission of advertisements and other non-program matter by means of telegraph lines is permitted. The Minister should consider amending the Bill by inserting the words 'and other matter' after the word 'program' on each of the three occasions when that word appears in the proposed new section. This addition would be entirely consistent with the principle of the Act. As to clause 10, proposed new sub-section 16 (2) appears to contain a contradiction in that, while it refers to the Tribunal's power to set standards under sub-section 16 (1) (e), it makes mention only of programs. For the purposes of clarity the proposed new sub-section could be amended by adding after the word 'programs' the words 'and advertisements'.

As to clause 12, proposed new sub-section 17C (1) requires the Tribunal to hold an inquiry on each occasion that it receives one or more applications for it to exercise any of its substantive powers. No discretionary power has been given to the Tribunal to decide whether or not the application has merit. The Administrative Review Council's recommendation on which this new provision is based is that, once the Tribunal has decided to exercise any of its substantive powers, it must hold an inquiry. In its present form proposed new sub-section 17C (1) gives the initiative to conduct an inquiry to a person lodging a submission. Failure to suitably amend this proposed new sub-section will result in an unending and totally unmanageable series of inquiries, many of which are likely to be on the most frivolous of grounds.

As to clause 19, proposed new sub-section 22(2) appears to be unique to Australian legislation. Therefore, there is uncertainty as to the extent of the obligations on the Tribunal to ensure that no party suffers detriment. If the proposed new sub-section is retained in its present form it is predicted that it will give rise to extensive legal argument and ultimate litigation. As to clause 23, it would appear that proposed new section 25AA extends beyond the recommendations of the ARC. In its proposed form the new section would permit the Tribunal to extend its inquiries into the broadcasting practices of a licensee as far back and as far forward in time as it wishes. It is totally unnecessary for the Tribunal to consider program practices engaged upon prior to the last renewal. The broadcasting practices of the licensee prior to that date have been considered by the Tribunal and the licence renewed.

There are two reasons why the Tribunal should not be empowered to investigate or comment upon future broadcasting practices. Firstly, the future broadcasting practices of a licensee are likely to be highly confidential and their publication could provide competitors and potential advertising consumers with the information which might be detrimental to the licensee. No protection exists under the Freedom of Information Act to preserve the confidentiality of a licensee's legitimate business secrets if disclosed to the Tribunal. Further, the granting of a power to the Tribunal to comment on future broadcasting practices implies that the Tribunal may be able to influence the future programming policies of the licensee.

As to clause 42, there is concern about the granting of almost unlimited powers to the Tribunal in respect of the transfer of a remote licence. Proposed new paragraph 89A (1D) (ca) (vi) confers on the Tribunal a wider power than any other part of the principal Act. It would appear to have the right to make an arbitrary decision as to what matters or circumstances may be relevant to it as grounds for refusal of the transfer. Such sweeping powers should not be granted to the Tribunal. As to clause 65, in his second reading speech the Minister said:
The fact that a licensee has not yet provided locally originated programs will not be a ground for censure of the licensee for not providing an adequate and comprehensive service.
Proposed new section 99A does not reflect the Minister's intentions. There is concern that the absence of a precise provision may unnecessarily raise people's expectations.

Finally, as to clause 92, proposed new section 133A concerns government policy statements. There is no requirement for the Minister to make public a government policy statement or to make that statement available to licensees at the time the policy statement is given to the Tribunal. The policy statement could be delivered to the Tribunal following the last day of a sitting and considerable time could elapse between that date and the next sitting of Parliament when the 15 sitting days referred to in the proposed new section would occur. This proposed new section should be tightened to ensure not only that licensees or their representatives are given access to the policy statement at the time it is made available to the Tribunal but also that the elapsed time between the delivery of the policy statement to the Tribunal and its being laid before each House of the Parliament is not greater than the total of 21 days, including 15 sitting days of either House.

In conclusion, this Bill is necessary and contains the most extensive revisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act. The Opposition reiterates that such an important and vital piece of legislation must be concise as to what it purports to do. Succinctly, the Parliament has a duty to get it right the first time. The Opposition has some misgivings that this has been achieved and submits that the proper course would have been to legislate separately for the introduction of remote licences and to introduce the remainder of this Bill this sitting and allow it to lie on the table for further consultation. However, if the Government is committed to pass this Bill as it stands, as it appears to be, reluctantly the Opposition will not oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the legislation. I commend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the Government for putting so much work into the communications arena. I commend the Government on the communications policy which it has adopted over the last two years and particularly over the last 12 months. This culminated in a ministerial statement by the Minister some time ago. It was that policy statement made in this House that set the right track for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which has to take note of government policy in its deliberations in regard to licensing of broadcasters in remote areas. This was, of course, brought about by the decision of the Government to go ahead with the introduction of the satellite broadcasting system. Two satellites will be launched this year-the first in a couple of months' time and the second later this year. The third will possibly be launched next year. The introduction of those satellite services really changes the whole concept of broadcasting of television in particular in Australia. The greatest impact will occur in the outback. It is in that respect that I would like to make a few comments now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill which is before us provides a clear pointer to the Government's position on communications policy. The policy is for the extension of services to remote regions. It provides for the simplification of licensing provisions to allow for the smooth introduction of new and appropriate technology. It opposes any further concentration of ownership by major city networks and resists what some may have seen as the inevitable impulse to national networking through the facilities of Aussat Pty Ltd which is the Government company that will manage the satellite system. The remote area licensing concept has been developed to meet the real but unique needs of individuals and communities in remote areas who are currently without commercial television services. The remote commercial television services-RCTS-licences will be based on high power signals beamed from the satellite to four regional footprints or zones which make up the Australian land mass and surrounding waters. The objective of the scheme is to encourage a commercial service appropriately geared to the needs and interests of people in these remote zones, to provide local and regional identification and special interest programming and to present programming appropriate to the time zone.

In the field of broadcasting services to remote areas, the satellite could have become for us one of the classic cases of technological determinism. After all, here was a piece of technology capable of bathing the nation coast to coast with broadcast signals emanating from one source. This Government and even, on occasions, the Opposition-although I get a little confused from time to time-depending on whom one listens to-have long held the position that the ownership and control of broadcasting facilities should not be allowed to concentrate further and that diversity of ownership and product should be maintained. If we had gone down that track the technology, very conceivably, could have led us to being left with very few broadcasting stations at all. The scheme would have been narrowed down, to, say, three providers, with the largest capable of transmitting right across the country. Regional stations could not have borne for long the competition involved with larger networks actually broadcasting into their service areas. Those networks, with their economies of scales and access to the means of national coverage, would have had the market all sewn up.

There are various points to be made in this respect. The proposal which the networks have put continually to the Government-it has been enshrined in various schemes but basically has remained the same-is that they broadcast directly from their major stations in Melbourne or Sydney right across Australia. While this is technically feasible, what it will do-if not in the very short term, in the not too long term-is ensure the complete demise of regional television. I am sure that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) would not agree with that. Regional television could not have borne that competition. It is appropriate to note that the latest schemes which have been put forward by the networks would, I believe, have provided windows to regional stations to provide local programs. In a practical world it would have meant that the regional stations would have needed only a small room with a camera and a couple of staff in order to run their 15-minute news service or whatever at night. In the long term they could have virtually done away with the rest of their staff and facilities.

There are many questions to be addressed. Technological change in this area continues to occur. At this stage we look forward to the second grouping of satellites to go up in the 1990s. From my own viewpoint, I think it is appropriate that the Government has spent many hours on this and feels that it is the most appropriate scheme. It is the most appropriate policy to put in place. We are looking at regionally based television for the rural and outback areas. The four footprint scheme, if I can term it that, does have wide backing in the regional areas. Applications have gone before the Tribunal. Some of them are very advanced. Several months ago I spoke to some of the applicants. They are very well advanced in their planning and ideas of what they want to do if they are successful in their applications. I remind the House that the Government has nothing to do with that. It is the Tribunal's decision as to who receives the licence after all the applications are in. The Tribunal must take note of the Government's policy which was put forward by the Minister, I think last year, in this House.

The Government, in this Bill, has also provided for service-based licensing arrangements. At present the hardware has to be licensed. For instance, if one puts up a new transmitter to service people in a community who are not being serviced or who are not being serviced properly, one must apply for that transmitter to be licensed separately. Instead of licensing hardware, the Bill provides that service areas will be licensed. One licence is required to service an area and it is the responsibility of the licensee to provide the service in that area. The licensee does not need separate licences to set up separate translators in order to provide the service to individual communities that may exist in small pockets throughout his service area.

The idea of service-based licensing arrangements, I think, is a much more rational idea. It will simplify many aspects of the legislation and the practical application in the work place for many licensees. It represents a major change. It has been discussed by members of the Government for quite some time and I am glad to see it before the House at this time. Of course, all of this works together with the satellite. The work of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be facilitated by the passage of these Bills through both Houses.

I appreciate that the honourable member for Bendigo will make a few comments in regard to an article published recently in the Bulletin magazine. I will leave that matter for him to address. I just point out that that article was nonsense. It had its facts, shall we say, back to front. It did not really address appropriately the questions before the broadcasting industry. The honourable member for Bendigo will say a bit more about that when he speaks in this House.

It has been interesting to see the small struggle that has been going on regarding the concentration of ownership. In fact, even the recent publicity regarding Rupert Murdoch's activities in America raises a lot of questions about future broadcasting in this country. I do not say that in order to flag the Government's viewpoint. Depending on what happens, this could push television broadcasting in all sorts of directions in the future. If Mr Murdoch is able to arrange his companies in such a way as still to have control, in effect that would mean a foreign person-I do not use that term to denigrate Mr Murdoch because I have nothing against him personally-having some control over a broadcasting network in Australia. In the American situation his control raises the possibility of concentration of ownership in regard to television stations and newspapers in the one city. In fact, it raises the question of whether in Australia we should continue to have the same extent of ownership as at present. That matter was raised by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its report last year, where effectively the Tribunal said that we should rip licences off a few people. The Government has not gone down that track. However, the Murdoch position in America raises a lot of questions that obviously governments in the future will need to address.

This goes back to the legislation and the fact that regionally based consortiums winning the licences for the remote commercial television service for which this Bill provides will move away from the concentration of ownership that would have been paramount if the major networks had been given the right to direct broadcast. Many people, especially those in the National Party of Australia, would appreciate that, effectively, that would have meant three broadcasters in Australia with blanket broadcasts across the continent. In Western Australia there would have been a two-hour time difference, a problem which has never been addressed by the networks. I do not believe that we will ever see the situation of three people controlling broadcasting in this country. I quite confidently say that is not something I would ever support, and I do not believe I would ever be sitting on this side of the chamber with a government that supported such an idea. It is a principle that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) also would find hard to wear because it goes right back to security considerations in other times.

In closing I refer to clause 62 of this rather complex Bill. The clause relates to proposed sub-sections 92V (3) and 92V (4), and the ownership or control of remote licences. It is interesting to note that proposed sub-section 92V (4) states:

. . . 'control' includes direct or indirect control and control as a result of, or by means of, trust, agreements, arrangements, understandings and practices, whether or not having legal or equitable force and whether or not based on legal or equitable rights;

That appears to me to be a little stronger than the provision in the original Act. I am not suggesting that the Government should do anything about that, and certainly the Government has not done anything in that regard. Because that provision is stronger than the provision in the original Act, if the Government did go down that track and change the original provision, I wonder how Rupert Murdoch would go. I think he would be knocked over in one fell swoop, no matter which way he tried to manoeuvre his companies. As I said before, that is not a personal thing against Rupert Murdoch. I have a long-standing view that, no matter who is involved, the foreign ownership provisions must be maintained rigidly. We just cannot have foreign interests controlling the communications of a country. It is not on; I do not think it is appropriate. The Bill before us has been researched and has been before the Government for consideration for many months. It has been discussed thoroughly. I recommend all the provisions of this legislation, particularly the remote area and the service provisions, to all honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly my privilege to speak today on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and cognate Bills. I am the only member of Parliament to speak on this legislation who represents a really remote area. It has been a battle for me this morning even to get to the top of the list of speakers. However, I was determined on behalf of my constituents to put forward some of their views.
—You should have come to see me.

—I regularly speak with the Minister. I guess the only disappointment I have today is that the House of Representatives debate is not being broadcast. I think it would have been very interesting for those people who live in remote Australia to have been able to listen to the radio broadcast of the debate on these Bills. Unfortunately that was not to be. Under the Bills, a lot of people-roughly 650,000-will receive a radio signal for the first time. It is interesting to note that a lot of remote dwellers do not even receive an adequate radio signal. Of course, the satellite will give them more than one radio signal. There will be an FM and an AM radio signal, which certainly will be a tremendous improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the satellite will be to broadcast television to these remote areas. I congratulate previous governments for the fact that we are to launch a satellite in August. I also congratulate the present Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for continuing down that track and, I hope, for winning the fight with the Hawke-Packer group in maintaining the regional networks. I remind the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that for those of us who live in regional Australia he is not the only member of Parliament. I know he is the Prime Minister and operates out of Melbourne, but I remind him that there are many members of this House who support, operate and work very closely with regional television and radio stations.

Those of us who live in scattered areas of Australia like to maintain the regionalism of broadcasting. For someone who represents a big electorate such as Maranoa, which is two or three times the size of Victoria, I am amazed when I travel around to see how regionalised such areas have become. We live in a vast continent. It is interesting to see the controversy that has broken out about the National program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Because of the satellite we will have to become a little more national, if you like, than we were previously. We will have to broaden the umbrella, although I have never believed that we should go the whole hog and broadcast across the nation. I support the Minister's concept of footprints on approximately a State basis. At least we are still able to retain the networks and communications that we have with one another in those areas.

Presently western Queensland is getting some telecasts from Sydney. Because of Intelsat and the configurations, we have attempted to make some changes. A number of us have met in Townsville to try to get some change. Presently the western Queensland dish is operating on the Intelsat IV satellite, receiving news and weather from Sydney. I can assure honourable members that people in that region are not very happy about it. I note that it is Government policy to encourage localism in broadcasting to serve the needs of local communities. This matter was mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech. I hope that the Prime Minister and his boys from Sydney are listening to this debate because when the licences are granted I hope that that will be done on a reasonable basis.

I put it to the Minister that a lot of stories have been put around that people cannot afford a licence. If the regional networks cannot afford to operate they can take in some capital city networks which are closer to them. If the regional networks in Queensland find that they cannot operate successfully they can include some Brisbane stations in their broadcast format.

I wish to concentrate on remote licences, rebroadcast licences and retransmission licenses. These Bills have been introduced because licences are no longer allocated on a structural format, on a radio or television tower. Licences are allocated to cover a particular area. The satellite has forced these changes to take place.

This legislation was first introduced in 1942 to cover the radio broadcast format. As changes have taken place we have seen a tremendous increase in broadcast technology. Hopefully, the satellite will be launched in August. We wish it well. Some of the satellites of late have not gone so well but we hope that ours will be launched successfully. Of course one or two others will follow. I congratulate Aussat Pty Ltd for the work that it has been doing in this regard.

At this stage I would also like to congratulate the Queensland Government. It is the first group to sign up for a transponder on the Aussat network. It will be spending $1.9m. The Minister for Industry, Small Business and Technology, Mr Mike Ahern, signed a two-year lease only two days ago with Mr Gosewinckel, Chairman of Aussat. Approximately $7m in total will be spent on the network. It will be known as QNET and, of course, it will be a tremendous help for communications in Queensland. Queensland is a very big, settled State. People live from one side of it to the other and from the north to the south. The transponder will be of tremendous help to those living in isolated parts of that State. Trials will take place in October and no doubt they will help tremendously such organisations as the Department of Education, the police, all sorts of primary industries and Public Service bodies. It will help them keep in contact with one another and speed up their communications. That is what the satellite is all about.

There has been talk about the cost of the dishes, et cetera. We have switched to the B-MAC system but it is turning out to be much more expensive that we originally thought. It is obviously a better system. The technology is better and we will get a clearer signal but it will be more expensive. I also address my remarks to the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and the communications committee. I will put a submission to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who will probably look at this matter at the tax summit. He is prepared to give $150m to the car companies of this country to keep them in business; I suggest that he knock the sales tax of 20 per cent off the dishes and knock the 33 1/3 per cent sales tax off the translators that are necessary.

I do not believe that there is any point in this Government spending $300m to $400m launching a satellite if people cannot receive the signal. Obviously in small communities a group of people-the shire council or whoever-would be able to put up a dish and rebroadcast and the cost would be much less. They could use their existing ordinary commercial television aerials. However, in more isolated areas-there are many isolated homesteads and many isolated Aboriginal communities, stock camps or whatever-where there will be one dish and one signal into one television set, it will be very difficult for these people to afford up to $2,000 to $3,000 to establish a dish. If the Government is not prepared to subsidise the cost it ought at least to be looking at taking off the sales tax on such products. Surely if there were a need for the removal of sales tax it is in this case. There is no business sense in our spending all of this money on a satellite and on all the installations involved and the ground equipment, which will probably cost nearly a billion dollars when all the work is done, if people in the outback-the people who were meant to receive this signal-cannot do so.

Aborigines are a group. I am a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. There are many Aborigines in my electorate and I hope that the Minister will allow them to get involved at the transmission level. We must not fill them with expectations. The National Aboriginal Conference has just put out directions 20 and 24. It gets a bit carried away. Fortunately the Minister will disband the NAC by the end of this month. The NAC, in directions 20 and 24, says that it wants its own television and radio stations. We have to get through to the NAC that with the advent of the satellite it will be able to get a rebroadcast licence and a retransmission licence. It will be able to use the signal coming off the satellite to have an input. The idea of that is to have a window on, and input of, their localism at that level. Perhaps they can get some original Aboriginal content. I cannot see how the Aborigines will ever be able to set up their own television stations. I think that that is a bit beyond the pale, so to speak.

Today I spoke to Mr Bill Pollock, the Manager of Telecom Australia. We have a problem with the flying doctor network, the School of the Air and isolated telephonic connections. Presently Telecom is going down the track of digital radio telephones which means that once the system is introduced it will not allow people in isolated homesteads to put in an up-down track on the satellite. Equipment is being developed to enable people to contact the flying doctor and in particular school children who reside in isolated communities to contact the School of the Air. Again, there are many Aboriginal children in isolated communities who are seeking better education. Apparently the previous Minister for Communications, Tony Staley, is heading a communications company which has put out some equipment. This matter is very important because I represent a very isolated part of Australia. People there do have needs. Telecom is going down the track of digital phones. Although it is a vast improvement on no phone at all-people will be able to get off the radio network-I think we have to have another look at the technology involved in giving people on isolated stations the opportunity to use the satellite for education and communication. No doubt the Minister will look at this problem for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general and brief terms the purpose of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and related Bills is probably four-fold. First, as has been mentioned, they implement a number of recent Government decisions regarding the revision of broadcasting legislation and relate those to services rather than technologies. Importantly, this legislation also provides for the licensing of services to outback areas using the satellites of Aussat Pty Ltd. It also provides other changes to regulations and inquiry procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I would like to concentrate my remarks in the limited time available to me on the remote commercial television services.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills create a new category of licences which, of course, will be called remote licences. The licences will enable licensees to provide commercial radio and television services to an estimated 600,000 to 650,000 people who live in outback Australia, and that will be done by means of the Aussat satellite. The satellites are due for launch later this year. The first one will go up in about two months time.

In terms of the licence provisions for the remote commercial services, there are a number of differences from the existing licence provisions. I will mention those briefly. Firstly, these licences relate to broadcasting services which will be provided by the use of that satellite and that, of course, is a new situation. Secondly, the public interest criteria which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal may apply to the granting or renewal of a licence are more widely expressed. In particular, I emphasise that there is no absolute prohibition on the concentration of ownership of those licences, although the Tribunal must consider the need to avoid an undue concentration of ownership and control in the servicing area concerned. That is subject, of course, to the other overriding objective-the fundamental objective-of ensuring that all Australians have access to both commercial radio and commercial television services.

I want to concentrate some remarks on that area because, as most honourable members would be aware, on the issue of the remote area television policy and licensing there was an article recently in the Bulletin magazine by a journalist, Mr Stackhouse, in which he pursued with some energy, but in a hardly convincing way, the case for an effective network monopoly of the remote commercial television service. It was an important article and I think it needs to be commented on because from that article one could certainly get the impression that it is only the Sydney and Melbourne television stations which are objecting to the proposed remote commercial television service. I say that because it is not as if the Government has only recently made a decision to proceed with the remote commercial television service. It is not as if the Government suddenly had a rush of blood and decided to implement legislation or Government decisions on that basis.

In that sense, one must wonder and one must ask why it is that it seems that only the networks are right, according to Mr Stackhouse, while the Federal Government, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, some 35 regional television stations and many State governments seem to be wrong. The fact is that this policy was not a result of a rush of blood. The fact is that this issue is at least four years old. The networks advanced virtually exactly the same arguments before two public inquiries and on both occasions their suggestions were rejected. The effect of the remote commercial television service policy is not to maintain the regional stations' monopoly, as suggested by the Bulletin. Its clear purpose is to provide 650,000 people who live in remote areas of Australia with the same level of television services as those which have already been enjoyed by other country people in Australia for at least the last 20 years. They have all enjoyed an Australian Broadcasting Corporation service and they have all enjoyed a commercial service.

This issue is all about ensuring that those other 650,000 people have the right to that same service. It has nothing at all to do, as claimed by Mr Stackhouse, with maintaining a regional station's monopoly. Mr Stackhouse is beating the drum for a last minute alternative scheme. Even though it has been rejected twice, he is suggesting it again at the last minute in his article. It should be clearly understood that the effect of what he is proposing would be to give his employer, as it happens, together with two other networks, effective monopoly control over the distribution of programs by satellite. His article is attempting to play on the sympathy that everyone feels for people in the outback by representing those big networks as benefactors. It has to be clearly understood that the real effect of the proposals advocated by Mr Stackhouse in the Bulletin would be to make remote Australians pay dearly in order to increase further and entrench the networks' control over the broadcasting system. It is simply not true to say that the network proposal involves remote viewers in only marginally more expense than the remote commercial television service.

The satellite system was deliberately designed -it is a feature of it-to minimise costs to viewers in the outback. It has been designed to use powerful transponders on the space craft, so producing an average domestic earth station cost of about $2,300, including sales tax and installation. The network proposal-the one advocated in the article by Mr Stackhouse-is to turn the satellite design on to its head. That proposal is about lowering the cost in space, which of course the broadcasters pay, at the expense of costs on the ground, which the viewers pay. The effect would be to produce dishes costing an average of $4,900. That is hardly an insignificant difference. In fact, it is almost twice the cost of the figure of $2,300 which I mentioned before.

If we go into further calculations we will see that the total extra costs the networks seem to be trying to pass on to outback viewers is in the order of $80m and could range as high as $277m. That is the effect of the article by Mr Stackhouse. That is the total extra cost that the networks seek to push on to outback viewers. I shall repeat those figures. It is in the order of $79m and could be as high as $277m. That is a significant cost and I am sure that honourable members of the House, such as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), who spoke earlier, and the Minister would not like it to be imposed on residents in northern Queensland. Quite apart from the fact that the proposal advocated seems to be ill-considered-it is certainly a superficial attempt to change the whole satellite system only months before the launch date-the network proposal ignores the central issue, which is how to move to equalisation of services in rural Australia without damaging the existing system and without abandoning our accepted broadcasting policy.

In conclusion, I shall make five points about the obvious difficulties with the network proposal. Firstly, the network proposals suggests that the networks and the ABC share a single satellite and direct broadcast four national beams across Australia. It has to be said to begin with that that is technically impossible because each satellite is designed to deliver only three national signals. As a result, the ABC would be pushed into a second satellite and that would mean inevitably that those same outback viewers would have to buy either two satellite dishes or an expensive dish that could be pointed at either of the two satellites. The second difficulty with the national network proposal is that if the ABC were to undo years of planning and transfer to a national beam, it would not be able to honour commitments to State governments to regionalise programs. We have only to recall the outcries when the ABC reduced regional coverage in Queensland or, for instance, some of the complaints that have recently been made about the National.

The third difficulty is that the Government, Aussat, the ABC, the Special Broadcasting Service, Telecom Australia and the industry are all committed to a series of decisions taken over a period of years which could now be reversed only at significant cost. If the networks' plan were suddenly substituted, Aussat's financial arrangements would be placed in some jeopardy, the ABC would have to re-plan its distribution system for television and radio services and Telecom would have to cancel ongoing construction of earth stations at hundreds of national transmitting sites.

The fourth difficulty is that the network proposal would give those stations, as I have said, some effective monopoly control over the satellite distribution system. I think it has to be clearly understood that the regional stations would become slave stations. The ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act would become virtually redundant. There is no doubt that there would be a major increase in the concentration of media ownership. The fifth difficulty with the network proposal is that the concept of a cheap and affordable dish for domestic use in the outback-that is a crucial element in widespread public acceptance of the satellite system-would simply disappear. There would be no cheap and affordable dish.

In short, the network proposal that was vigorously espoused by Mr Stackhouse would seem to be very attractive to the networks but to very few other people. In my view it is not an option for the Government, it is not an option for the public and it is not an option for the 650,000 remote viewers of Australia. I commend the four Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments in relation to the broadcasting and television Bills. Like other speakers, I wish to refer generally to remote area television and radio services, regional television services, networking and new technology, particularly the domestic satellites which are about to be launched. I suppose the first thing I would like to do is commend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for changing his terminology to the remote commercial television and radio service. At one stage last year the terminology was different. I think this change makes much more sense because we can now clearly differentiate between 'regional' and 'remote'.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's satellite program service inquiry which I think really gave a most fundamental consideration of the questions of delivery of programs into the regional and remote areas of Australia and the concentration of programming power and media ownership in the commercial television sector. I believe that what the Tribunal said was contrary to what many people thought it would say. I think many people thought it would say that we already have a concentration in the regional areas and therefore we should allow a further movement of the three networks into those areas. My understanding of what the Tribunal said is that if one is really looking at the question of power in the commercial television sector of Australia, one has to look at the question of programming power-the ability to buy programs, make programs and so on. At this stage there are really only three groups in Australia that have that ability. There is a need for alternative sources of power to be able to compete.

If we are talking about choice in commercial television in Australia, we should really be looking at the licensing arrangements for the major metropolitan areas rather than the regional areas of Australia because that, in effect, is where the lack of choice is at present compared with the situation in other countries. The Tribunal talked about going back to square one, which I think would be considered a little too difficult by any government at the present time.

The Government and the Minister have talked about equalisation of services. I question what is really meant by equalisation of services and how quickly this process should occur. I know the Minister has indicated that this would take place over a period. But what is seen as important to rural and remote area Australia and what is the position in Australia compared with that in other countries? To repeat what a number of people have said, when one talks to country people about the delivery of communications one is told that the single most important thing to them is a telephone. I will go right through the priorities. Next to that is a telephone that works; the most important thing of all is a telephone that works all the time. A telephone is easily the most important priority because it is the fundamental modern technical means of communication.

At present regional Australia basically has one commercial television service and one Australian Broadcasting Corporation television service. I believe that the majority of people in regional Australia have a greater program choice at present than is the case in the regional parts of the United Kingdom and certainly the regional parts of the United States of America outside the limits of metropolitan areas. The position is the opposite if one looks at metropolitan Australia, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, and compares the program choice with that offered in similar sized cities in the United States. There is less choice of program in our major cities than there is in equivalent cities in the United States. I think the answer is quite obvious in terms of the ability of people to look at a range of programs in regional Australia and metropolitan Australia. I represent a regional area and I have looked at the situation in some other countries. There is relatively less choice in metropolitan areas and relatively more choice in regional areas. I think the provision of an ABC and commercial television service in remote areas will be a tremendous achievement for people living in those areas; it will be a tremendous achievement for what has become basically a bipartisan policy.

Once this arrangement is established, certainly we can and should look further for greater program choice in regional Australia, metropolitan Australia and remote area Australia. We should look at all three areas. One suggestion that is around at the present time is to allow groups of regional stations to band together. I believe that that is a sensible suggestion because it would provide the opportunity for alternative programming power. It could mean that some sort of fourth power could create and buy programs in this country.

One can say that we should accelerate what is happening by using technology as much as possible. But we have to do this in a way that is understandable and acceptable. We also have to take into account the technology that is available. This brings me to the supplementary licence system which I believe is an important step in providing greater program choice for people in regional areas. My only word to the Minister in this respect is that his efforts should be accelerated so that people in regional areas can receive a second program choice as soon as possible.

I join with the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and others who talked about the problems that would be experienced in remote areas if one signal came in on a national beam and another signal came in on a zonal beam. I am concerned about the problems that that would create for people in remote areas who are already being subjected to considerable cost in terms of receiving television services. There are also other problems such as time zones.

We also have a problem in respect of localism. Even State localism would mean that people in remote areas would receive programs with inputs from Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth or wherever. I believe it is of fundamental importance that people in remote areas should be able to get State localism and, hopefully, more regional localism through the zonal system. Certainly that matter is important and such a system should be adopted as opposed to, if one likes, a national system with all the problems, such as time zones, that it creates. In addition, a national system does not take into account the question of regionalism.

At this point I want to make a suggestion to the Minister which I think probably has been made by other speakers in this debate. We have been advised that the ABC will have access to the first satellite and that the remote commercial service will be able to use the third satellite. We will then have a situation in which different satellites will be in slightly different positions. This will create problems in that there will need to be a technical ability for people to switch either to a commercial or to the ABC service. We need to ensure that people in remote areas do not have a problem with respect to the type, size or number of reception dishes that will be needed.

Whatever decisions are made at this stage, we will have problems because we are in a transitional period with new technology. The second generation of satellites which will come along will obviously mean that the whole question of programming and networking will be subject to further change. Certainly it is quite possible that eventually there will be some sort of network system right throughout the country. That is something that will have to be addressed when the second generation of satellites are used. There are certainly questions about the viability of some of these remote services.

I believe that the regionals have accepted a responsibility to cover and carry as much as possible the losses that will occur. They accept that they now have a responsibility to remote areas as well as regional areas. Although this might be a self-protection situation, this is now being done. There will be problems whatever decision is made on this issue. It is a question of transition as we move into the first generation of satellites and, from there, to the second generation. I would like to say personally, having some interest in this matter, that I give my general support to the direction which the Minister is taking on this very important matter concerning television programs for the regional and remote areas of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-There are a few things that I would like to say before dealing with some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Firstly, the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill is an extremely complex piece of legislation. I express my appreciation to the officers of the Department of Communications for the assistance they have given in the drafting of the legislation. The Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, which under all governments finds itself in the last part of a parliamentary session under enormous pressure, deserves also to be congratulated for the amount of work it has done on this Bill. I also thank on the Government side the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) for their contributions. The honourable member for Isaacs has always taken a very active interest in this area. The honourable member for Bendigo represents a provincial area in Victoria and his concerns regarding these matters are well known.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing in detail with the matters raised by the honourable members for Ryan, Murray and Maranoa, I indicate that it is interesting and probably all too unusual in this place that we have reached a bipartisan position on this issue. When the remote commercial television service licence scheme was announced in this House last year it was given the support of the then shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Murray. Although some real problems have justifiably been raised by the honourable member for Ryan, and I will deal with them in a moment, if that bipartisan approach which has been continued here today occurred in relation to more issues, the Parliament would operate a lot better and things would be a lot better for Australia as a whole. I thank honourable members for their assistance in that regard.

It is necessary to address the specific items raised by the honourable member for Ryan. I think it is reasonable to say that they are matters which have been raised with the honourable member by the industry and they are, of course, known to me because of that. The first item to which he referred was clause 12 of the Bill. The industry organisation has complained that this clause does not give the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal a discretion to dispense with an inquiry-it should be emphasised that we are talking about a public inquiry-when exercising any of its substantive powers. It is claimed that this means that an inquiry must be held whenever a submission is lodged, resulting in an unending and totally unmanageable series of inquiries, many of which are likely to be on frivolous grounds. If that were the position, the matters raised by the industry and put forward today by the honourable member for Ryan would cause considerable concern; but I do not think that the criticisms are justified.

I refer honourable members to sub-section 19 (1) of the principal Act, which is not amended by this Bill. That requires inquiry proceedings before the Tribunal to be held in public. Proposed new sub-section 17C (1) in clause 12 provides that the Tribunal must hold an inquiry into the exercise of substantive powers. Proposed new sub-section 17C (5) provides that regulations may prescribe inquiry proceedings in respect of sub-section 17C (1) inquiries. The effect of these provisions is that regulations may provide for circumstances in which the Tribunal may dispense with public hearings in the exercise of its substantive power. It has the power to dispense with them, and that is what we are talking about. We are not trying to further complicate the proceedings but to cut them down. In accordance with Administrative Review Council recommendation 14, which was accepted by the Government, it is proposed that the regulations empower the Tribunal to dispense with public hearings where no matters of substantial controversy or concern are raised by an applicant. I think that will meet the industry's concern.

I think the point made by the honourable member for Ryan in relation to clause 19 was that the requirement in section 22 of the principal Act, for the ABT to ensure as far as practicable that no party suffers detriment by being unrepresented at an inquiry, is unique in Australian legislation. The Department of Communications and I have looked at this matter and we have taken the view that the provision is a direct reflection of ARC recommendation 20B. It is not something that was dreamt up by us but is a recommendation of the ARC. The honourable member for Ryan adverted to substantial matters in respect of clause 23 of the Bill. The purpose of that clause is to implement the ARC recommendation in this area and to clarify the Tribunal's existing obligation to investigate thoroughly all matters relevant to an inquiry. The Tribunal's power is to investigate and comment, not to take action, and it must relate, of course, to broadcasting practices. The word 'practice' is defined by the Concise Oxford Dictionary as 'an habitual action or carrying on or a repeated exercise'. Therefore, the Tribunal can inquire only into a course of conduct over an appreciable period and not into specific isolated incidents, and it can consider only matters relevant to an inquiry. The criteria for the renewal of licences are particularised in sections 86 and 86A of the Act. Only if those criteria were breached, either by a specific instance or by a course of conduct, could the Tribunal legally exercise any of its substantive powers.

The question of proposed future conduct was also raised by the honourable member for Ryan. Example program acquisition proposals could be relevant to the capacity effectively to provide a licence service. I think the real issue here is that the Tribunal is not in a position in an area inquiry to exercise substantive powers. I take the honourable member's point that further discussions have to be held with the industry. If it is not satisfied in relation to these matters, provided that its lack of satisfaction is reasonable, we will do what we can to meet those problems. The other clause which caused some concern to the honourable member for Ryan was clause 42. In that regard, I think what is described as the wide approach is defensible and should be proceeded with because it also gives a considerable amount of necessary flexibility. There is no evidence of any problems having been experienced with that approach to date. It is proposed to advise the industry that the wide approach is to be adopted because it is more flexible, but, quite clearly, on the basis of the matters raised here today, that provision may have to be looked at in the future as specific problems arise.

Clause 65 was another clause referred to by the honourable member for Ryan. The complaint put forward by the industry was that the provision relating to local origination does not reflect the second reading speech. The industry is concerned that the licensee's failure to use local origination could count against the licensee in the ABT's assessment of what is adequate and comprehensive. That complaint did not come only from the television industry; it was also a criticism from the radio industry. I am not convinced about that matter. In fact, my view is totally to the contrary. In my view the Bill does reflect the speech, as permission can be granted only upon application. The Bill does have the effect that the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations advocates. The further safety factor is that clause is the requirement for separate proclamation only after detailed provisions and procedures have been determined in respect of each category of licence. This, in my view, ensures clearly that the intention embodied in the second reading speech is picked up before proclamation.

The other area related to clause 92 of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, since concern was expressed about having adequate access to Government policy statements. I will ensure that the industry will be provided with policy statements as a matter of course, and that further procedural requirements to make these statements available will be included in the regulations. I think that meets the point of concern.

The honourable member for Maranoa raised the question of telephones and mentioned the satellite. I repeat something I have gone through over and over again. I think that the digital radio concentration system is the best way to go with remote telephones. However, there will be some cases in which the satellite will be used. Those who talk of the cost of the satellite in respect of telephony often do not address the question of the cost of the infrastructure that is necessary on the ground as opposed to what is already up in the satellite. Many submissions have been put forward on this point that the Iterra system would be a better system to be used in remote areas. It is not something with which too many people agree. I should be happy to discuss the matter with the honourable member some time in the future when things here have settled down a little, but at this stage I am not convinced that is the way we should go with remote telephony. In some specific areas such as a mining community, a mining company that wants such a system may be able to afford it, but in view of the expense to the average person in the remote areas represented by some honourable members I do not think that is the answer. The honourable member for Maranoa can continue discussion, as he said, with Telecom on that matter, but Telecom's arguments to me on the issue were overwhelmingly convincing.

The honourable member for Murray talked of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation being on the first satellite and he asked who would be on the second satellite. At this stage it is likely that the Western Australian remote licence will be on the second satellite, because it is in a particular position due to the time zone problem and the matters raised by the honourable member for Isaacs. The honourable member for Murray made the significant point that it is necessary to have one dish in order that the ABC and the remote services can be available on the one dish. That will be done because the switching referred to by the honourable member to make that effective will be carried out. That advice has been given by Aussat Pty Ltd recently. The problems raised by the member for Murray are well known on that matter and it will be handled in that way.

I want now to move to matters relating to the Government's amendments which have been circulated and which will be moved in the Committee stage. I shall now briefly foreshadow those amendments. The main aspect is the insertion of the date 1 January 1986 as the date for the commencement of the main provisions. It did not satisfy the remote licence applicants that there should not be a fixed date. That was a reasonable point and I thought it should be adopted. Another amendment seeks to include the words 'Corporation or the Service'-that is the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service, which will be included in the provision to take into account the question of adequate and comprehensive services within a specific area. That relates to the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and most of the other amendments relate to the same matters.

In relation to the Broadcasting and Television (Consequential Amendments) Bill, there is again insertion of the date 1 January 1986. The same applies to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill. Those amendments will be moved as soon as we move into the Committee stage. In closing, I thank the honourable members for their contribution to the debate today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the honourable gentleman to the drift and indecision evident regarding the Government's wages policy. I remind him that three months ago, on 25 February, he told the House that 'the Government is yet to finalise its position' in relation to discounting of potential wage increases from the effects of depreciation. Will the Prime Minister put an end to the drift, indecision and conflicting ministerial statements which have characterised Government comments on this issue since his original and highly equivocal response by stating once and for all the Government's position on the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for his question. I note in preface that it is more than passing strange that the Opposition in general and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in particular should be referring to any indecision in regard to wages policy because if we want to look for indecision and total chaos in the area of wages policy we should just look at the Opposition. I make the point generally that it is only within a centralised wage system, which has now been so firmly endorsed unanimously by the members of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, that we have any capacity for an effective wages policy. The prescription of those opposite would be a prescription for unbounded inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: Having pointed out the hypocrisy of the Opposition, I say simply this: The Treasurer and myself and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations have made it clear that the Government will make the decision which is appropriate at the time when it needs to be taken to protect for Australia the undoubted benefit which will accrue to this country from the devaluation which has taken place. It is a repudiation of sensible decision making to come to some position in advance of what you know the position will be. I make it clear that this debate originated when in fact the dollar had gone down to about US62c. It is now back to the order of US70c. It makes sense to say: 'All right, when you come up to the point where you have to make a decision, you will make the decision then as to what is necessary to protect the interests of this country'. That has been the position of the Treasurer, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and myself. The community can be assured that, under the wages policy which has successfully produced for this country a recovery from the economic disaster into which the policies of those opposite plunged it, we will continue to make the decisions which will continue the recovery, continue employment growth, and continue it within containable levels of inflation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a delegation from the Bundestag of the Federal Republic of Germany led by Mr Richard Stuecklen, Vice-President of the Bundestag.
