INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Is it a fact that Adelaide is the only State capital city without a recognised Commonwealth Government centre? Can the Minister say what progress has been made by the Government towards developing a Commonwealth centre in Adelaide? Can he assure the House that any proposed development will make a positive contribution to the Adelaide city environment?

—Yes, it is a fact that Adelaide is the only capital city that has not a Commonwealth centre. I am pleased to say that the Government has decided to proceed with a new Commonwealth centre in Adelaide at an estimated cost of $38m, which includes $4m for internal fittings. The building will be of environmentally sympathetic architectural design with twin towers. It will be about 27,000 square metres and will house about 1,400 public servants. Tenders will be called on 8 June 1985. Tenders will be assessed between July 1985 and August 1985. The contract will be let in September 1985. The estimated completion date is December 1987. The construction of this building will stimulate the construction industry in Adelaide in South Australia. It will be a co-operative effort between the Australian Government, the State Government and the Adelaide City Council. That is part of our overall pattern of discussion with both State and local government, and I believe that the building will add to the business centre of Adelaide.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the Government's drift and indecision regarding amendments to the assets test, a test which on the evidence has caused the Government to fall into contempt with Australians.
—I would not talk about your support today, if I were you! If you want to have a discussion on that, you can, any time you like.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting. The Leader of the Opposition will get to his question.
—He has fallen even below the value of the dollar. I suggest that those opposite float the Prime Minister. They had better make sure it is not a dirty float, though.
—I thought you didn't believe in polls.

—Never make comments on polls; I am talking about support. I ask the Minister: Is it the case that, following the Prime Minister's commitment to amend the assets test, the Minister took the matter to Cabinet on 14 May and, in line with the normal drift and indecision with this Government, the Cabinet was yet again unable to make a decision? When will the Minister be announcing the changes to the test?

—It is interesting that once again the Opposition returns to the assets test. In this case it is talking about urgency in relation to amendment. A lot of the criticism has come from the National Party. It is of some interest to recall that, when the right honourable member for New England, for example, was the Minister for Social Security, the assets test that operated under a coalition government was much more draconian and much tougher in every respect than the means test that currently operates. There was no situation then in which people had open to them the review and appeal procedures that operate at present. The Government has always said that the assets test would need to be carefully monitored, particularly during the implementation stages. It is true that over the last several weeks I have brought to the Government several reports which are the results of the information that has been collected in relation to the implementation phase. The Government has analysed that information. There are some outstanding matters. When we have resolved those outstanding matters, of course, an announcement will be made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. The Minister will be aware of yesterday's decision by the High Court of Australia affecting children's television programs. What consequences will this decision have on the local film and television program industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canberra for her question. I understand that yesterday the High Court upheld an appeal by Herald-Sun TV Pty Ltd against the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's standards for pre-school children's programs and advertising. Essentially this means that the power to require pre-classification of such programs can no longer be supported under the present legislation. This has considerable importance in terms of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's administration of standards and accordingly could have a marked effect on local film and television program production in Australia. When I delivered the second reading speech on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill last week, I indicated that it had been the Government's intention to bring forward amendments at this time to clarify and, in fact, affirm the Tribunal's standards. I also said that because of possible effects of such legislation expressed by sections of the broadcasting industry it was decided to exclude the provisions from the Bill at that time to allow further consultation with the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I made it clear at that time, and I wish to emphasise it today, that the Government's view is that the standards powers must be supported. The Government will move to legislate at the earliest possible time to give effect to the policy that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal maintain its powers to set and enforce both qualitative and quantitative standards in relation to broadcasting in this area, and that would be in the area of standards and/or conditions. Also at that time I gave notice that because of the Government's commitment to a viable Australian film and television industry, this Government would take all necessary steps to maintain the viability of the industry and, if necessary, would make the legislation effective from the date of the second reading speech; that is, 15 May 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to the Government's hopeless drift and indecision over Aboriginal land rights. Will he end the uncertainty which is damaging to all Australians and advise the House what he intends to do about Aboriginal land rights? Will the Government be introducing legislation?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. The answer is that the Government is seeking the views of Aboriginal people and all the relevant organisations on the question of what ought to go into a land rights package. I remind the honourable gentleman, who talked about drift and indecision, that one of the responsible-I thought it was responsible-bodies that we have approached for its views is Her Majesty's Opposition. Some months ago I gave the honourable gentleman a copy of the preferred model and sought his comments. I offered the resources of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. What we have is an announced position without any attempt to get an adequate briefing. On half a dozen occasions in the House I have invited the honourable gentleman to tell us what the Opposition's position is on land rights. He has the gall to talk about drift and indecision. This Opposition has had more positions on land rights than a drunken sailor working his way through the Kama Sutra. When the honourable gentleman is able to inform the House whether the Opposition supports the principle of land rights, a principle espoused by a former Liberal government, and is not prepared to pander to some of the worst racist elements in this community, he is entitled to an answer from me.

—My question is to the Minister for Housing and Construction. As the Australian Bureau of Statistics has released today final figures on building commencements for Australia for the December 1984 quarter, can the Minister inform the House whether these figures indicate that the target for housing commencements for this year will be met? What are the future prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The targets will be met. Eighteen months ago my predecessor, the then Minister, predicted that there would be 145,000 housing starts this financial year. The latest indicators show that there will be approximately 150,000 starts. Indeed, the final figures for the December quarter to be released today by the Bureau of Statistics indicate that the number of dwelling commencements for the December quarter last year was 39,000. That is the highest quarterly figure since March 1974. I might also say that the figures are particularly strong in the private sector, with private units and townhouses commencements up 44 1/2 per cent in the December quarter on the December quarter of the previous year. Of course, this has had an effect on employment. In the total housing and construction employment area, there has been an increase of 83,000 jobs since August 1983. That means that unemployment in the industry has been reduced from 14 per cent, which was the figure when we took over, to 7.3 per cent currently, which is now less than the national average instead of significantly more than the national average.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the honourable member's question concerned the prospects for the future. I want to look to the two key indicators-approvals by local government authorities and the number of loans by all significant lenders. Both of those indicators show continued stability in the industry, perhaps at a slightly reduced level going into 1985-86. As far as lending is concerned, the picture has been very good because the numbers of loans by all significant lenders has gone up by 15 per cent on the previous year. As far as savings banks are concerned, the number of loans is up 13.7 per cent in the three months to February 1985 over the corresponding period a year earlier. I should say that the picture for the future will depend upon such indicators as the level of interest rates, the level of funding for the States in the area of public housing and the continued availability of finance from the banks. I might say that the level of growth in savings bank deposits, although it has declined somewhat over the last few months, is now back to the long term trend line of the early 1980s. That is not as bad as some people are making out in the banking industry. It does not indicate that serious thought should be given to the deregulation of housing interest rates.

Those indicators in regard to the number of loans by all significant lenders and the number of approvals by the local government authorities over the last few months show that we will get 150,000 starts this year, which is in direct contrast to the level two years ago, when we took over, an abysmal 105,000 starts. We are up 50 per cent in two years, on the record of the previous government. Because of what two key indicators show for the last few months, we are looking at stability in the industry over the next 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence a question, and I again refer to the Government's drift and indecision in policy formulation. I ask: Did the Royal Australian Navy's initial request for tender for the Oberon replacement submarine specify that the winning design would preferably be a boat in service or about to go into service with the sponsoring government's Navy in order to ensure low technical and production risks? Has this criterion been met by the German and Swedish preferred tenderers? If not, does this criterion still apply? When was it varied? What are the new criteria? On what date were all tenderers advised of the change? Can the Minister assure the House that the preferred tenderers can guarantee the low technical and production risk for Australian building that were originally specified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get on to the right honourable gentleman's question, but his wording invites me to comment on drift and indecision and whether this Government has a comparable record to his in the area of drift and indecision in defence matters. In the next 10 minutes or so I shall canvas that subject and then get on to his question. We have before us the example of the drift and indecision of the previous Government in that marvellous process it went through in its decision as to whether it would proceed with an aircraft carrier purchase. That is a memory that will live with us forever. That purchase was on one day and off the next. The previous Government got the Invincible, then handed it back again. It changed the requirement and said: 'Yes, we need a forward power projection capability'. Then it said: 'No, we need an anti-submarine warfare capability. What are we going to do?' This drift and indecision went on for about three years.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter was not dealt with until we came into office, when we did two things. Firstly, we brought the matter to the conclusion the Opposition in government had arrived at in an intellectual sense but which it did not have the guts to implement or announce publicly. Secondly, because that left an ASW gap, when we came into office we addressed immediately the question that had been drifting and handled indecisively through the present Opposition's unwillingness to come to a decision on what sort of helicopter ought to go on the back of the frigates. So we ended that drift and indecision.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still don't know.

—I know the honourable member does not read much. However, if he had looked every now and then at the newspapers he would have seen our helicopter solution for the frigates. Our decisive activity on the drift and indecision by the Opposition when in government in relation to the helicopter purchase was very thoroughly addressed by us.

ANSWER.PARA: We then had the right honourable gentleman's drift and indecision on Army training and manoeuvre facilities in the New South Wales area. For a couple of years the right honourable member and his predecessors sat on a series of briefings that bounced to and fro from the Department. Something like five million hectares were under investigation, and bits and pieces of information were leaking out now and then to the disturbance and distress of people in that area. We were obliged to come in and deal decisively with that area of drift and indecision in the previous Government's policies. When it comes to the drift and indecision stakes we come a very poor second to the crew opposite. Next time the right honourable member gets up to ask a serious question he had better work out his preamble somewhat better because his premises will be addressed as well as his general question. The right honourable member accused this Government of drift and indecision. This Government is a Government which when it makes a decision about a weapons purchase makes absolutely certain that what it is getting has the capability it requires. It undertakes a proper investigation of those capabilities, and when it arrives at a conclusion it acts decisively. This Government will do that, in contrast to the actions of the Government of the right honourable member.

I now come to the point of the right honourable member's question, most of which I have forgotten. The right honourable member was wondering, as I recollect, whether the criteria set down in the tender process had been met by the selection that was made. I think if he had read through the entirety of the tender requirements he would have seen more than simply the points he raised. He would have found, too, that if a particular requirement for a boat in the water at the point at which a decision was made could not be met there was a minimum requirement for a derivative of proven design. In the areas of derivatives of proven design he would find that certainly the companies we have selected for the tender process met the requirement.

As I recollect-I am not absolutely certain of this-the requirement was for a boat in the water by 1986. In fact, only one boat offered to us for consideration conformed with that and that was the Dutch RDM boat. I do not think the Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering Ltd boat goes into the water until about 1988. The version offered to us, as opposed to that boat, represented a substantial upgrading by several hundred tonnes. So the question as to whether paper boats or real boats were selected is largely a question of degree to the extent to which there is a requirement to go above the tonnage of a boat already in the water.

So we did not change the criteria. We based our decisions on the criteria. Where we considered there was an element of technical risk involved as to whether people could achieve what they said they could achieve, a very extensive series of judgments was made and, where relevant, an adjustment was made to the claimed costings that were associated with them. Everything in the decision was conservatively weighted to take that into account. As I said, we are a government that acts both responsibly and decisively in the area of defence policy-making. We are the first government that has operated decisively and clearly in the area of defence policy making since 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to Press reports that the Sri Lankan Government is trying to raise money in Australia for its military campaign in the Tamil areas of that country? Can the Minister give the House any information on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position is that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid has recently issued a Press statement drawing attention to the concern expressed about raising funds in Australia for what is called the National Defence Fund of Sri Lanka. I am advised that this matter arose last year when a series of letters, I think dated in August, were issued from the Sri Lankan High Commissioner soliciting contributions for a defence fund. That caused some concern and apparently investigations took place at that time. It was acknowledged that whilst that solicitation was not in breach of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations it was a practice that should not be encouraged. It was considered that the request went beyond what could be regarded as normal diplomatic custom, convention and practice.

ANSWER.PARA: Representations were made to the Sri Lankan High Commissioner in, I think, November last year. At that time the High Commissioner indicated that the appeal had concluded. I am now advised, having again been asked about the present position of the Fund, that the High Commissioner has said that whilst no further appeal has been made by him since last year some moneys are still being received into what he calls the trust account of the Fund. We hope that that practice will not be continued. We accept the advice that there has been no further appeal because it is a practice which we do not think should be encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer taken a decision to exclude petroleum fuel taxation from the White Paper on tax and the tax summit deliberations? If so, has he now rejected his previous statements that every petrol bowser in Australia is simply a branch of the Australian Taxation Office? If not, will he assure the House that petroleum fuel taxation will be reviewed at the summit, including the record 78 per cent of fuel taxation not expended on roads?

—If members of the Opposition want to waste questions with speculation on what is in the White Paper they are perfectly entitled to do so. I would have thought that back bench members should reserve their questions for things which they could apply to Ministers with some reasonable prospect of an answer.

—My question is to the Minister for Aviation and concerns the second Sydney airport. Specifically, I would like an update on where we are with the second Sydney airport development. Further, will the Minister contrast the present Government's policies with the drift and indecision of the previous Government over the question of the second Sydney airport and specifically the damaging speculation to land values in my electorate and other areas under consideration? What has the Government done in this regard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I think that he has outshone the honourable member for Lowe in this respect. I can tell the honourable member that the program for the selection of the site of the second Sydney airport is, as I have stated before, that the Government is determined to make a decision before the end of the year. On the last occasion when this matter was raised I said that the release of the draft environmental impact statement had been held up because we could not get the volumes printed in time. They are expected to be released in about the middle of June. There will be a 10-week exhibition period, a response period, and then the final statement will be prepared and a recommendation will go to Government. That will be done before the end of the Budget session.

ANSWER.PARA: I will try to relate to the honourable member, knowing his very deep concern about this issue, the history of the drift and indecision of the conservative governments. I think I would have to go back to about 1968 which would take a considerable time. My recollection is that in 1968 the then Prime Minister, John Gorton, announced that Taren Point would be the ideal site for the second-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I will keep on going; the record can stand corrected. My recollection is that the site was Taren Point and there was a great furore about that. No decision was made until we came to government. We had a shot at selecting the site. In 1975 we left everything as honourable members opposite had left things in 1972. The then Government had everything available to it, including all the sites, and it set out on a new study. It went through a series of discussions and examinations but, again, it was unable to come to a decision until finally, I think it was Minister Fife at the time, went for a stubby airstrip. Nothing really happened in respect of that and that leads on to the situation raised by the honourable member.

ANSWER.PARA: Sydney has the busiest airport in this nation. For instance, more than two and a half million people per year come through the international terminal. That terminal is inadequate; the conditions there are totally unsatisfactory. The arrival of aircraft is such that there is no way that the existing facilities can adequately handle them. On a Sunday morning, for instance, three aircraft are programmed for arrival in 10 minutes and some six in 60 minutes but, because of delays elsewhere at points of departure, we finish up with an arrangement whereby six aircraft arrive in 45 minutes. There is no way that the existing services there can handle that number of people and that number of aircraft in that time. What we are coping with is the failure of conservative governments to plan investment in the airport properly. They have preferred to go for monuments and white elephants outside Sydney rather than invest in improving that terminal.

We have directed the Department of Aviation to prepare urgently a report on ways and means by which we can make better use of the existing space that is available and ways and means by which we can try to alter the arrival of aircraft so that there can be a better spread of the usage of the facilities and also to take up with the Minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the means by which we can process people faster through the primary Customs barrier. The luggage handling facilities in the lower section of the terminal are archaic. They are problems that we cannot overcome quickly but we will try to rearrange the facilities in a better way. We will be doing what we can to try to improve that situation.

As far as the honourable member for Barton is concerned, we are determined, as I have said, to proceed with the selection of a second site. We are proceeding to make better use of the existing facilities at the existing terminals pending the development of an upgrading program of extensions to the existing operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to ask the Treasurer a question in light of frequent references this afternoon to drift and indecision. Will the Treasurer advise which preferred tax option the Government prefers? Is the Government not sure whether it prefers to have a preferred option at all, that is, a deferred, preferred option? Whilst asking this question of the Treasurer, is it a fact that the Foreign Minister's preferred option is to be somewhere else so that he cannot be blamed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that old empty head here is buoyed by the results in today's Bulletin. This is a former Minister, who, as Minister for Industrial Relations, let the Australian economy fall to pieces in front of his eyes, who spat out the dummy and resigned when wages blew out, who repaired to his office and for the next two years played darts or draughts, or cards when he was bored with the others, with his staff. He was one of the guilty people who sat and watched the Australian economy slide into its greatest recession since the Great Depression. He was incapable of ever mastering a domestic portfolio; he was incapable of any original thoughts about change in this country and he was totally incapable of dealing with any substantial structural problem, let alone the tax system.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has said that it will give this nation tax reform. It has laid down a procedure. I cannot understand the point of the Leader of the Opposition's trying by way of questions to seek from me or from the Prime Minister matters which are before the Cabinet and which will all be revealed in a week or two's time when the White Paper is published. All I say to the Leader of the Opposition, again, is that if he wants to waste his questions, I do not mind replying to him; but I do not think anyone in the business community or the nation at large has any belief that old empty head here could ever deliver anything. He is rivalling Bill Snedden as the greatest empty head ever to lead the Liberal Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. It is in respect of the new tax sharing arrangements for local government. Is the Minister aware of a statement issued by the Municipal Association of Victoria claiming that funding for local government has been cut back and that this is likely to result in the loss of up to 500 jobs in Victoria? Will the Minister assure the House that the claims are not correct and that in fact funding for local government is one of the areas where the May economic statement provides for a real increase in general purpose funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. I am aware that he has 21 local councils in his electorate. I have read the statement of the Victorian local government association and do not agree with it. I think it has overstated its case. Local government will not get the increase that was projected but it will get a substantial increase. That increase for Victoria is estimated to be $11m or 9 per cent. In other words, there will be an increase from $124m in 1984-85 to $135m next year.

ANSWER.PARA: Looking at the national scene, I point out that the situation is that local government was paid $486m this year and next year it will receive an estimated $531m-a $45m or 9 per cent increase. If one compares the role of our Government in the first two years with that of the Fraser Government in its last year concerning both tied and untied grants one will find that the funding to local government has increased by over 50 per cent and by 30 June of this year we will be paying $976 in both tied and untied grants. The fact is that local government is not alone in being given a lesser increase than the States in respect of the Commonwealth Budget because the Commonwealth itself is to be cut back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory interjects. Since the Department of Finance made a submission to the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, which was a little over two months ago, there has been controversy over how much finance local government would receive this year. I have been waiting for the star from the north to ask me a question. I have not received one question on local government in over 2 1/2 months. No matter of public importance has been raised. Given the controversy, one can imagine what we would have done if we were in opposition. We would have torn honourable members opposite to pieces. There has been not one question or matter of public importance on the subject of local government finance.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Opposition also that we inherited a $9.6 billion deficit. In present terms that is over $10 billion. It has cost this Government over $3 billion to service that deficit alone. Therefore, there are difficulties across the board. Our commitment to local government is not one of finance alone. The fact is that this Government has made a broad commitment to local government. It wants to broaden the base of local government because it has faith in the democratic processes in this country. We believe that the form of government which is closest to the people should be a more broadly based government. We have encouraged local government to broaden its base. People have to make decisions about their own lives. Certainly our Government has given local government every encouragement.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a special report from the Joint Standing Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings relating to the broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House authorises the broadcasting and re-broadcasting on Australian radio and television stations of a sound record of excerpts of its proceedings for a trial period from 20 August 1985 until the end of the 1985 Budget period of sittings, subject to the conditions determined for this purpose by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.

Mr Speaker, I understand that there has been consultation with yourself, the Joint Standing Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, the leaders of the parties, and in the party rooms, and that it has been decided unanimously that the subject of this motion ought to be given a trial. It is a step very much in the right direction and we look forward to the experiment in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in speaking to this motion, I protest initially. I received the report on this subject only about 10 minutes ago. I have been trying hard to read its recommendations. As there are 13 terms and conditions on which broadcasting is to be conditional, I suggest that the consideration of this motion be deferred for a few minutes to enable me to read those conditions. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

I also present, pursuant to sub-section 34C (6) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, letters relating to the delay in tabling the report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for giving me the opportunity to peruse the Committee's guidelines. I think other members would want to peruse some of those 13 guidelines. It is necessary that they realise that it is the audio signal of proceedings transmitted by the House monitoring system that is to be broadcast. I notice that the adjournment debate is specifically referred to in the guideline No. 1. Along with many other members, I hope that the adjournment debate will be broadcast. I think it is a very important part of the proceedings of this place. I note that there is a condition that, should either House agree to the broadcasting of the adjournment debates, authorisation for excerpting should be extended to cover those proceedings. I think it is very desirable that that take place. I hope that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings might take note of that condition, perhaps consider it prior to the Budget session and make a recommendation to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The other conditions seem to follow the general text of the recommendations of each of the party leaders who have expressed the views of the members of their parties. In that sense I would like to mention that a fortnightly return in respect of the excerpts of proceedings broadcast is to be made available to the Committee by media organisations to give some idea of the broadcast balance between the sides of the House. It is our view that in accepting this guideline obviously there needs to be some balance between both sides of the House and between chambers so that proceedings can be broadcast not just from the House that is being broadcast on that day.

With those remarks, and having had some opportunity very briefly to peruse the report, on behalf of the Opposition I support the motion and commend the practice. I trust that it will be dispassionately and effectively used in accordance with the guidelines now laid down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the House would allow me to make a brief comment. I wish to refer to only one matter raised by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair)-that is, the question of the adjournment debate. The Committee in its deliberations decided that the excerpting would be made from those times of broadcasting of the House that are normally available to air, whether or not the proceedings were on air. I think the Committee was not prepared to excerpt the adjournment debate until the House made the decision to broadcast that debate. We are looking at that matter. I think that this would reflect the view expressed by the Leader of the National Party. It is perhaps something that could be done in the next session.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-

SPEECH.PARA: INTRODUCTION

On 17 May 1983 the Government appointed a Royal Commission, conducted by Mr Justice Hope, to undertake a major review of Australia's security and intelligence agencies. Having reported to the Government on the Combe-Ivanov affair in December 1983 and the Sheraton Hotel incident in February 1984, the Royal Commission presented its final reports to the Government in December 1984. I now table certain of those reports in edited form.
Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave-agreed to:

That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the following reports of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies:
General Report
Australian Security Intelligence Organisation
Office of National Assessments and Joint Intelligence Organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commenting on the reports, I should like, on behalf of the Government, to express my sincere thanks to Mr Justice Hope for having completed with distinction a very difficult task. His Honour is of course, no stranger to the intelligence and security community having previously inquired into and reported on it in a series of major reports in 1976 and 1977. Those reports led, amongst other things, to the enactment of a new Act governing the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, a Security Appeals Tribunal, the establishment by legislation of the Office of National Assessments, the public acknowledgement of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and Defence Signals Directorate, and the creation of a Cabinet committee and supporting committee of departmental secretaries to oversight the activities of the intelligence community. I should also like to thank the New South Wales Government for releasing Mr Justice Hope from his duties as a Judge of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: THE REPORTS

On 21 December 1984 the Royal Commission presented the Government with a general report, individual reports on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-ASIO, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service-ASIS, and the Defence Signals Directorate-DSD, and a combined report on the Office of National Assessments-ONA-and the Joint Intelligence Organisation- JIO.

While the nature of the subject matter of these reports rules out, on grounds of national security, publication of some material, the Government has decided to publish as much as is possible of the reports within these constraints. It has taken account of the views about possible publication expressed by His Honour in each of the reports, and has consulted with him further in reaching a decision on publication.

As suggested by Mr Justice Hope, the Government is tabling edited versions of the general, ASIO, and ONA-JIO reports. As also recommended by His Honour, the ASIS and DSD reports are not being published, but some general comments about the legality, propriety, effectiveness and efficiency of each are to be found in the published general report and I will have something further to say about each in this statement.
I mention also that in accordance with established practice on intelligence and security matters, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has been provided with copies of unexpurgated reports.

The Government in this statement responds in broad terms to the principal recommendations raised in the published reports. It has not yet reached a final position on all of the hundreds of recommendations and suggestions made: Many raise complex issues; many are intertwined; many, if adopted, will require the introduction or amendment of legislation. Detailed examination of all of the recommendations has commenced and will continue over future months.
MAJOR FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
Evaluation of the Performance of the Agencies

Mr Justice Hope has reiterated his views, formed during his earlier review, that Australia needs intelligence of quality, timeliness and relevance, and for this purpose requires a highly professional system of intelligence and security services (General, 2.43). He has concluded that governments should continue to ensure that the intelligence community is able to fulfil its important role in helping to advise on and protect Australia's national interests (General, 2.44). This Government endorses those views.

The inquiry by Mr Justice Hope has been a most comprehensive review of Australia's security and intelligence agencies. It has also examined a number of complaints. It has exposed deficiencies in some agencies. But while noting that there will always be room for improvement, His Honour concludes that the agencies are generally performing effectively and efficiently. He finds that:

In ASIO, much work has been done, and is continuing, to restructure and revitalise the Organisation, making it a service more responsive to predetermined policies (General, 2.21). ASIO has been concerned to ensure that its operations and actions are within its charter and has been substantially successful in this (General, 2.5). Its record as to legality and propriety is good (General, 2.6). However, His Honour has pointed to a number of areas, particularly in management and administration, where improvement in performance is necessary.

ONA, although a relatively small body, has established its independence and authority by the quality of the work it produces, and is held in high regard (General, 2.34, 2.36). Its national assessments have been of high quality and it also produces valuable reports on matters of current significance (General, 2.36).

JIO is a competent and professional agency (ONA/JIO, 4.9). It fulfils an important role in providing the defence organisation and other areas of government with a range of data and assessed intelligence on international, military and defence related developments (ONA/JIO, 2.18). It handles a vast amount of intelligence, and issues assessments and reports, many of which are of a high standard. Its product is well regarded by those who receive it (General, 2.40).

ASIS has achieved success over the last decade in organising and reorganising to achieve its goals (General, 2.26). Its effectiveness and efficiency and its contribution to Australia's intelligence will continue to grow as a consequence of the closer relationship with other areas of government which it now has (General, 2.28). The Sheraton Hotel incident was not representative of the quality or professionalism exhibited by ASIS in performing its principal tasks (General, 2.28), and firm and clear steps have been taken to ensure that there will be no repetition of such an incident (General, 2.15).

Just to expand on this point, as Mr Justice Hope suggests the Government might, the report on ASIS recommends that ASIS's directive be amended to exclude ASIS from carrying out covert action in the form of either special operations or special political action, and from undertaking training for such action. Special operations can be defined roughly as unorthodox, possibly paramilitary, activity in foreign countries designed to be used in case of war or some other crisis. Special political action is clandestine action against another country designed to further the foreign policy aims of a government, also in time of war or crisis. The development in ASIS of such a covert action capability had been accorded a priority well below that given to the development of ASIS's main intelligence gathering function and had in practice consumed only a very small proportion of the organisation's manpower and resources. Development of this capability as a contingency planning measure had not proceeded very far at the time of the Sheraton incident, and-apart from such training-any action at all of this nature, either special operations or special political action, would have required prior ministerial approval.

The report also recommends that the use by ASIS of weapons be terminated and that ASIS's stocks of weapons, including explosives, be disposed of. The Government has accepted and acted upon these recommendations. ASIS will not hold weapons and will not maintain a capability for special operations or special political action.

Returning to the evaluation of agencies' performance, Mr Justice Hope finds that DSD is impressive (General, 2.30). Its activities have expanded since 1974, and its skills and technology have thus far substantially kept up with this expansion (General, 2.32). It complies with the obligations which law imposes upon it (General, 2.17).

The Government has accepted and welcomes these generally reassuring findings in relation to the agencies. The reports naturally contain recommendations aimed at further improving the performance of the agencies and at ensuring that they continue to act with legality and propriety. Other recommendations are directed to making the agencies more accountable. The Government endorses most of these and is pleased to note the ready support of the agencies for the additional measures I will now outline.
General Oversight and Accountability

Principal responsibility for oversight and accountability will, naturally, continue to rest with Ministers. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence, and the Attorney-General, each of whom has direct ministerial responsibility for one or more of the agencies, together with the Special Minister of State and the Minister for Resources and Energy, constitute the Security Committee of Cabinet. The Security Committee was established in recognition that there should be a small number of Ministers collectively tasked with developing policies for, and oversighting the performance of, the security and intelligence community. In the course of the Royal Commission the Committee, deliberately and properly, refrained from taking initiatives which would in any way have cut across His Honour's inquiry or anticipated his findings. Now, with the material contained in comprehensive reports before it and with other matters held in abeyance for the period of the Royal Commission, the Committee confronts a significant and challenging work load.

The Government has responded with a number of initiatives. It has instituted a regular program of meetings for the Security Committee which will bring to the security and intelligence community a more rigorous oversight than ever before in this country. The Government believes that the agencies must benefit from having the clear guidance and directions on government policy which will emanate from these regular programmed meetings of the Committee.

To ensure that material comes before the Committee in a regular and orderly fashion, a suitably staffed, full time secretariat will be established in my Department. To strengthen its ability to advise the Security Committee on security matters, the Secretaries Committee on Intelligence and Security-SCIS-has been expanded to include the secretaries to the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of the Special Minister of State. The Government has also affirmed the mandate of the SCIS, its individual members, and other relevant agency heads for ensuring that the Committee of Ministers is kept regularly and fully informed of all relevant matters.

Mr Justice Hope has made a number of recommendations also aimed at assisting Ministers in the discharge of these functions. I now wish to set out the Government's reaction to these recommendations. As the principal recommendation in the general report, Mr Justice Hope recommends that there be created an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security which would perform the role of independent watchdog, assisting Ministers in looking after the public interest in the proper functioning of the security and intelligence agencies.

The Government accepts the recommendation, believing the proposed Office-covering as it does most of the functions of the Security Commissioner, including in particular the audit function, proposed in the Australian Labor Party submission to Mr Justice Hope-to be a valuable addition to the existing machinery. While the details will need to be finalised in legislation, the Government agrees with the thrust of what is proposed for the Office in the general report (3.19.26) and ASIO report (16.76-102). Basically, the Office will comprise an Inspector-General of appropriate standing, appointed after consultation with the Leader of the Opposition, and a small staff. For administrative purposes, the office will be attached to my portfolio. In relation to ASIO, the Inspector-General will be able to act on his or her own initiative, or at the request of the Attorney-General, or in reponse to a complaint, and will report his or her findings to the Attorney. The Inspector-General's functions and powers will also include:

inquiring into and reporting to the Attorney-General on ASIO's compliance with the law and propriety; and, if required by the Attorney-General, on the appropriateness and effectiveness of particular internal procedures;
having full access to ASIO's files and other materials and power to require answers to questions; and
reviewing ASIO's performance in opening, maintaining and culling files.
In respect of the other agencies, the Inspector-General's function will include:
checking, as occasion requires, the legality and propriety of the activities of ASIS and DSD
investigating and reporting upon matters referred by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence in respect of ONA and JIO respectively; and
investigating the appropriateness and effectiveness of particular internal procedures of any agency if so required by the relevant Minister.

The Inspector-General will produce an annual report which will be made available to the Parliament with such editing only as would be consistent with national security, privacy and other public interest considerations, and in an unexpurgated form to the Leader of the Opposition.
Parliamentary Committee

Mr Justice Hope has also given consideration to the need for a parliamentary committee and has concluded that it is neither necessary nor appropriate that a special parliamentary committee be established to improve accountability (General, 3.28, ASIO, 17.34). He does, however, emphasise that this is ultimately a matter for Parliament to decide.

The Government has given a great deal of consideration to the question. It has weighed His Honour's comments about the adequacy of existing oversight and accountability measures-particularly when supplemented by the new office of Inspector-General. The Government accepts that these measures will be improved by the creation of the Office of Inspector-General. Nevertheless, it believes a further improvement can be obtained by directly involving the Parliament-on both sides and in both Houses-in imposing the discipline of an external scrutiny of the intelligence and security agencies quite independent of the Executive. While the Government has been conscious also of the need to carefully protect intelligence and security information, it believes that appropriate arrangements can be made to ensure that a small but informed parliamentary committee would operate effectively in the public interest. It notes, in this regard, relevant overseas experience of parliamentary scrutiny of intelligence and security agencies.

Although the Government will be consulting on the details of the committee's operation, it would propose to establish the committee by amendment to the ASIO Act, to oversight prescribed activities of ASIO relating to domestic security. The committee would not act as a grievance mechanism-that role being given to the proposed Inspector-General-and appropriate safeguards for national security classified material would, of course, have to apply.

In relation to ASIO this joint parliamentary committee would supplement, not replace, the arrangements already in place for official briefings on national intelligence and security matters, on a personal and confidential basis, to nominated members of the Opposition, an approach which Mr Justice Hope has endorsed.
Impact of Archives Act

There is one final matter affecting the general accountability of the security and intelligence agencies which requires comment. In June 1984, this Government brought into operation the Archives Act to govern public access to Commonwealth records. Mr Justice Hope, in his general report, has made recommendations relating to the impact of the Archives Act on the intelligence and security agencies. His Honour has raised a concern that the 30-year time limit which is applied to records under the Archives Act may be insufficient for many intelligence community records because release even after that lapse of time could still reveal sources, modus operandi and other security-sensitive information. His recommendation is that consideration be given to legislative amendments to remove operational records of security and intelligence agencies from the mandatory requirements of handover to Archives and public access after 30 years, leaving discretion with agency heads to hand over records when appropriate.

The intelligence community has strongly supported Mr Justice Hope's recommendations and has raised with the Government its concerns about the adequacy of, and feasibility of applying, the safeguards in the Act against compromising the large volume of sensitive documents held, many of which have been provided in confidence by overseas sources. At the same time, the community acknowledges both that its records contain documents of major historical significance, and the Government's commitment to ensuring that these records are preserved and, where possible, made available for public access.

The Government takes very seriously its duty to protect the confidentiality of intelligence, its sources and the means by which it is obtained. However, it believes that safeguards in the Archives Act have been appropriately designed and have not been shown to the deficient. The provisions of section 29 of the Archives Act were developed to have the effect of exempting the intelligence agencies from the 'mandatory transfer' provision referred to by His Honour (General); and beyond this, in the event of a request for access, the Act provides a range of exemption provisions and for conclusive ministerial certificates to protect security sensitive information. The Government will ensure, however, that the intelligence community concerns and experiences are specifically addressed in the review of the Archives Act which is scheduled for 1987.
ASIO REPORT

Turning now to the report on ASIO, I primarily wish to address four main groups of recommendations: Those directed at strengthening ministerial control; those relating to amendment of the ASIO Act to redefine ASIO's jurisdiction; those affecting the role of the Security Appeals Tribunal; and those proposing the gathering-together of a range of protective security measures under the Special Minister of State.
Strengthening of Ministerial Control

Mr Justice Hope has recommended that the Attorney-General's control over ASIO be significantly expanded and his Department be given a larger role in support of him. He has proposed that the Director-General of Security, in the performance of his functions, be subject to the direction of the Attorney-General, except as to the nature of the advice he should give (ASIO, 16.46). The proposal includes appropriate control mechanisms. The Government endorses his recommendations.

His Honour has also recommended that the Attorney-General be given power to issue guidelines relating to a number of areas of ASIO activity. The guidelines will have the status of administrative directions; where appropriate, will be tabled in Parliament; and will be given to the Leader of the Opposition. The areas to be covered will include intelligence collection, targeting, review of file holdings, and the extent of ASIO involvement in investigating activities which might involve the hindering of the Defence Force function (ASIO, 16.52). The Government endorses these recommendations, and has also decided that the Security Committee will approve the guidelines to be issued by the Attorney-General.
Amendments to ASIO Act

His Honour has recommended significant changes to the definition of 'security' contained in the ASIO Act. The effect of the changes proposed is to allow ASIO's functions and activities to be more carefully defined and limited (ASIO, Chapters 3, 4, 5).

The Government accepts the main thrust of these recommendations. I do not intend repeating all of the details-I invite honourable members to give them careful study in the lead up to the future introduction of amendments to the ASIO Act. I will comment that the Government is particularly pleased that the general direction of the changes would:
give full recognition to the policy that ASIO should not be concerned with the activities of persons which involve only lawful protest or dissent (ASIO, 4.91 (h));

see the term 'subversion' deleted from the definition of 'security' (ASIO, 5.54 (b)) in favour of a concept of 'politically motivated violence' which covers a much narrower definition of the contentious notion of 'subversion';
make separate provision dealing with activities directed to promoting violence between different communal groups (ASIO, 4.91 (f)); and

delete the term 'active measures of foreign intervention' from the definition of 'security' and substitute a more tightly defined definition of 'acts of foreign interference' along the lines suggested by His Honour. Concern has been expressed in some quarters about the ambiguities and potential dangers inherent in the term 'agent of influence'. By changing the emphasis in the concept of 'foreign interference' from activities designed to advance the interests of a foreign country to activities that will have a result detrimental for Australia, this recommendation should allay those concerns.

The Government also accepts Mr Justice Hope's recommendation that there should be separate provision dealing with activities directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering with the performance by the Defence Force of its activities (ASIO, 4.91 (d)). The Government proposes to add to this provision as proposed by Mr Justice Hope a further requirement that the acts concerned be not only intended to, but likely to, obstruct, hinder or interfere. I reiterate that these provisions will be subject to the policy on lawful dissent.

Another significant amendment of the ASIO Act would result from Mr Justice Hope's proposal that ASIO, under warrant, collect foreign intelligence in Australia-that is, information concerning the capabilities, policies and activities of foreign powers or bodies (ASIO, 6.82, 6.84, 6.87). His Honour concludes, and the Government agrees, that it would be highly advantageous for Australia to provide for the collection of such intelligence (ASIO, 6.80).

The Government also agrees that if this is to be done it must be regulated by legislation, as is the case in the United States and Canada and as is being introduced in the United Kingdom, and any such legislation would need to ensure, as His Honour recognises, that no Australian person or corporation would be the target of operations involving such collection (ASIO, 6.84). We will be giving further consideration to the complex issues raised by this recommendation.
Security Appeals Tribunal

Mr Justice Hope recommends a number of procedural and jurisdictional changes for the Security Appeals Tribunal. These stem from the requirement to report on whether there is adequate provision for effective redress for persons who may be unjustifiably disadvantaged by actions of the agencies. With an exception which I will now address, these recommendations will be the subject of a further submission by the Attorney-General. As already mentioned, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will be empowered, as part of improved redress procedures, to investigate complaints by individuals.

Beyond this, Mr Justice Hope has recommended that in any case where a report by ASIO may result in action adverse to the interests of an individual and where the individual does not already have a right to review of that report, the Attorney-General may refer the matter to the Security Appeals Tribunal for advice on the appropriate procedures to be followed by the Government having regard to the interests of the person who is exposed to possible prejudice (ASIO, 17.58). It is suggested that the Tribunal could be asked to consider whether the person should be given notice and an opportunity of testing the ASIO information on which the Government is proposing to act or has taken interim action (ASIO, 17.58).

The Government accepts the desirability of being able to draw on independent advice in the circumstances outlined. However, it is concerned that the recommendation may place the SAT, a quasi-judicial body, in the position of giving advice to government on aspects of the handling of a developing security matter. The Government intends, therefore, to incorporate this advisory role in the functions of the proposed Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.
Protective Security

Chapters 9 to 12 of the ASIO report deal with protective security matters. Key recommendations set out at chapter 12, paragraphs 77 to 79, are that the Special Minister of State be given responsibility for protective security policy and co-ordination, and that a high level committee be convened by the Department of the Special Minister of State to co-ordinate protective security measures, with representation from ASIO and other agencies with specialist security expertise, and from the major user departments.

The Government recognises that under existing arrangements responsibility for protective security policy is vested in a number of departments and agencies. There is, therefore, some attraction to the idea of bringing protective security policy under one department and developing the machinery for co-ordination. Such a rationalisation inevitably carries with it resource and cost implications. Accordingly, the Government is carefully examining whether the benefits of centralisation outweigh these costs.
ONA-JIO REPORT
ONA

After making his favourable findings about ONA, to which I referred earlier and which the Government endorses, Mr Justice Hope went on to suggest that there was scope for ONA more actively to encourage departments to recognise and use its analytical skills and to co-operate with it in its work (ONA/JIO, 3.163). To this end he suggested the establishment of a National Intelligence Committee (Gen., 2.38, ONA/JIO, 3.169-170, 5.47) chaired by ONA and including senior representatives of policy departments and JIO, with representatives of the intelligence collection agencies present as observers. The Government agrees with His Honour and accordingly accepts the recommendations at paragraphs 3. 169 (a) and (b) of the report on ONA and JIO. Appropriate administrative action is being taken to give effect to that decision.
Mr Justice Hope suggests four functions for the NIC, involving it in:
the development of ONA's work program;
monitoring ONA's product;
advising ONA on intelligence needs and priorities; and
considering all ONA's assessments.

The Government agrees with the first three suggested functions for the NIC. Policy departments are already drawn into these things in a variety of ways, but it would be a useful improvement to have them done more formally, and in a multilateral way, in an NIC. The Government does not accept that the NIC should be given the fourth recommended function-that of considering all ONA's assessments. In the Government's view this would result in a most unwieldy system, would greatly reduce ONA's output, would make very difficult the preservation of ONA's independence and could quite easily lead to the introduction of departmental policy preference into ONA's assessments.
JIO

As with his recommendations on ONA, Mr Justice Hope's main recommendations in respect of JIO are directed towards improving the process of consultation between JIO and its main customers. He also makes suggestions for improving JIO's organisation, manning, training and some aspects of its co-ordination and forward planning. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) will be advising the Government on what action to take in response to the detailed recommendations and suggestions on the JIO.
DSD Report

As I have said, the DSD report is not being published but it is appropriate at this stage to make some comment about the DSD charter. Following consideration of the reports of the earlier Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence, the then Prime Minister in 1977 broadly outlined the role and functions of DSD.

Mr Justice Hope has now recommended that the Government consider making public the DSD directive, with amendments where necessary for security reasons. This Government has issued DSD with a new directive which differs only slightly, and not in matters of substance, from the previous directive under which DSD operated. We agree with Mr Justice Hope that publication of the directive will allow the Australian public to obtain a clearer appreciation of DSD's role and functions and may allay misconceptions about the organisation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the new DSD directive.
