The document read as follows-
DEFENCE SIGNALS DIRECTORATEDIRECTIVE

1. The Commonwealth Government requires the maintenance of a capability to collect, produce and disseminate foreign signal intelligence and to advise the Government on all matters pertaining to the security of signal communications and related equipments.
2. The capability will be located in:
(a) the organisation in the Department of Defence known as the 'Defence Signals Directorate' (DSD); and
(b) specialist units of the Defence Force.
Functions
3. In respect of signal intelligence, the functions of DSD and the specialist units of the Defence Force referred to in paragraph 2 above shall be:
(a) to develop and maintain a capability to provide signal intelligence in support of the Defence Force; and
(b) to collect, produce and disseminate foreign signal intelligence to meet the national requirements of the Commonwealth Government.
4. In respect of communications security, the functions of DSD shall be:

(a) to provide materials, advice and assistance to Commonwealth Government departments and authorities and the Defence Force on matters relevant to the security of their communications and electronic and related activities; and
(b) through the Secretary to the Department of Defence, to keep the Secretaries' Committee on Intelligence and Security generally informed on the state of communications security.
Organisational Principles

5. Policy control and managerial oversight over the national intelligence community, external and internal, is exercised by the Security Committee of Cabinet in respect of targets, priorities, activities, organisational requirements, broad allocation of resources, performance and co-ordination and inter-relationships of the various agencies. In the performance of its functions DSD, as a component of the national intelligence community, shall accept the guidance on targets and priorities issued from time to time by the Security Committee of Cabinet.

6. The Australian capability in signal intelligence shall be maintained in DSD and the Defence Force for national purposes generally. DSD shall be the national communications security advisory authority and as such shall maintain the expertise required to carry out those functions detailed in paragraph 4 above.
7. DSD shall be an outrider organisation in the Department of Defence. The Director, DSD shall control DSD and shall be responsible to the Secretary to the Department of Defence.

8. Specialist units of the Defence Force, and Defence Force personnel engaged in signal intelligence and communications security tasks, shall be subject to the command arrangements made by or under the authority of the Chief of the Defence Force. Members of the Defence Force may be loaned or seconded for service with DSD.
Operating Guidelines
9. DSD and units of the Defence Force engaged in signal intelligence and communications security functions shall operate in conformity with Australian law.
10. DSD shall maintain direct contact with appropriate Commonwealth Government departments and authorities and the Defence Force as regards signal intelligence and communications security matters.

11. DSD shall be the Australian national authority on signal intelligence and communications security matters. DSD shall conduct liaison on signal intelligence and communications security matters on behalf of the Australian Government as appropriate with counterpart agencies or authorities in other countries and shall maintain overseas technical representation as is necessary.

12. The Director, DSD shall furnish to the Secretary to the Department of Defence and to the Chief of the Defence Force an Annual Report which shall include an account of the performance of DSD in relation to the functions stated in paragraphs 3 and 4 above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come to my concluding remarks. As I have indicated in this statement, the Government has accepted and welcomed His Honour's findings and, as is quite clear, has accepted most of his principal recommendations. More work remains to be done in responding to his other recommendations and in the area of implementation. The Government will ensure that there is no delay to this work and that its results will be made known as appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: When all is finished, I have no doubt that Australia's intelligence and security services will be more efficient and effective than they now are, that they will be run with even greater regard for legality and propriety and that their accountability and oversight will be further strengthened. These will be worthwhile gains to the Australian people, to the Australian government and to the Australian security and intelligence community itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Whilst following convention, I would like to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for providing me with access to the various volumes, both public and private, of Mr Justice Hope's Royal Commission into Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. I will, of course, be commenting on only those aspects of the reports made public.

SPEECH.PARA: In any healthy democracy, a fine balance has to be struck between the requirements of national security on the one hand and those of personal liberty on the other. Australia has been fortunate to have had Mr Justice Hope preside over the second Royal Commission into Australia's Security and Intelligence Services. He has always brought to his task a perceptive realism about the issues at stake and maintained a standard of excellence in the performance of Royal Commissions. What is unusual is that he brings a continuity to this process of review which is highly beneficial, for Mr Justice Hope was the Royal Commissioner into Australian intelligence and security, established in 1974. On that occasion he investigated the activities of Australia's intelligence agencies in considerable depth.

The present Commission, established in May 1983, has enabled him to look into those same security and intelligence agencies and examine progress and developments since his last report. He has also been able to examine the workings of the Office of National Assessments which grew out of his last report.

It is regrettable that in Australia the security forces have not received a good Press. Recent events such as the Combe-Ivanov affair, the Sheraton Hotel fiasco, and reports about wire tapping have left the public with an impression which does not do justice to our security organisations. As Mr Justice Hope has pointed out in his report, morale, particularly in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, has suffered as a consequence of adverse publicity.

The Royal Commissioner has done us a great service in spelling out in clear terms the current strengths and weaknesses of Australia's security organisations. From reading all the reports there is one underlying thread which runs through them, that is, these organisations are dedicated both to preserving Australia's security and to preserving its way of life and fundamental freedoms. Mr Justice Hope's previous Royal Commission was critical of some aspects of the past performance of ASIO and made recommendations seeking to update ASIO's function to help it respond to the realities of the 1970s.

The coalition is pleased to note that ASIO has responded well to this challenge. Importantly, the royal commissioner has found that one of the greatest changes was in ASIO's degree of concern for compliance with the requirements of the law and propriety. The royal commissioner points out that this change has come about through increased legislative and government direction. We will be giving close examination to the proposed amendments to the ASIO Act to ensure that the changes to various definitions and the increase in ministerial control do not move us too far in the other direction and hinder the effective operation of ASIO.

Mr Justice Hope also made a number of recommendations on the collection and handling of intelligence. These appear generally sensible. It is ironical to now see Mr Justice Hope's statement that ASIO's concern with propriety may have resulted in undue caution.

The most contentious aspect is the question of external accountability. The Prime Minister, in his statement today, has confirmed his Party's paranoia over the role of security services in this country and its inability to face the reality of the world we live in-where security services are vital.

The coalition's position is clear. We support the Royal Commissioner's recommendations that ASIO lift its public image, and that the ASIO Act be amended to require the ASIO annual report to be drafted in such a way as to allow the Attorney-General to table an edited version in Parliament. The coalition sees some merit in the appointment of an Inspector-General and an Office of Inspector-General to be established by legislation. And it takes on board the royal commissioner's comments that such an office should be empowered to inquire into ASIO's compliance with the law, the propriety of its actions in general terms, and its appropriateness and the effectiveness of its general procedures.

Finally, the coalition supports the proposed changes to the Security Appeals Tribunal-but that is where it stops. We categorically reject any notion that there should be a parliamentary committee to scrutinise ASIO's activities. Such an idea is a thoroughly bad one and we oppose it. Like the Royal Commissioner, who spends a considerable amount of time demolishing the idea, we believe it is neither 'necessary' nor 'appropriate'. It is a bad idea because we are now likely to have in any case a full-time Inspector-General. We will continue to have the Security Appeals Tribunal and the Attorney-General's own role. We will most probably continue to have the occasional judicial audit such as the one undertaken by Mr Justice Hope, an audit which incidentally happens to show how unnecessary such a parliamentary committee is.

Of course, because of its paranoia, this Government seems determined to supervise ASIO out of operational efficiency. It is also a bad idea because any analogy with Congressional oversight of the intelligence community of the United States is a completely false one. In Australia, Ministers are members of parliament and are still responsible, accountable to Parliament. In the United States the legislature and the Executive are separate. Moreover, Congress does not function at all times on party lines and members are not elected to committees by the party. Again, in the Congress the committees have a good record in protecting classified information. The Congress also maintains effective powers to censor, suspend or expel any member responsible for unorthodox disclosure of confidential information.

In Australia, not only are there no real restraints, but also is the record dismal. Indeed, we have a Cabinet Minister who leaked information relating to national security and an Administration where the use of judicious leaks has become a way of governing.
The Canadian Parliament, through its Special Committee of the Senate, took a very sensible attitude to the idea of a parliamentary committee overseeing intelligence. It said:

Parliamentary committees are notoriously subject to vagaries of time, changes in membership and overwork. There is also the problem of maintaining security of information. This has reference in part to the possibility of partisan motivation in some members, but it also refers to the general question of whether that type of committee can maintain the requisite confidentiality by reason of the nature of its proceedings.

Mr Justice Hope also recommends that consideration be given to the allocation to the Special Minister of State of responsibility for protective security policy and co-ordination. Leaving aside the irony of giving the current Special Minister of State (Mr Young) responsibility for security and the prevention of leaks, the coalition approaches this suggestion with an open mind.

As a result of Mr Justice Hope's previous submission on security, a number of reforms were implemented. The royal commissioner now proposes on three grounds the transfer of these functions from ASIO to Special Minister of State. Whilst the coalition accepts the soundness of the three reasons propounded by the royal commissioner for this change, it remains to be convinced that the Australian Federal Police and Special Minister of State have the capacity to assume this vital role. Australia does have secrets which the Australian Government is obliged to protect. Left wing paranoia in the Labor Party about security is no justification for any abdication of this responsibility by the Government.

The coalition also notes Mr Justice Hope's comments on the collection of foreign intelligence in Australia and his recommendation that certain amendments be made to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act. This would enable ASIO in certain circumstances to conduct intelligence gatherings in Australia relating to the capabilities, intentions or activities of foreign groups of powers. The coalition, while not opposing in principle an extension of ASIO powers in this way, would be deeply concerned if, as a result of changes, there was any diminution of Australia's ability to conduct foreign intelligence gatherings within Australia. The coalition is in general agreement on the Royal Commissioner's remarks on incidental intelligence.

In turning to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, it is, of course, not my intention to comment on the confidential aspect of the Royal Commissioner's report. This limits me drastically in what I can say. I knew the Organisation well. I had the honour-I indicate 'the honour'-to have been the Minister in charge of ASIS for some five years. I am pleased to note Mr Justice Hope's comments that ASIS has been:

Organising and reorganising over the last decade to achieve its goals-its success in doing so has not been dramatic but it had been good. It has proved that it is a valuable part of Australia's intelligence service.
I also welcome the fact that it has recovered from the difficulties of the Sheraton incident and the firmer steps that have been taken to ensure that no such incident will happen again.

Equally, in the operation of the Defence Signals Directorate, I am unable to comment on matters of real substance. Once again, however, I note the Royal Commissioner's remarks that DSD has maintained its impressive performance. Whilst on DSD, I cannot help noting how fitting it is that every now and again the drivel and nonsense perpetrated by the Left in this country are justly destroyed. This happened with the release of the Petrov papers. It has happened again here. In this case, it was a former Labor member for Fraser, Mr Fry, with his assertion that the intelligence community knew that the five Australian journalists 'killed in East Timor were going to be treated as combatants, knew that the Indonesians were about to invade the area where the journalists were, and did not do a damn thing to protect them.'

As the Royal Commissioner states, he investigated DSD activities. It had no knowledge of where the journalists were, nor that they were going to be treated as combatants. Moreover, Mr Justice Hope states there was no evidence of improper behaviour on DSD's part. It is these sorts of attacks which do such harm to morale in security organisations, and place pressure on the government principle of neither confirming nor denying matters of security. I welcome the Royal Commissioner's recommendations that the principle-that is, the principle of neither confirming nor denying matters of security-be adhered to. I hope that this Government will not repeat its mistake during the Combe-Ivanov affair and depart again from the principle.

Whilst on ASIS and DSD, may I say that I agree with the Royal Commissioner's remarks on the need to strengthen certain aspects of their intelligence gathering operations. I also lend my support to Mr Justice Hope's suggestion that the Inspector-General should be able to, if requested by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the case of ASIS and the Minister for Defence in the case of DSD, investigate the appropriateness of particular internal procedures. We would not support any proposal to enable the Inspector-General to act on his or her own initiative in this regard.

The role of an independent watch-dog assisting the relevant Minister in looking after the public interest may well be a useful addition to the mechanisms for the accountability of our intelligence services. I also see merit in his recommendation concerning the Inspector-General, the Office of National Assessments and the Joint Intelligence Organisation.

The Prime Minister, in his statement, rejected Mr Justice Hope's proposal to introduce legislative amendments to remove ASIO's operational records from the requirement to hand records over to the Australian Archives after 30 years and from the application of the 30-year rule in regard to public access. The Government's argument that there are sufficient safeguards in the Archives Act do little to mitigate the concern expressed by Mr Justice Hope. The Government has appeared to put historical and public curiosity ahead of a need to safeguard the large volume of sensitive documents held by ASIO, many of which have been provided in confidence by overseas sources. There is genuine concern in the intelligence community, and supported by the Royal Commissioner, that the 30-year period is too short. The Government should take heed.

Finally, I turn to Mr Justice Hope's examination of ONA and JIO. ONA was established by the previous Government largely as a result of His Honour's first Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security. I note Mr Justice Hope's remarks that ONA has been able to establish its independence and authority and has done so by the quality of the work it produces. The difficulties of placing a new intelligence organisation into an already fairly crowded area seem to have been largely overcome. The bureaucratic problem of co-ordination and co-operation pointed to by Mr Justice Hope, while not unexpected, hopefully can be resolved.

I conclude by saying that the security forces in this country have been under constant threat from the left wing of the Labor Party and various other lunatic fringes in the community. I would hope that all ordinary Australians and maybe even some of the rat-bags who sit on the other side will take in this statement of Mr Justice Hope's:

The product of Australia's intelligence services is a great value to the nation. No doubt there will always be room for improvement and no doubt their need for resources will always have to be measured against the proper claims of other national interests. I am satisfied, however, that Australia's investment in its intelligence services is well justified, and that Governments should continue to ensure that they are able to fulfil the important roles they play in helping to advise and protect Australia's national interest.
On behalf of all honourable members on this side of the House, I can fully endorse that paragraph. I reiterate the Opposition's appreciation to Mr Justice Hope and the staff who assisted him.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The alarming run-down by the Government of the manpower, morale and effectiveness of the Army Reserve.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance we bring before the House today-the alarming run down by this Government of the manpower, morale and effectiveness of the Army Reserve-is a matter where concern has now gone far beyond the armed forces. For some time now both Regular and Reserve people have been greatly concerned about what this Government has been doing, not only to the Army Reserve but to the defence forces in general. That concern has now gone far beyond the armed forces. The community at large is also concerned about the parlous state in which the Army Reserve has been placed. Before I detail exactly what this Government has done to the Army Reserve over the last couple of years, I would like firstly to contrast it with the performance of the coalition in that regard and, secondly, at the outset lay down exactly what the role of the Army Reserve is. The Army Reserve now has exactly the same role under the total force concept as the Regular Army. That role is defined in the Army Office publication Army in the 1980s:

SPEECH.PARA: To organise, train, equip and maintain forces for the conduct of timely and sustained combat operations on land. To develop and maintain Reserve forces to supplement or expand the Regular Army.
To provide a sound base for expansion.
To maintain reserves of equipment and supplies.

In view of the appalling record of the Australian Labor Party in relation to the Army Reserve over the last couple of years it is very doubtful whether the Army Reserve could now perform any of those functions laid down in Army in the 1980. The damage done by this Government to the Army Reserve, since the Budget of August 1983 in particular, has been enormous. There could not possibly be a greater contrast than that between the record of the coalition and the record of the incumbent Labor Government on this matter. By contrast, the coalition took the Reserve seriously and in its period in office gave it great support and encouragement.

I go back to February 1980, when the importance of the Reserve was recognised by the Fraser Government. In February 1980 Prime Minister Fraser announced an expansion of the Army Reserve numbers from 22,000 to 30,000. That 30,000 was deemed to be the effective strength and the increase was to take place over a period of five years. However, as regional instability worsened during 1980 some changes were made to the original decision. Honourable members might recall that the Afghanistan crisis in particular caused a great deal of concern in this country and in other nations throughout this region. Accordingly, the period for expansion of the Army Reserve was shortened from five years to one year. As a back-up the Fraser Government very sensibly allocated $3.7m for recruiting over the 1980-81 financial year. A further $70m was allocated for new facilities and equipment, again over that 1980-81 financial year, with a capacity to carry over those funds as necessary into the next financial year. Those funds were designated for things such as extra depot facilities, clothing, equipment, boots and so on.

By 1980-81, that target had been achieved and the Reserve reached a posted strength of over 33,000. As one always has to allow in the Army Reserve for a factor of about 10 per cent for those coming and going the effective strength in fact was about 30,000. So the target of 30,0000 was achieved quite precisely. Additional Australian Regular Army cadres were allocated to make the expansion process work. Both Reserve officers and ARA cadres worked very hard to make that expansion successful. I think it was an extraordinary achievement on the part of both the Reserves and the Regular Army that the Reserve was expanded by one-third in a year. This was not a one-off success as it has often been claimed by some people, particularly on the Government side, in trying to explain away the rundown in the last couple of years. In fact, that growth was maintained right throughout the 1981-83 period. The Reserves developed a new sense of purpose, stability and continuity. Both senior Regular and Reserve officers came to be very impressed by the higher standards and good morale evident in the Reserve. In fact, had that good support from government continued there is no doubt that the tremendous success story in regard to the work undertaken by the coalition in expanding the Army Reserve would have been continued.

I now come to what has happened under this Government. The tremendous record of the coalition in expanding the Reserve so successfully and in sustaining that expansion was undercut in August 1983 by the first Hawke Labor Budget. For the first time in 20 years, Reserve pay was taxed. At the same time, training days were cut from 38.25 to 36 days per man. In terms of practical effect, some units were down to as little as 30 training days a man a year. Advertising funds also were cut. By September 1983 the first effects of these hostile decisions by the Labor Government on the Reserve were apparent. I draw honourable member's attention to a manpower chart of the Third Division of the Army Reserve which shows quite clearly that in September, immediately after the Budget, there was an end to the growth that had taken place under the previous Government. That growth plateaued out and came to an end. In October 1983 advertising ceased completely. We really started to run into trouble in December 1983, when the tax on Reserve pay was actually implemented. That tax initially operated on 100 per cent of the pay. However, the Government having recognised that it had made a mistake, it cut it back to 50 per cent of pay. Once again, the effect can be very clearly seen. It can be seen from the chart that from December 1983 there was a plummeting trend in Reserve strength.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate that chart.

—I intend to seek leave to incorporate that chart in Hansard later on. The cutback in training days meant that by December 1983 many reservists were parading unpaid. That went on for some time until it became so embarrassing that unpaid training had to be forbidden by the Army.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, in March 1983 we got the final nail in the coffin, when manning levels were reduced and a new ceiling was imposed on the Reserve posted strength of 30,000. Again allowing for that 10 per cent factor for those coming and going, the effective strength obviously was significantly below that. That was a real cut in Reserve strength. Again if we look at the graph of the Third Division, we can see that that downward trend accelerated even faster, heading toward the appalling situation we have now. It is a shameful exercise all round. Right throughout the 1984-85 period, as a result of the cumulative effect of all those hostile Government actions on the Reserve, the downward trend accelerated. By the end of April 1985 the posted strength of the Reserve was down to 23,900. I remind honourable members that in August 1983 when the first Hawke Labor Budget was brought down, the strength of of the Army Reserve was 33,523. It is now down to an effective strength of 20,000 compared--

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. It has an effective strength of 20,000-and that number is falling-compared with an effective strength of 30,000 in August 1983. What has happened under this Government over the past 20 months is that we have lost 10,000 reservists. One-third of the Army Reserve has voted with its feet and left. This Government can take sole responsibility for having destroyed one-third of the Army Reserve. That is an appalling record. In support of what I have just said I seek leave to incorporate a graph in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall have to check with the Speaker to see whether the graph falls within the guidelines. I will let the honourable gentleman know when the Speaker has made a decision on the matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: (For technical reasons, the graph was not incorporated in Hansard)

TALK.START.PARA: —If one looks particularly at the people who hold the Reserve together-the officers and the non-commissioned officers-one again sees an appalling situation. There is now a national shortfall of 1,000 officers. Over the past 12 months the average rate of officers and NCOs leaving the Reserve has doubled. Over the last few years it has normally been in the order of 6 to 8 per cent per annum.
—That is in addition to the cadet force too.

—That is perfectly correct. The Government did exactly the same in relation to cadets. Over the last 12 months officers and NCOs have left the Reserve at an average rate of 16 per cent. It is a totally disgraceful situation. One can ask: Why did this happen? The worst interpretation of this is that there was on the part of this Government a deliberate intention, under pressure from the Left Wing, to denigrate our defence capability and run it down. The best interpretation is that it was sheer bumbling ineptitude and a failure to understand the nature and value of the reserves. I observe that having watched this Government over the last two years I am inclined to think that in this case it was sheer stupidity.

SPEECH.PARA: How did it happen? It happened because this Government removed the tax-free incentive granted to the reserves in 1964 by the Menzies Government. This had an unequal effect on individuals because obviously those who pay tax on their Reserve pay, all pay tax at differing marginal rates. Those who are the hardest hit are the high achievers, the successful industry executives who might be captains or majors, skilled tradesmen who might be sergeants or warrant officers, the ones who are paying the highest marginal tax rates. The high achievers in the community who want to contribute are the ones who have been driven out. Obviously, this tax on Reserve pay could not have worked from the very beginning.

As some people are aware, in its place is what is called a Reserve allowance. It was recommended by the Coldham Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay and has proved to be very ineffective. It is also taxable; so we have the same base problem as we had with the taxing of Reserve pay-it is administratively cumbersome and difficult to apply. It cuts into the defence budget because, obviously, the tax on Reserve pay goes to Consolidated Revenue through the Treasury as does the tax on the Reserve allowance. However, paying the Reserve allowance is an extra charge against the defence budget. So the defence budget loses overall by the institution of this Reserve allowance.

What are we going to do about it or, more particularly, what is this Government going to do about it? I suggest that it use its current discussions in relation to the Budget to scrap the tax on Reserve pay without further delay and, of course, as part of that exercise also remove the Reserve allowance. If the Government removes the tax on Reserve pay obviously the Reserve allowance becomes totally unnecessary. I think there is a very good case for increasing the number of training days per man to the level that applied during the days when the coalition was in government. One final factor that this Government could put into effect is that the Minister of the day could finally take some interest in what the Army Reserve is doing; he has certainly taken no interest to date.

There are certain things that this Government should not be doing. It should not be using the excuse-it is quite fatuous and stupid-that there has been a rise in the number of ineffectives in the Reserve and the Government has been culling them out. That is absolute rubbish. The number has been 10 per cent for years. For heavens sake, I hope that someone on the other side does not get up here today and claim that it is another measure which is under review by Dibb and the Government cannot make a decision for another year. The Government will get away with that for just so long but it cannot use the excuse of the Dibb review forever for forestalling any decisive action in any area.

Also the Government's television advertisements will be coming along in late June-early July and they will be interesting. However, they will certainly not resolve the Government's basic problem. Finally, I refer to a couple of quotes of what one might call the rhetoric side of what this Government has done rather than the reality. In the Australian of 10 May 1985 the Prime Minister is reported as saying:
A credible military capability which will hopefully deter and, if necessary defeat, the use of force against Australia remains an indisputable component of national security policy . . .
In the alliance context, the Government is committed to developing independent Australian defence capabilities suited to the 1980's and beyond.
I think I have shown that we have little of either capability or credibility. This is the final touch. Defence Minister Beazley in the Age of 10 May 1985 is reported as saying:
I am concerned that we should be able fairly rapidly to deploy to a battlefield more troops than we are able to deploy now. At present, we can deploy a thousand or so men quite rapidly-
that in itself is a disgrace-
and then mobilise over months two big divisions.
The Minister is a great optimist. As he now knows there is not much left of anything to deploy anywhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened with considerable interest to the speech made by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred). The matter of public importance which he raised is:

SPEECH.PARA: The alarming run-down by the Government of the manpower, morale and effectiveness of the Army Reserve.

I must say in looking at the material placed before the House by the honourable member that I am looking forward to examining with some care the chart which he has sought to have incorporated in Hansard. He told us a story in which he compared figures in rather a strange way. In 1980, when the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan, the former Government decided to increase the number in the reserves from 22,000 to 30,000. That was the information given by the honourable member to the House. The number of the reserves went up to 33,500. The target for the reserves over the next five-year period by the present Government is the same 30,000 that applied when the honourable member's Government was in office. His Government allowed the reserves to increase beyond their target. His Government made no provision for any number of people in the reserves beyond the 30,000 and so the quality of training for the reserves under the former coalition Government fell alarmingly.

It was the policy of this Government to reduce the number of reserves to its 30,000 target. The honourable member has said that the number of people effectively in the reserves has fallen by 10,000. I would be interested to see the comparisons because the figures show that today the reserves are 5,300 below target. I take it that the honourable member is repudiating the target of his Government which is the 30,000 that remains the target of the present Government. When the present Government came to office it discontinued the advertising for recruitment to the reserves that previously applied. The number of people in the Army Reserve, which at the end of March stood at 24,701, is 5,300 below target. Advertising is being set in train to bring the reserves back up to the Government's target.

I noted with interest a reply given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to a question asked in the House this afternoon. It is wrong to single out the Army Reserve as being an example of some vast area of malpractice or neglect by the Australian Government of the Australian Defence Force. When one looks at defence and the record of this Government on defence one needs to look at that record as a whole. This Government has devoted a great deal of its time-I include the former Minister for Defence, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and the present Minister for Defence-to endeavouring to work out priorities and overcome the years of neglect by the previous coalition Government.

I take this opportunity to remind honourable members of some of those areas of neglect-areas in which the former Whitlam Government was concerned and had moved but in which very little was done through the Fraser years. When the Whitlam Government was elected in 1972 Australia was coming to the end of its involvement in Vietnam. For a considerable period hardly any equipment had been ordered for the Australian Defence Force and in a very real sense that Defence Force was living on its fat. We were running down our equipment stocks. In fact, many items of equipment, such as tanks, armed personnel carriers and Caribou aircraft, were placed under a lot of pressure in Vietnam and needed either major upgrading or replacement. It was an opportunity for the Whitlam Government to set in train an equipment program for the Australian Defence Force, the like of which had not been seen for many years.

I am sure all honourable members who have an interest in defence understand that there is a very long lead time in an equipment program. The equipment that the Australian Defence Force has today in many cases was ordered 20 years ago. The items presently on order for the Australian Defence Force will come on stream at the end of a considerable period-sometimes a decade-and will be around at the turn of the century and beyond. The Whitlam Government ordered the first two FFG frigates to be built in the United States. At that time consideration-

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the Army Reserve.

—Fine. I am trying to paint a broad brush position of the Australian Defence Force. It is important to see the Army Reserve against the background of what has been happening in the Defence Force generally. At that time we had a study on the helicopters for those FFGs. It is only within the last few weeks that the announcement has been made by the Government that orders are being placed to equip the frigate program with the helicopters it has needed since day one. There are now eight frigates in service or in prospect for the Royal Australian Navy.

SPEECH.PARA: One should also go back a bit in history and say that in the Whitlam Government days we were looking at upgrading the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal as a replacement for RAAF Darwin and the principal base for a fighter force in the north of Australia. That decision was under active consideration by the Whitlam Government. Nothing further was done about it in the seven years of the Fraser Government. A decision was recently made. As we all know, the first expenditure on upgrading RAAF Tindal is taking place in the current financial year. It is going to cost over $160m.

In addition to facilities of that kind, one has to look at what happened at RAAF Darwin, in particular the disgraceful state of housing for the permanent forces in the Australian Defence Force. It has been disgraceful for many years. At the rate of expenditure by the previous Government, to ensure that every member of the permanent Defence Force had an adequate standard of housing, it would have taken 20 years. Amongst the worst of the accommodation was the accommodation at RAAF Darwin. That accommodation was severely damaged in Cyclone Tracy at the end of 1974. In some cases, very ad hoc repairs were made in the belief that the decision on RAAF Tindal was to be made. At the end of last year, after the decision on upgrading RAAF Tindal had been made, money was provided to upgrade the standard of defence housing at RAAF Darwin. The people who have lived in that very sub-standard accommodation have lived in an absolutely disgraceful situation about which the previous Government had done nothing for a period of seven years.

One could go on and on talking about these areas of neglect. Training areas for the Army were under consideration by the Whitlam Government. That is not necessarily a popular political decision but, if we are to have effective defence forces, appropriate and adequate training areas need to be acquired. The Whitlam Government returned to the New South Wales Government some areas of land around Sydney and around Sydney Harbour that were no longer relevant for defence purposes. It was recognised that Holsworthy, which is subject to suburban encroachment, was no longer suitable for some of its then training activities. A procedure was set in train to acquire training areas. The Labor Government has come along seven years down the track and now has to bite the bullet on those important questions of training areas for the Australian Defence Force.

Arising out of this debate some people might feel that the Government has done nothing about the Army Reserve. We have heard about the question of the tax on Army Reserve pay and about the recommendations of the Coldham Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay, which resulted in an allowance for reservists. That decision was made last year and it means that members of the Army Reserve, particularly those conscientious members of the Reserve, have a take home pay equivalent to what it was before.

The Defence Force Renumeration Tribunal, under legislation brought in by this Government last year and appointed this year, has a continuing charter to look at the question of Defence Force pay on an annual and continuing basis. It is going to have, as part of its charter, the responsibility of looking at Reserve pay as well. I remind honourable members of the history of pay increases for the Australian Defence Force. When the Labor Government was elected in 1972 it ordered a review of Defence Force pay. That review took place in 1973 and it was paid in that year. In the system that has existed, the discretion about when to review Services pay has been a matter for the Minister for Defence. Under the previous Government a further review was not ordered until 1980. The recommendation came down in 1981. The money was not available to meet those increases in pay in 1981 and the actual increases were paid in 1982. That meant that there was just under nine years between one major review of Defence Force pay and the next major review of Defence Force pay. In that period was the seven years of the coalition Government.
A number of decisions of significance to the Army Reserve have been made by the present Government and they have been announced by the Minister for Defence in more recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly the tax on pay. That was fairly significant.

—I have dealt with that already. It is a pity that the honourable member for McPherson did not show enough interest to be in the House. I will not repeat myself. One of the important Press statements that were made by the Minister was released on 5 May this year. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Regular and Reserve units of the Army's Field Force are to be more closely integrated.

Eleven Regular and Reserve units in Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia will be involved in this latest phase of integration, which will see some reservists being trained and administered within Regular brigades and units.
''This development will continue to improve the readiness and expansion capacity of the Army,'' Mr Beazley said.
''It is a further move towards a Total Force structure for the Army, and reflects the important part that dedicated reservists have in providing for the future defence of Australia.

''Following the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into the Citizen Military Forces set up by the Whitlam Government in 1973, some steps have already been taken to combine progressively the Regular and Reserve components into a more effective force.

That statement goes on, but I will not repeat what the Minister has already said in this House. I want to make some concluding remarks. The Government agrees that the present level of Army reserves is below target and is taking action to bring that number up to 30,000 in the year immediately ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your TV ads?

—I am sorry that the honourable member for McPherson suggested that people dropped out of the Defence Force Reserve because of questions of pay. This nation owes a great debt to the reserves, not only in the Army, but also in the other areas of the Services. Over the years the reserves have had a lot of people who have enlisted to serve their country. Those people have been more concerned with money for training time and the like than they have been for pay. Previous governments have not served them well. There are problems in that area today. There are enormous problems across the board in the Australian Defence Force. This Government is spending more money on defence than its predecessor. In each of the two Labor governments there has been more money provided than the average over the Fraser years-certainly in the two Budgets that immediately preceded the first Labor Government Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those people who would like to see this Government spending more on defence. It is the view of the defence sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in a report last year that we should try to increase the level of defence expenditure by an amount which would be of the order of 4 1/2 per cent in real terms per annum. But we live in fairly difficult days. There are severe economic problems in this country. There are great problems of unemployment and governments have to address all of those considerations and, of course, a lot of humanitarian issues as well. But it is totally untrue for anybody to suggest that the present Australian Government is underrating the Defence Force reserves or the Army Reserve in particular or that it is neglecting them and will do so in the future. Whatever has been said in the debate today, the Budget to be brought down on 20 August will prove that very point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr Speaker has advised me that, if it is technically possible and does not delay the production of Hansard, the graph that the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) seeks to have incorporated in Hansard will be so incorporated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted with interest the wide-ranging defence overview of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross). Unfortunately, neither he nor the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) appears to have the capacity to examine rationally the composition, structure and manpower requirements of our reserve forces.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now faced with a situation in which our reserve forces have been allowed to deteriorate to a point where they are exhibiting all the symptoms of terminal insufficiency and neglect. Decisive and radical treatment is required to halt the progress of this debilitating disease. Whether or not this Government cares to take action, or even knows that action must be taken, is a matter of conjecture.

It is apparent the Hawke Government regards the security of Australia and Australians as a disposable commodity. This Government has exhibited its lack of concern for the future defence and security of this nation by taking no positive action to rectify the immediate problems facing our reserve forces-lack of sense of purpose, lack of appropriate financial support, lack of adequate training facilities and opportunities, lack of satisfactory recruitment, and lack of morale. In fact, the only thing our defence reserve forces do not lack is the opportunity to pay increased taxes. They are penalised because of their commitment and desire to serve this country.

The resignation rate in the Reserve has reached disastrous proportions. In August 1983 the Australia-wide strength of the Reserve totalled in excess of 33,000 members. Today it is only 23,900-10,000 fewer reservists. In reality, the Reserve can field fewer than 20,000 effective personnel.

One of the major concerns is the current decline in the number of junior officers in the Reserve. There are insufficient junior officers to replace retiring senior officers. This appalling situation has arisen as a direct result of Government cutbacks in training and support, and the decision to tax 50 per cent of reservists' pay and related allowances.

Those most adversely affected by this 'levy on loyalty' include the men and women who are already in the middle income bracket. They have seen their combined civilian and Reserve earnings result in immediate promotion to higher tax brackets. In civilian life, these people are the trade and professional achievers; in the Reserve, as officers and non-commissioned officers, they have the vital combination of skills and leadership potential necessary to maintain the efficiency of existing forces and to provide adequate training for new recruits.

A well-trained, properly maintained Reserve Force is an essential factor in Australia's overall defence capability and preparedness. It depends not only on adequate numbers and financial resources, but on retention of staff, so that advanced training for specialist skills and promotion can be provided. A satisfactorily high retention rate will not be achieved unless our reservists are provided with adequate equipment, adequate training and adequate reimbursement for their efforts and sacrifices-both real and potential. Under this Government the rewards are few. The recognition of their vital role is an ever-diminishing dot on the defence horizon.

It is rather doubtful whether the promised series of television commercials designed to boost Army Reserve recruiting will have much effect whilst the policy of taxing reservists' pay remains in force. The mind boggles at the possible content of these planned forays into the living rooms of Australia, when two of our lesser-known local military heroes will be promoted to the front lines of the television ratings war. However, after a solid diet of yabbies, with the 1812 Overture as accompanying background dinner music, the public will perhaps have their dormant 'Join the reserves' instincts titillated by the more dramatic exploits and encouragement of Captain Hawkeye and Corporal Kim who have no doubt paid up their Actors Equity dues especially for the occasion.

Another area of concern is the integration of the Regular and Reserve units of the Army's Field Force. This is an excellent concept, but it will be successful only if the Reserves enjoy the same access to funds, equipment and training resources and opportunities as the Regular Army. At present this is not the case.

A recent issue of Defence Industry states that Major-General Jack Kelly, General Officer Commanding Field Force Command, considers that, should Reserve units be required as back-up for Regular elements in a conflict situation, they would require at least 90 days continuous training-in some instances an even longer period-to bring them up to acceptable standards to enter battle. The same article highlights the fact that current equipment deficiencies preclude the provisions of adequate training opportunities for some Reserve units. For example, there is no sign of tanks being available for units nominated as tank units under the Force Structure Study. As a consequence, their 'training' would be to drive Land Rovers. If, at some time in the future, a Leopard tank were allocated to a Reserve armoured element such as the 1st/15th Royal New South Wales Lancers at Parramatta, it would have to be left parked in the depot. To quote General Kelly:
We won't be able to afford to run it around. We'll train them how to actually drive a tank, but they won't be able to run it around. Not straight away, anyhow. It will depend on how the money is.
General Kelly said that if operating costs were cut any lower in the Regular Army 'we will start to go backwards'. He continued:
To be quite frank, in the Army Reserve we are going backwards now.

Notwithstanding the current decline and continuing difficulties facing the Reserve forces, their role in our overall security is still of major importance. The intelligent reform of amending legislative restrictions on call-out of the Reserve for full time service is more critical now than ever before. Under the present provisions, reserves cannot be called out except in situations of war or defence emergency. Serving members of the Reserve believe they should, and would, be called for service if required in circumstances short of war or declared emergency. Their employers also believe the Reserve is a meaningful part of our defence, and they too expect their employees, who are reservists, to be called for when needed.

At no cost to the taxpayer, section 50(A) (1) of the Defence Act can simply be amended to provide for the call-out of the Reserve forces, or any part of them, for continuous full time military services in situations other than war or defence emergency. This would put call-out of the Reserve on the same straightforward basis as call-out of the Regular Army Emergency Reserve as specified in section 46 of the Defence Act, with the conditions applying to service in section 46 similarly applying to the reserves.

This Government's unsympathetic treatment of the needs and problems facing a vital component of our Defence Force is a continuing and shameful saga of neglect, irresponsibility and inaction. It is perhaps well summed-up as follows by Francis Quales:
Our God and soldiers we adore when at the brink of ruin-not before; After deliverance, both alike requited, Our God forgotten, and our soldiers slighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition has chosen today to talk about the rundown in the manpower, morale and effectiveness of the Army Reserve. Historically, the Opposition has always been long on rhetoric with respect to the Army and the whole commitment of defence forces, but it has proved itself to be very deficient in terms of performance. I note that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has now left the chamber. It is no good people such as the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) talking in this House about the issue of funding. They have to recognise that when they were in government they were dealing with a Treasurer who had at his feet the same sorts of economic issues we have.

SPEECH.PARA: One is never really sure where the Opposition stands in debates such as this. For some members of the Opposition it is spend, spend, spend, yet a few of the others who come creeping out from the undergrowth, the economic dries, want us not to spend and to continue not to spend. It would make a lot of sense if members of the Opposition could sort themselves out before they make such speeches. I am sure that the Australian public would be advantaged by that, because of the confusion the Opposition creates. We are never really sure whether we are dealing with members of the National Party, who want to spend a lot more, with some in the Liberal Party who are from time to time concerned about spending and who perhaps misguidedly seek to spend more, or with those in the Liberal Party who seek to reduce spending. We are never really sure which group we are dealing with. We are dealing in this debate with those who want to increase spending. Well, that is all right. That is the group we are identifying today, but let us be sure which group we are dealing with. I think it is important that the Australian community understand that because the other side of spending, of course, is taxation. I could talk further about that but I will not at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's where you spend it.

—I recognise the point made by the honourable member for Wide Bay. It is where we spend that is important. We also recognise that effective spending is important. From the way honourable members have spoken so far in this debate, one would almost wonder whether, if they were in government, they would have Reserve units in Afghanistan. That is what they recruited members of the Reserve for, and recruited frantically. One can remember the drums of war being beaten in this country by Prime Minister Fraser and his cohorts, who came down upon us saying: 'We are about to be invaded by the Soviet Union via Afghanistan'. One wonders that the Army Reserve is not committed to Afghanistan because that is the sort of scenario honourable members opposite painted. To head down that track is a very dangerous course for the Opposition because the Australian public was similarly deceived in the 1960s and 1970s about Indo-China and Vietnam. It is unwise for those opposite to practise further deception upon the Australian community because the community does not forget that previous deception.

SPEECH.PARA: I add that, as part of that deception, people such as those previously in government were prepared to turn their backs upon the Vietnam veterans when they returned here with the memory of unpleasant experiences and with unpleasant war-caused illnesses. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) was a prime example of someone who beat the drums of war very loudly but, when it came to the consequences of war, was not prepared to accept that there were Vietnam veterans who may have been impaired by chemically caused problems such as the agent orange situation. Let us be clear in our rhetoric in this place, that we know precisely what we are saying. I am saying to those on the other side who have already spoken that we need to get this structure very clear. There are some central issues to address. I note that the Opposition has said that our Reserve Force is below strength. That has already been dealt with by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross). We recognise that the Reserve Force is under strength by some 5,300, and we are doing something about increasing that strength.

I think it is important to emphasise that we are also talking about appropriate levels of pay. Only scant attention was paid by the Opposition to the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay headed by Mr Justice Coldham. It is important to recognise that members of the defence forces must have adequate levels of pay, but I was a little concerned to deduce from comments of members of the Opposition that they were prepared to give those in the Army Reserve very preferential tax treatment. When they were in office, the Department of Defence told them that it would be appropriate to try to equalise taxation arrangements. When honourable members opposite were in office the Department was advocating the path down which we proceeded. We have now brought in a taxation treatment which aims at a degree of equity. One wonders how easy it is to get to an equitable taxation position. It is one of those elusive goals we have, but one has no excuse for working in the other direction.

The Government is suggesting that it is important to have appropriate levels of pay, and Mr Justice Coldham has looked at that, but it is also appropriate to have equitable levels of taxation. I do not think I can accept the issue honourable members opposite have raised. I do not think we on this side can accept the proposition that a more equitable taxation system is not something we should aim at. That is something that I believe we should be aiming at all the time. Whilst many people were very concerned at the time about the decision we took on taxation, what we finally arrived at in regard to taxation arrangements for Reserve Force pay-in effect, the imposition of a 30 per cent tax rate-is more sustainable. We are not arguing for an inequitable position. We are not saying that these people should be treated adversely by having very high marginal rates, nor are we saying that they should be removed from the tax system. We are saying: 'Let us look at the average rate of tax they should pay'. I defend that decision, because I think it is a sensible one in the light of the argument that the rest of the community should also be paying equitable rates of tax.

I turn to the arrangements for integration, which have been addressed by other members. The question of the integration of the Reserve forces into the Regular forces is very important. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, an all-party committee of which I was a member at the time, completed a report on the Australian Defence Force structure and capabilities. One of the advantages of that report was that it gave us a fairly rational framework with respect to what we believed were desirable goals for Defence Force structure and capabilities. When we talk about Defence Force needs in this country we must try to deal with a fairly rational picture. I applaud honourable members of the Committee for their contributions to that picture, because I think that is important. I say to Opposition members who have spoken today that they have to be wary of the rhetoric. It is all right suddenly to perceive a defence threat, try to beat it up and seek to match the rhetoric with performance, but what has been done in the meantime in terms of the underlying structure and capabilities may be a grave disservice to the Defence Force. We could go at length into the issues of procurement policy and procurement deficiencies. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in Question Time today spoke about areas of deficiency. He spoke about the question of the on-again off-again aircraft carrier purchase, or non-purchase. He also spoke about helicopter procurement and about the areas of Army manoeuvring and deployment and decisions that were not taken but rolled over.

Obviously, we do not want to get into too negative an environment in this debate, but we have an obligation to look continually at the needs of the defence forces and to have a rational view, recognising that we will always have to deal with rhetorical arguments. That is the nature of the political community by which we are surrounded. Nevertheless, we cannot afford to say: 'Let us distort the structure and capability of our Defence Force to try to meet some short term rhetorical goal we might want to erect'. There have been at least two occasions on which members of the Opposition have done that in government. The Afghanistan exercise was one and the Indo-China exercise was another. We will not go into the merits and demerits of those matters, but if, as a consequence of such a rhetorical exercise, we distort the underlying structure and capabilities of our Defence Force we will have a long term problem. This Government is trying to address some of those problems. It is not easy, because Defence Force matters are always big Budget matters, but in respect of the consultancy work that is currently being done for the Minister for Defence in terms of Defence Force priorities, I am confident that we will emerge with a much more effective Defence Force structure and a much better equipped Defence Force.

Clearly, there are some issues we need to address. Many of those have been raised in today's debate. It is not good enough for members of the Opposition to engage in exercises in rhetoric in which they seek to put up a position. It is very important to recognise that we have a long term commitment in terms of the structure and capability of the Defence Force. I believe that what we on this side are doing is satisfactory. Some of us on this side would like to see even further improvement. I believe that those improvements will come, certainly as a result of the work that is being done at present. Clearly, it is possible to defend the Government's record on the Defence Force. We believe that it is satisfactory.
