PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill I introduce today is to provide a separate law on cheques. The Government foreshadowed its intention to introduce this legislation when it released a draft Cheques Bill for public comment in February 1984.

The law on cheques is presently governed substantially by the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 which also regulates the law relating to other negotiable instruments such as bills of exchange and promissory notes. Essentially, the Bill will revise the provisions of the Bills of Exchange Act applicable to cheques, effectively confining the operation of the Act to bills of exchange other than cheques. The Bill will also clarify the law on cheques in certain areas of existing uncertainty and make a number of substantive changes to that law. However, the new legislation will not alter the fundamental legal character of cheques. In conjunction with the present Bill, I will be introducing a Bill to amend the Bills of Exchange Act making certain changes to the Act that are largely consequential upon the introduction of the Cheques Bill.
Background

The Bills of Exchange Act is modelled on the United Kingdom Bills of Exchange Act of 1882. The only amendment of the Australian Bills of Exchange Act of any substance-made by the Bills of Exchange Amendment Act 1971-reduced the need for endorsement of order cheques lodged by payees with their banks for collection. Thus, the present law on cheques in Australia effectively dates back over 100 years.

Some of the more important changes the Bill will make to the law on cheques are based on recommendations of a committee, chaired by the late Mr Justice Manning of the New South Wales Supreme Court, which reviewed the Bills of Exchange Act. The Manning Committee was appointed by the then Government in 1962, to examine, amongst other things, the provisions of the Act and to recommend any amendments to the Act it considered desirable. The most important recommendation of the Committee, which reported in 1964, was that there should be separate legislation dealing with cheques. This recommendation was based on the following factors:
Since the enactment of the Bills of Exchange Act, the use of cheques had increased enormously compared with other bills of exchange;
considerable confusion and uncertainty had developed in relation to the law on cheques because that law and the law on other bills had become intertwined under the Bills of Exchange Act, and
the law on cheques had assumed great importance to a large number of people, whereas the law relating to other bills of exchange was of significance to comparatively few people.

The Bill represents reform of a very technical area of the law. Possibly for this reason, previous governments did not accord its enactment a sufficiently high priority. I think that is understood, Mr Deputy Speaker, because, although the report was completed in 1964, here we are 21 years later with this Bill. It gives me considerable pleasure, therefore, to introduce this Bill today after many years of relative inactivity.
Public Consultation

Prior to the public exposure of the draft Bill from February to May 1984, discussions on the legislation were held over several years with the Australian Bankers Association, the Australian Merchant Bankers Association, the Commercial Law Association and the Law Council of Australia. In the pre-exposure period, comments were also sought from the States and the Northern Territory, as well as the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and the Australian Association of Credit Union Leagues, as well as the relevant trade union organisations.

The purpose of calling for comment was to give the public, including the general business community-the people who write and receive most cheques-the opportunity to participate in this important reform of the law. The public exposure period also gave the legal and banking professions, which had already been consulted, the chance to make further comments. A number of other changes have been made to the exposure draft of the Bill in the light of submissions received and I will mention some of the more important changes shortly.
Implications of the Bill for the Domestic Payment System

It has been suggested at various times in the course of preparation of the Bill that it should perhaps be deferred until there has been a broader consideration of the payment system and its legislative framework. The proponents of this view have, essentially, two concerns. The first concern is that any legislation that deals with an aspect of the payment system, such as the Cheques Bill, should regulate the rights and obligations of users and providers of electronic funds transfer systems. The second concern is that the formulation of the Bill should take account of any Government decision on the access of non-bank financial institutions to the cheque clearing system.
Electronic Funds Transfer Systems

On 25 June 1984, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the establishment of an inter-departmental working group to consider the consumer protection aspects of the development of electronic funds transfer systems in Australia and to advise whether supervisory arrangements, including legislation, are necessary. The Government considers that it would be premature to make any decision regarding legislation on electronic funds transfer systems until receipt of the working group's recommendations. In any case, even if legislation on electronic funds transfer systems is recommended in the future, it can be expected to be considered separately from the cheques legislation. This Bill is concerned with the cheque as a negotiable instrument, whereas electronic funds transfer systems are, of course, systems for moving money by means of electronics. Two fundamentally different means of achieving a transfer of funds are therefore involved.
Access to the Cheque Processing System by Non-Bank Financial Institutions

The Treasurer's Press release of 25 June 1984 also advised of the establishment of the Australian Payments System Council. One of the important matters referred by the Treasurer to the Council was the question of access by non-bank financial institutions to the cheque clearing system. The Council, in the course of its deliberations, examined existing commercial arrangements between certain banks and non-bank financial institutions whereby customers of non-bank financial institutions are able to issue cheques drawn on banks with which the non-bank financial institutions have accounts. Several problems were identified with these arrangements in the context of the operation of the present law. I am pleased to be able to tell honourable members that the Bill has been amended in several important respects to meet these problems. I stress that the provisions in the Bill which affect non-bank financial institutions in no way pre-empt any future decision that may be taken by the Government on the question of access by non-bank financial institutions to the cheque clearing system. Future decisions on the access question will be taken by the Government when the consideration of this matter has been finalised.
Vesting and Access of Paid Cheques

Clause 68 of the Bill makes provision with respect to how paid cheques are to be dealt with. The basic thrust of the clause is that, when a cheque is paid by the drawee bank, the drawee bank has the right to possession of the cheque. This approach basically follows that taken in the Bills of Exchange Act. However, this right that the drawee bank has will not disturb the common law principle that the ownership as distinct from possession in a paid cheque vests in the drawer of the cheque. This common law rule is preserved by virtue of sub-clause 4 (2) of the Bill. It has been proposed that the ownership of paid cheques should vest in the drawee bank. On the other hand, it has also been suggested by interested groups, notably local government associations, that cheques issued by such groups should be exempt from this requirement on the basis that those groups need to have access to their own cheques for audit purposes.

The Government has recently considered a submission from the Treasurer on certain recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union relating, amongst other things, to banking controls, including those relating to the retention of banking records. In response to this, a working group of officials has recently been established from interested departments and agencies under the chairmanship of a Treasury officer to consult, as necessary, with State authorities and the industry and to advise the Treasurer as to what action may be practical and appropriate with respect to those recommendations. The working group can be expected, in the course of its enquiries, to consider the question of the vesting and access of paid cheques. The Government considers, therefore, that it would be premature to deal in the Bill with the question of access to, and vesting of, paid cheques other than by preserving the legal status that paid cheques currently enjoy. Again, I stress that the present provisions in no way pre-empt the Government's future consideration of this issue.
Changes Resulting from Exposure of Draft Bill

A number of changes have been made to the draft Bill following its exposure for public comment in February last year. Some of the more important of these changes are summarised as follows: The insertion of sub-clause 6 (2), which ensures that certain rights and obligations under the Bill cannot be altered by agreement; the deletion of certain provisions contained in the exposure draft of the Bill requiring a notice of dishonour to a drawer or indorser of a cheque before the drawer or indorser could be regarded as being liable on the cheque; and a general revision of the provisions in the Bill dealing with material alterations.

These and other amendments to the Bill reflect the Government's willingness to seek and, where appropriate, to accept suggestions for changes from interested bodies in the course of the finalisation of the Bill. A comprehensive list of these changes is contained in an attachment to the explanatory memorandum on the Bill.
The Banker-Customer Relationship

The Bill does not deal in detail with the relationship between banker and customer. Although the release of the exposure draft of the Bill prompted some calls for comprehensive coverage of this subject in the Bill, it has been decided that codification of the common law is not at this point justified in this area. The Bill does, however, deal with the banker-customer relationship in certain limited respects. For example, the Bill imposes a duty on banks to present cheques promptly and to pay or dishonour cheques promptly. Banks will be liable to the holders of cheques for breach of this duty.
Content of Bill
Some of the more important features of the Bill which I will now outline represent significant advances in the law on cheques.
Definition of 'Bank'

The Bill departs from the approach of the Bills of Exchange Act in its definition of 'bank' in sub-clause 3 (1). In the Act the defined term is 'banker' and it includes any incorporated or unincorporated body which carries on the business of banking. Because the term 'business of banking' is undefined, there is, in the Australian context, some uncertainty surrounding the proper interpretation of the word 'banker'. This led to the possibility, recognised by some writers, that various corporations authorised under the Banking Act 1959 to carry on the business of banking would not be bankers for the purposes of the Bills of Exchange Act. Conversely, a person could be a banker for the purposes of that Act while carrying on business in contravention of the Banking Act. The Bill seeks to overcome this problem by defining the term 'bank' and limiting it to the Reserve Bank of Australia, banks within the meaning of the Banking Act, State banks and persons who carry on the business of banking outside Australia.
Alteration of Rights, Duties and Liabilities of Persons in Relation to Cheques

One of the most important provisions of the Bill is clause 6, which provides that, subject to certain specified exceptions, nothing in the Bill will prevent two or more persons from altering by agreement their rights, duties and liabilities in relation to one another under the Bill. An agreement between two parties cannot, of course, affect the rights, duties and liabilities of a third party. But there are important exceptions to this general principle. The provisions of the Bill that may not be altered by agreement will ensure, in particular, that the crucial legal features of the concept of a cheque may not be altered.
Transferabilty of Cheques

One of the underlying philosophies of the Bill, which is reflected in clause 39, is that every cheque should be capable of being transferred by negotiation until it is discharged. This provision will have effect notwithstanding: Firstly, any agreement between the parties to the cheque; secondly, anything on the face of the cheque-for example, words indicating an intention that the cheque not be transferred, such as 'pay X only'; and, thirdly, the crossing of the cheque.

Clause 39 changes the existing law in this area as section 13 of the Bills of Exchange Act makes it clear that a bill of exchange, which includes a cheque, may be made non-transferable. The inclusion of this clause is considered desirable for the following reasons: The holder of a cheque has always had the right to negotiate or transfer his cheque instead of paying it to the credit of his own account; crossed cheques are the medium used for making many types of payment; and some people without such accounts find it convenient to cash cheques-for example, with shopkeepers or people who provide similar services. The provision also gives effect to a recommendation of the Manning Committee.
Crossing of Cheques

The crossing of cheques will be simplified and standardised by clauses 53 to 57 of the Bill. Nothing on the face of a cheque will be effective as a crossing except two parallel transverse lines or two parallel transverse lines with words 'not negotiable' placed either completely or substantially between the lines.

Although crossings other than those just referred to will not be effective as crossings, this does not mean that a bank will be able to disregard totally a non-permissable crossing if the words of the crossing, either alone or in conjunction with other circumstances known to the bank, are sufficient to put the bank on inquiry. For example, the words 'Account Payee Only' will not make a cheque non-transferable but a court might well hold that a drawee bank was negligent in not considering the implications of those words in paying a cheque to someone other than the original payee.
Truncation of Cheques

Probably the most significant feature of the Bill is the presentment provisions which will enable the 'truncation' of cheques. Under sub-clause 62 (2), a bank will be able to present a cheque for payment by physically presenting the cheque or by employing any other means to effect presentment. There is no restriction on the 'other means' that may be used for presentment. Thus, the demand could be made, for example, by exhibition of a facsimile copy of the cheque, transmission of a copy of the cheque or transmission of particulars of the cheque by electronic means. It is clearly desirable for the means that may be used to effect presentment to be left completely open in view of the advances in banking practice in recent times.

Although the collecting bank will be able to choose any means to effect presentment of a cheque, the means chosen by the bank will be one of a number of factors to be taken into account in determining whether it has fulfilled its duty under clause 66 to present the cheque 'as soon as is reasonably practicable'. Sub-clause 62 (3) of the Bill provides that where the cheque is not delivered to the drawee bank the demand for payment of the cheque will have to identify the cheque with reasonable certainty and be in a form that is intelligible to, or readily decipherable by, the drawee bank.

It will also be possible for a bank to designate, by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, a place for the purpose of presenting cheques or for the giving or receiving of further particulars to facilitate the payment of cheques. The changes in the area of presentment of cheques have been made specifically to take account of developments in technology by enabling cheques to be presented for payment by transmission of particulars without physical movement of the cheque itself. This method of 'presentment by particulars' will speed up transactions and enable the faster clearance of cheques. Needless to say, this will provide benefits not only to banks but also to the general cheque-issuing public.
Dishonour of Cheques

The most significant aspect of the provisions in the Bill dealing with dishonour is that the drawee bank must pay or dishonour a cheque promptly. Sub-clause 67 (1) of the Bill imposes a duty on the drawee bank either to pay or to dishonour a cheque presented to it 'as soon as is reasonably practicable'. If it fails to do so, the bank may not dishonour the cheque and is liable to pay the amount of the cheque to the holder. It has been decided not to impose an arbitrary standard time limit for the payment or dishonour of cheques, firstly, because such a limit may not always be appropriate in the future given technological developments in communication and, secondly, because arbitrary time limits could be too onerous in certain cases.
Material Alterations

The provisions in the Bill relating to the material alteration of cheques represent an important change of approach from the corresponding provisions of the Bills of Exchange Act. Section 69 of the Act provides, among other things, that where a bill of exchange is materially altered without the assent of all parties liable on the bill, the bill is 'avoided'. The section also specifies the instance where alterations will be regarded as 'material'.

The problem with enumerating the circumstances in which an alteration of a cheque is to be regarded as material is that it is virtually impossible to provide an exhaustive list of these circumstances. Any such enumeration could, therefore, result in anomalies as it may be that in a particular case an alteration such as that to the date of a cheque should not be regarded as material. Basically, an alteration will be material, under sub-clause 3 (8) of the Bill, if it has the effect of altering the rights, duties or liabilities of the drawer, indorse or drawee bank in respect of the cheque. This test is well supported by authority and it is considered that a general guiding principle in determining material alterations is preferable to the enumeration of a miscellany of separate instances. The new test should also overcome difficulties that the present law produces and that have been evidenced by recent judicial decisions.
Standard of Care for Application of Protective Provisions to Paying Bank

At present the Bills of Exchange Act, with one exception, requires a paying bank to act in 'good faith and in the ordinary course of business' if it is to have benefit of the protective provisions contained in the Act. The exception is section 86, which requires a bank to act in 'good faith and without negligence' in the payment of crossed cheques. The letter standard has been adopted in all the protective provisions contained in the Bill that apply to paying banks because the existing law has the effect that a drawee bank may act negligently so long as it is in the ordinary course of business to do so. It is clearly in accordance with the modern concept of 'duty of care' that banks be required to act without negligence in all cases.
Other Significant Features of the Bill
There are several other features of the Bill which deserve brief mention:

Sub-clause 3 (5) of the Bill will extend by three months the period during which a cheque operates as a valid mandate to the drawee bank. A cheque will now not become stale until fifteen months after the date upon which it is drawn;

where a cheque inconsistently describes the sum ordered to be paid because the words and figures used express different amounts the cheque will be deemed to be an order to pay the smaller of the two sums mentioned. This is provided in clause 15. Previously, where the two differed, effect was given to the words expressing the sum to be paid and the figures were ignored;

clause 16 of the Bill will clarify the status of post-dated cheques to ensure their validity as cheques where they meet all other necessary criteria. Under the Bills of Exchange Act it was unclear whether a post-dated cheque was in fact a valid cheque

under clause 17 of the Bill, it will not be possible for the drawer to limit his liability on a cheque. In this respect, the Bill equates the drawer of a cheque with the acceptor of a bill of exchange and ensures the drawer's primary liability on the cheque;
clause 5 will provide that, with certain specified exceptions, the provisions of the Bill apply to 'bank cheques' and 'bank drafts';
clause 98 will give legal effect to the established practice of affixing a signature on a cheque by stamp or by mechanical means; and

clause 91 of the Bill will provide that where a cheque is fraudulently altered so as to increase the amount of the cheque, the alteration is the only material alteration made fraudulently and the drawee bank pays the cheque in good faith and without negligence, the bank will be able to debit the drawer's account for the original amount of the cheque.
Financial Impact Statement

The Cheques Bill is concerned with the law relating to cheques. It will not provide for any additional powers and controls to be vested in any public official. The Bill will, therefore, have no impact on Government revenues.

It is proposed that the Bill be only introduced at this stage and not proceed to finality, but it is hoped that the matter can be speedily completed in the Budget session. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill I introduce today, in conjunction with the Cheques Bill 1985, is to amend the Bills of Exchange Act 1909. The Bills of Exchange Act substantially governs the law in Australia relating to bills of exchange, including cheques and promissory notes. Upon enactment of the Cheques Bill, the law relating to cheques will be governed by that Bill. The Cheques Bill and the Bill to amend the Act will have the combined effect of confining the application of the Act to bills of exchange other than cheques. This Bill to amend the Bills of Exchange Act will also revise certain provisions of the Act to either mirror similar provisions in the Cheques Bill or give effect to recommendations of the 1964 Manning Committee report on the Act.
Content of Bill
The more significant provisions of the Bill are as follows:
Act not to apply to cheques

The Bill will insert a provision into the Act to provide, in effect, that the Bills of Exchange Act will not apply to cheques drawn on or after the date of commencement of the Cheques Bill. However, the Bill will also provide that cheques drawn before that date will continue to be governed by the Act.
Clarification of certain expressions in section 14 of the Act

To be a valid bill of exchange, a bill must, among other things, be expressed to be payable for a sum certain in money. The provisions of the Bills of Exchange Act which relate to what constitutes a 'sum payable' and a 'sum certain' by a bill of exchange will be expanded and clarified to accord with current commercial practice and to bring the provisions into line with the Cheques Bill. Thus, a bill of exchange will be valid even though it is expressed to be payable for an amount plus bank charges. The possibility of an injustice being caused under the present provisions of the Act to a drawer of a bill of exchange who makes an error when writing in the sum payable will be removed by the insertion of a new provision which provides that, where more than one sum is expressed to be payable in a bill, the lesser or least of the amounts so specified will be taken to be the operative amount. This provision will mirror a provision in the Cheques Bill and give effect to a recommendation of the Manning Committee.
Extension of time in relation to noting of bills

In the case of certain bills of exchange, evidence may be required to indicate that notice of dishonour has been given in relation to the bill. This evidence is provided by noting or protesting the bill. As the noting or protesting of a bill involves compliance with certain formalities and there are, as the Manning Committee noted, occasions when considerable technical difficulties have been experienced in complying with the relevant requirements, the time allowed for noting a bill will be extended from 24 to 48 hours after its dishonour. Moreover, a bill which has been returned by post dishonoured will be able to be protested not later than the next business day after the day of its return. These changes will introduce more flexibility in the noting and protesting of bills of exchange and, again, will give effect to a recommendation of the Manning Committee.
Expansion of provisions dealing with replacement of lost or destroyed bills

The provisions in the Bills of Exchange Act dealing with the replacement of lost or destroyed bills will be revised to bring them into line with the provisions in the Cheques Bill dealing with the replacement of lost or destroyed cheques. These changes will also give effect to a recommendation of the Manning Committee. The current provisions in the Act authorise the person who was the holder of a bill which has been lost or destroyed before it is overdue to apply to the drawer to give him another bill of the same tenor. The holder may be required to give security to the drawer as an indemnity in case a lost bill is found. This provision was criticised by the Manning Committee on the basis that it did not give equivalent rights against the acceptor or any indorser of the bill. This defect has been rectified by a new provision to be inserted into the Act by the present Bill.
The new section will make detailed provision with respect to the method by which a request for a replacement bill may be made. Under the new provision, the request must:
(i) be in the form of a notice in writing;
(ii) be served either personally or by post on the drawer;
(iii) clearly identify the original bill; and
(iv) contain sufficient information to enable the drawer to draw a new bill.

The new provision will also specify certain time limits within which a drawer will be required to provide a replacement bill. Similar time limits will apply to an acceptor or an indorser of a bill in relation to the acceptance or indorsement of the replacement bill.
Financial Impact Statement
The Bill will not provide for any additional powers and controls to be vested in any public official and will, therefore, have no impact on Government revenues. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the resolution of the House of 21 May 1985, concerning the delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament to the Australian Constitutional Convention, be amended, as follows:
(a) paragraph (1) (a)-omit '4 shall be members of the Senate and 8', substitute '5 shall be members of the Senate and 7';

(b) paragraph (1) (b)-omit '8 Members of the House of Representatives comprise 4 members of the Australian Labor Party, 3', substitute '7 Members of the House of Representatives comprise 4 members of the Australian Labor Party, 2', and

(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution agreed to by the House of Representatives.

This is a formal matter. Yesterday we approved delegations representative of both the Government and the Opposition from this House and from the Senate. The Opposition has given me advice, which I understand has been approved by its parties, that it wishes to alter the numerical representation by reducing the number from this House and increasing the number from the Senate. It makes no difference to the total number. What I have moved is somewhat of a mathematical mystery, but it works out in fact.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there have been some discussions about this amendment. The only comment I would make is that I notice that, in the debate yesterday on the original motion, views were expressed about the value or otherwise of the Constitutional Convention. I confess to being one of those cynics who regard the Convention as not having contributed a great deal towards changing the substances of concern to most members in this place. While I do not go along with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his suggestion of a people's convention, I think there is reason for the Convention system to continue. I am a little concerned about the reduction in membership as far as my Party is concerned because I see that either I or somebody from my Party may attend, but not both. As the Deputy Prime Minister would realise, there are sometimes problems in making sure that we are in two places at one time! I am rather disappointed that two members of my Party will not be able to be present so that I can be absent if I need to be. However, that aside, I accept the changes and, rather obviously, the Opposition does not oppose this motion.

Of course, the representation was determined by the Executive, not by the Government. What the right honourable member says about previous Conventions not being successful encourages the Executive to think that they would be more successful if fewer people were there.

—I am glad the right honourable member agrees that something can be done. I am a little disappointed that he does not agree with my proposal. It has been suggested that I will have everybody in Australia at the Convention. I referred to 'a wider representative gathering of the people'. I think that the number could be limited to, say, 100. I am sure that we could have people from all shades of political thought who might be able to agree on a new document for Australia. I hope that it comes about.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELEVISION COVERAGE OF THE BUDGET SPEECH AND REPLY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House authorises-

(1) the Speaker to make arrangements for the preliminary proceedings relating to the introduction of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86, all or part of the second reading speech of the Treasurer, and all or part of the reply to that speech by the Leader of the Opposition to be filmed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation;

(2) the direct, live, telecast of all or part of that film and the accompanying sound of the proceedings by any television station provided that a station telecasts both speeches live and gives approximately equal time to both speeches, and
(3) the use by any television station of any part of the filmed proceedings and accompanying sound in subsequent news, current affairs and documentary programs.

The motion permits the arrangement for the televising of the Budget Speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the reply by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) when the House meets in August. I think this was done for the first time last year. Not only were people able to hear on the news what was contained in the Budget, but also they were able to watch the presentation of it. They appreciated the fact that the Parliament had been opened up even to that limited extent. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation does the filming and makes the film available to other stations so that they may use it. As long as the television stations use the film on the basis of equality between the parties-that is, between the Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition-we give approval.

My personal view is that we could look to extending this into some other debates, if greater interest were shown by the television stations, so that people could see more workings of the Parliament. We have taken a minor step today by doing something with the broadcasting of the proceedings as an experiment in the Budget session. I am pretty sure that it will not be long before we look to experimenting with the televising of at least the major debates of the Parliament so that people throughout Australia can witness those also.

For some time Question Time in the South Australian Parliament has been televised. Therefore, the South Australian people have been able to watch excerpts from Question Time every night. I am not too sure of the guidelines which apply. I do not think that the stations have to be too strict in terms of the way in which they portray the parties. Usually in a news service or a current affairs program the television stations are anxious to see that governments and oppositions are given equal time. Perhaps this will lead to a further discussion of those matters, but at the moment we are merely setting in train the procedures which applied in 1984, which I think everybody would agree, were very successful.

I do believe that there are modern television cameras now which are adequate-
—It will wilt Hodgman's flower.

—If we had to look at the honourable member for Prospect, I could understand our not wanting the bright lights. Considering the shirt that he is wearing, one can understand the reason. At the same time, there is a necessity for us to try to get cameras that can record accurately the proceedings of this place without a level of lighting intensity that is quite unpleasant to sit under. It is that which has concerned me in respect of other chambers that I have seen televised. I know that in the House of Commons-
—What about the Whips? They have to watch the screens all the time.

—I am not worried about the Whips. The Whips look after the rest of us. The honourable member for Griffith probably will be filmed by the television camera when he is running around. For the rest of us there is a problem. One finds that quite often in other chambers the lights seem to be set fairly low and they impede on the vision of speakers. The lighting can be quite unpleasant. I hope that the lighting for whatever cameras are used in the chamber will be kept to a minimum so that it will not become too unpleasant for us all to sit under it. Once that is achieved I think it will be easier for us to achieve more uniform acceptance of the televising of other proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly-again, there is no specific mention of this in the motion-I think there is an advantage if not only the speakers but also others in the chamber are shown on television. I refer to the sartorial splendour of the Australian Labor Party Whip, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), who, I am sure, would benefit considerably if his electors could see the manner in which he is attired. Others in this place may not find that the same benefits ensue. For those of us who are rather concerned that the dress standards in this place have slipped, I think it would be a good idea if a roving camera could pick out some members who come into the chamber in a form of a dress that I frankly do not believe is appropriate to the Parliament. It might be of advantage for their constituents to view the degree of recognition which they give to the chamber. For that reason, I hope there will be an occasional roving camera that might even pick up, for example, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) and show him in all his glory. I do think it is necessary that not just the speakers in their respective places are shown but also other honourable members in the chamber.

Last year's experiment seemed to me to work quite well. Those of us who were present at the Joint Sitting in 1974 found that the level of lighting was fairly intense. I think honourable members will remember that it was necessary for honourable members and honourable senators to speak alongside the Speaker's chair in order that the proceedings could be televised. If there is to be an extension of the televising of parliamentary proceedings, I believe back benchers and others in the chamber need to be able to rise in their places rather than our adopting a procedure which requires everybody to come down to a rostrum. This place is principally a debating forum. I think that it should continue in that role. I do not think that we are here simply to increase our television image and to appear as performers. That does not accommodate the purpose for which we are seated where we are in the chamber at the moment. When we consider extending the televising of proceedings, we need to have in mind that the cameras should be placed to enable them to record the proceedings and the lighting intensity should be such as not to inconvenience honourable members when they are in their normal places in this House. Having said those words, the Opposition agrees with the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young).
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REFURBISHMENT OF COMMONWEALTH CENTRE AND ASSOCIATED MAJOR FITOUT WORKS, MELBOURNE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment of Commonwealth Centre and associated major fitout works, Melbourne.

Melbourne Commonwealth Centre, at the corner of Spring and La Trobe Streets, is on the north-eastern fringe of the central business district. Built in two stages in 1958 and 1966, it consists of two blocks and an adjoining link with basement, lower ground, ground and 11 upper floors. The external appearance of the building and its internal finishes and services were appropriate to the time of construction, but have since deteriorated and are now below current acceptable community standards. In addition, there is a significant amount of sprayed asbestos fire protection material in the building which must be removed for safety reasons.

The Government plans to refurbish the building and its services to bring it to a standard generally equivalent to that of commercial office buildings in Melbourne. It is expected that the work will extend the useful life of the centre by some 20 years. The building will need to be vacated to allow the work to proceed and a number of fitout works in leased premises are consequently required to accommodate displaced staff. The proposed work in the Commonwealth Centre comprises air-conditioning of Block 1; replacement of Block 1 lifts; installation of automatic fire sprinklers and improved lighting throughout; upgrading of services; removal of asbestos base fire protection material and revised internal layouts to suit occupancy changes.

The proposal had originally been planned to be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works over the summer recess at a limit of cost estimate of $16.4m, but this was not possible due to the dissolution of the House last October. The current limit of cost estimate is $18.4m at February 1985 prices, the increase being due solely to movements in costs in the building industry as measured by my Department's building price index. The associated major fitout work at 399 Lonsdale Street is a further $2m. I present plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, on behalf of the Opposition I indicate that we support the motion referring this matter of the Melbourne Commonwealth Centre to the Joint Committee on Public Works. However, there are two comments I want to make in relation to the proposed works. Many who attended the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting would be aware of this building and its general location. I agree with the statement of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) about the appearance of the building. However, what staggers me is that for an expenditure in total of $20.4m the useful life of the Commonwealth Centre will be extended only, in the Minister's own words, 'by some 20 years'.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the Public Works Committee in its deliberations to look at the mathematics of that because, on the face of it the Commonwealth is incurring on behalf of the taxpayers of Australia an expense of $20.4m, which will extend the useful life of a building by some 20 years-in other words, $1m a year. To a layman at least, that figure is rather staggering. I ask that when the Committee looks at the matter there be some cost-benefit analysis of the project. In addition, the Committee might well take evidence from the business community in Melbourne as to the availability of more economical and more suitable accommodation than the accommodation that will be provided by the refurbishing of this building.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can rent a lot of space for $1m a year.

—My word, that is quite correct. It seems absolutely staggering that the Hawke socialist Government is going to slug the taxpayers of Australia $20.4m to extend the use of a building by some 20 years. Mr Deputy Speaker, with your prior experience in this field, I think you will agree that the comment I make is a legitimate one. I think a cost-benefit analysis should be carried out and the alternative of renting accommodation from the private enterprise sector should at least be looked at. With those comments, we support the motion.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMONWEALTH OFFICES SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of new Commonwealth Offices, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

The Joint Committee on Public Works has now reported that there is a need for a new building at Kingsford-Smith Airport, Sydney, to accommodate on-airport Commonwealth functions associated with the operation of the international terminal building and cargo complexes. The proposed multilevel complex will house the Australian Customs Service, Australian Federal Police, and the departments of Foreign Affairs, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Defence, and Local Government and Administrative Services. The proposal is intended to overcome present unsatisfactory aspects of operations and provide appropriate facilities to meet needs to the year 2000.

In recommending construction of the work, the Committee suggested that toilets for the disabled should be provided on each floor and that proposed cafeteria, amenities and recreation areas should be made contiguous. I am advised that the building was planned in accordance with the relevant Australian standard for access by the disabled, with toilets on two levels only. However, the additional cost of facilities on each floor for the disabled is marginal, and I can advise the House that changes will be made to include the additional facilities within the overall estimated project budget. Regarding the cafeteria, amenities and recreation areas, the Committee was advised at the public hearing last year that these will be brought together during the normal refinement of design which follows the PWC consideration phase.

The estimated cost of the proposed work is $7.6m at February 1985 prices. Subject to the approval of the House, it will take some eight months for the project to be advanced to the point of readiness for calling tenders. Construction is of course subject to further approvals in the Budget context. I would like to thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of this proposal. Its report is the first tabled by the new Committee. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the expediency motion just moved by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). We also congratulate the Joint Committee on Public Works for the speed with which it reported back to the Parliament. This matter was before the House comparatively recently. The mathematics in regard to this project are a lot better than they were for the previous project. For an expenditure of $7.6m in this case there will be usage of the building, with its combined facilities, to the year 2000-that is, another 15 years. I must say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the year 2000 is approaching very quickly. The Opposition agrees that it is appropriate to have the relevant functions to which the Minister referred accommodated in the one complex.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the recommendation of the Committee that the provision of toilets, including toilets for the disabled, be in excess of the Australian standard, I can assume only, without having the opportunity of studying the reports and the evidence before the Committee, that there were good and valid reasons for this recommendation. For example, one could well imagine that if a person was disabled and was being subjected to a body search by the Australian Customs Service or was in the custody of the Australian Federal Police, there may be good reasons, from the security point of view, to have that person remain on the same floor rather than have to move to another floor area for the purpose of attending a toilet for the disabled. I say that on the face of it, the Opposition takes the view that the Australian standard should not be exceeded unless there is evidence, and strong evidence, to justify the additional expenditure. In this case the Minister has indicated that the additional cost is minimal. I do not take the matter any further.

I say on behalf of those people who have the opportunity to travel internationally-I certainly do not have that opportunity on many occasions-that these facilities will be at least a step towards bringing Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport into the twentieth century. Even representing a constituency as far away as Tasmania, I still get the occasional letters of outrage from international travellers who have returned to Kingsford-Smith Airport and who have been detained for various purposes relating to Customs or even, in one case, a Federal Police investigation. The facilities currently available are far below the standard suitable for an international airport and for facilities which are located in what is described as Australia's number one airport.

Having said that, I hope the Government will now put its money where its mouth is. Expediency motions normally carry with them an implication that the Government will proceed to provide the funding. I am sure that the Minister has moved this expediency motion before we rise for the winter recess so that he will be able to persuade the Expenditure Review Committee and, indeed, the Cabinet to make an appropriation of funds for the 1985-86 Commonwealth Budget. I hope the Minister does not suffer the acute embarrassment that occurred particularly during the Whitlam years, when expediency motions were passed in relation to very important projects for which funds were not then made available. That can be very embarrassing. I am sure the Minister will have no problem at all in anticipating the response of the Opposition if such an eventuality occurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they broke again?
—It looks as though we are heading for bankruptcy. Hopefully this Minister will be in a position to make an appropriate announcement on 20 August next that the funds have been made available.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 (1985) and Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1985).

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1985) which I have just tabled places before Parliament alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. The proposals abolish the duty on wine produced with added sugar and set out revised definitions and restructured tariff items dealing with brandy, whisky, rum and liquers. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 (1985) which I have also just tabled contains a complementary change to the Customs Tariff Act 1982 in respect of rum. The changes contained in both Tariff Proposals operate on and from 23 May 1985.

The Government has previously announced that amendment to excise and associated legislation dealing with wines and spirits was to be undertaken to reflect, as appropriate, the revised standards for wines and spirits adopted by the National Health and Medical Research Council. The alterations contained in these tariff proposals are part of those measures.

Excise tariff item 16 presently imposes a duty of 49c per litre on wine produced with added sugar. The item was introduced in the 1930s for the purpose of inhibiting the manufacture of wine made by adding sugar before fermentation. All States have since prohibited the practice of adding sugar thus rendering this item redundant.

While the amendments to the excise tariff items dealing with brandy, whisky, rum and liquers and the Customs tariff item for rum change the specification of those products, they do not alter any duty rates prescribed in the relevant provisions. In addition, these Tariff Proposals follow complementary changes to the Spirits Act and the Distillation Act which have already been enacted by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1984. I commend the Proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House at a later hour this day.
Motion (by Mr Cohen) agreed to:

That in accordance with the provisions of section 11 of the Australian National University Act 1946, this House elects Mr P. M. Ruddock and Dr R. E. Klugman to be members of the Council of the Australian National University for a period of three years from 18 August 1985.
Debate resumed from 15 may, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a brief statement about an amendment that the Government will be moving at the Committee stage, to facilitate debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 9 of the Bill provides for annual reviews of fees on which Medicare benefits are based. The purpose of this clause was to accommodate recommendation No. 6 of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. While both the Government and the Australian Medical Association believe that annual reviews of these fees are highly desirable, the AMA has raised a number of further points for negotiation concerning the nature of the review mechanism to be adopted. The Government has therefore decided to give further consideration to the views of the AMA. The Government does not, however, wish such consideration to delay consideration of the remainder of the Bill which gives effect to the major elements of the New South Wales doctors' dispute settlement package. It has, therefore, been decided to withdraw clause 9 at this stage, pending further discussions with the medical profession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's single greatest achievement in its health policy is that it has managed to break more promises in less time than any government before it. It promised to make health care more accessible to all Australians; yet the Medicare queues for public hospital beds are still growing. We have just received information that 24,772 people are waiting for beds in Victoria alone. Compare that with the statement of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) seven months ago that under the previous Government there were waiting lists in Victoria of between 8,000 and 11,000. So the queues in Victoria alone have more than doubled since the introduction of Medicare. Medicare has caused an Australia-wide increase in the number of those on waiting lists.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government promised to make private insurance more affordable; yet the Government has made private insurance more expensive, in direct contradiction to the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The cost of private health insurance is set to increase by at least $52 per annum as a direct result of this Government's action. That will cause a further swing away from the private sector and increase the burden on the public hospital system which already is unable to cope with the demand generated by Medicare. The Government promised to put an end to constant changes in the health insurance policy yet here we are today, with Medicare only 15 months old, debating changes to the health insurance policy. The Government promised to save money in the area of health, yet it has totally failed to contain costs. The cost of Medicare is going through the roof. The additional costs over the original estimates have increased by $430m, that is 24 per cent in just 14 months.

The Government promised to end medifraud. In November 1983 the Minister for Health reported to us in glowing terms how his Department was upgrading the fraud and overservicing detection system to increase its operational efficiency. In fact he doubled its budget from $4m to $8m and doubled its staffing. Then 16 months later he dismantled the system, calling it 'overly bureaucratic and inefficient'. The Government promised to help the chronically ill with prescription charges and to provide free pharmaceuticals for the unemployed. The Government has done neither. The Government promised to maintain the highest standards of health care in this country. The standard of care in public hospitals has deteriorated dramatically. The Minister promised that Medicare is about the less well off in society, yet they are now the ones who are on the end of long queues for hospital beds. The fact is that Medicare is failing on every front.

The Government has engaged in open warfare with the medical profession. Last year the Minister caused the first doctors' strike in Australia's history. There has been a Medicare induced mass exodus of nurses from the overburdened public hospital system. In the last six months 10 per cent of nurses have resigned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. We were promised Medicare; we have got medichaos. For over a year doctors and health professionals across Australia have been calling for fundamental changes to Medicare. Contrary to the Minister's claims that the doctors were interested only in money they have consistently addressed the problems of the erosion of the private health system and the decline in the standard of care in the public sector. The Opposition has consistently called for fundamental changes to Medicare in order to restore the balance between the public and private sectors' involvement in the delivery of health care in this country. The doctors and other health professionals who have been pressing the Government for changes have been expressing similar concerns. Given the extent to which the thrust of the doctors' case was consistent with the Opposition's policy, we supported their arguments, and continue to do so. We do not in any way retreat from our position; nor in fact does the AMA. It also seeks further changes to Medicare. The Minister and the Government stand alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's overt contempt for the medical profession so jaundiced his judgment that he set out like a man possessed to discredit the doctors. He insulted them and he endeavoured to obstruct the conduct of their private practice. He has single-handedly turned the relationship between the Government and the profession into open hostility. In his arrogance he has assumed that he can plan for the nation's health without consulting the major health providers.
In November 1984 the Prime Minister, in his policy speech, said of his Government's health policy:
Medicare has put an end to the constant changes in health insurance policy that have marked the past decade.

Medicare had been in place a whole 10 months when he said that. Now, some six months later, we are considering Medicare mark 2. This Bill not only changes the health insurance policy but also repeals the draconian section 17 provisions which last year caused the first doctors' strike in Australia and which have caused continuous disruption and confrontation in the health system since their introduction.

We all know the history of this Bill. It represents the Government's attempt to implement the so-called seven-point peace plan in the New South Wales doctors' dispute. However, in reality it is no more than a crude political quick-fix which will not fix anything because it does not address the fundamental issues which are at the heart of the declining health system in this country.

The Bill does several things. First of all it repeals the provisions of section 17 inserted by Health Legislation Amendment Act of 1983. These coercive provisions were a blatant attempt by the Minister to control the private practice rights of doctors in public hospitals. The legislation was based on information which was wildly inaccurate but which, because of the Minister's ideological blind spot and his contempt for the medical profession, he believed without question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bullshit.

—That is an interesting interjection and is about the standard I would expect from the Minister. I remind the Minister in particular how wrong the information of the Minister for Health was in justifying his action to control doctors' incomes. He cited the rapid rise in the incidence and cost of pathology and radiology services in public hospitals. He claimed that pathology services had risen by 105 per cent over seven years. In fact, they had risen by 39.7 per cent over nine years. He claimed that radiology services had risen by 55 per cent over seven years. In fact, they fell by 14 per cent. The Minister was proven wrong on every count by the report of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. The Minister believes he is infallible. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we cannot and will not be deterred from the principle of section 17.

After months and months of confrontation and disruption generated by this Government, after causing massive hardship and inconvenience to the people of Australia and after making constant and totally unjustified attacks on the medical profession, the Minister has belatedly agreed to repeal his obnoxious section 17 legislation, pretending that he can now reverse his position because in his petty minded way he believes that the medical profession has behaved itself, and not lived up to the outrageous claims that he made earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pathetic!
—It is indeed pathetic. The Minister stated in March of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: It would not be in the interests of any Government, especially a Labor Government, to introduce guidelines that prompted an exodus of specialists from the public hospital system. We are dependent on these people for the excellence of care that is currently provided in our public hospitals.

That was in March of last year. A more important issue, I put to the Minister, is that it was not in the interests of the people of Australia to introduce legislation which prompted an exodus of specialists from the public hospital system. We can only be thankful that at long last the Minister has discovered that it was not in the Labor Government's interests either.

The balance of the Bill changes the Government's health insurance policy to implement the insurance package proposed in the settlement of the New South Wales doctors' dispute. The amendments do not go far enough to make private insurance more attractive. Contrary to the Prime Minister's pledge to make private insurance more affordable, this package, in addition to the further reduction in the reinsurance subsidy which was part of the mini-Budget, will increase private health insurance premiums by up to $1.15 per week, hardly making private health insurance more affordable. Expansion of the basic cover to include hospital gap insurance, prostheses and surgical implants means that the private health funds will now be faced with much larger payouts, and the Government has provided no relief to the funds when the big payouts come. With the further reduction in the reinsurance fund under the mini-Budget, the only alternative for health funds is to raise premiums.

The increased costs of private insurance will now prove to be prohibitive for many. Now, only those who are able to afford the higher premiums-in addition, of course, to the still compulsory one per cent Medicare levy-will be able to insure privately. In addition, the health funds will now be forced to process numerous $4 and $5 claims for gap insurance, but they are not permitted to process Medicare claims. Their administrative costs will increase, thus forcing up premiums even further. Meanwhile, consumers have the inconvenience and inefficiency of the dual administration of one claim. So much for the simplicity and efficiency of Medicare!

I understand that the health funds have offered to handle Medicare claims for the Government at the same cost as the Government is now paying to its own public servants. In other words, the private insurers have offered one stop shopping at no extra cost to the Government. The Opposition has consistently maintained that health insurers ought to be allowed to handle Medicare claims. The proposal of the private insurers would extend Medicare agencies to the bush, it would provide one stop shopping and it would save the dual administration of claims. As the funds have offered to handle the claims for the same amount as it is currently costing the Government, there is no reason why the health funds should not be allowed to handle the claims. The Government stands condemned for its failure to accept readily the health insurers' offer.

I turn now to the extensions to the basic table. Gap insurance is only to be allowed for treatment within a hospital. This means increased incentives for consumers and doctors inappropriately to utilise hospital facilities. People will now opt for procedures to be done in hospital because insurance will pay, whereas some procedures could be performed out of hospital. This will increase health costs and pressure on hospitals. By limiting gap insurance to treatment within a hospital, doctors such as general practitioners who carry out a small proportion of their work within a hospital are disadvantaged compared with specialists who perform most of their work within hospitals.

In his second reading speech the Minister made some very peculiar and puzzling statements regarding gap insurance. He seems to suggest that gap insurance for medical services outside a hospital would induce doctors to charge above the schedule fee, while gap insurance for treatment in hospital would somehow not have that effect. This artificial distinction between the way doctors charge in or out of hospital begs the question anyway, because the gap insurance is limited to covering the difference between the Medicare benefit and the schedule fee. The Opposition is committed to allowing gap insurance for both medical and hospital treatment.

Permitting health funds to offer front-end deductible tables is hardly likely to result in a stampede to the private sector. Those who are likely to be attracted to that option will be the young and the healthy who were previously covered by the commercial insurers at lower rates, and others who are already insured, but who cannot afford to take the risk of the first dollars payout. The poor, the elderly, and the chronically ill, who are most likely to experience frequent illness, simply cannot afford such insurance.

Clause 13 of the Bill would permit payment of benefits for single day treatment in a private hospital or a 'day hospital facility'. The definition of a day hospital facility is not clearly spelt out in the Bill, but leaves the regulation to the States, or in the absence of State regulation, regulations will be prescribed.
I call the Minister's attention to the language in clause 13 which seeks to add paragraph (db) to section 4 of the National Health Act. Proposed paragraph (db) states:
In respect of a day on which a person occupies a bed in hospital, for a period that does not include part of an overnight stay--

Use of the phrase 'occupies a bed' would appear to limit private hospitals wishing to establish day surgery units to do so only within the number of their currently approved hospital beds. Section 24 (5) (a) of the Health Insurance Act states that the number of beds at the hospital will not at any time exceed such number as is determined by the Minister to be the number of approved beds in relation to the hospital.

Private hospitals, therefore, will be able to establish such a day surgery unit only if they are prepared to reduce in-patient beds, or by establishing a separate premise registered under State law or as prescribed. This limitation on the development of day hospital facilities could be corrected by changing the language to read 'in respect of a day on which a person received treatment'. I urge the Minister to re-consider the implications of the present wording which could unduly stifle the development of single day beds.

This matter was only recently drawn to my attention. The fact that the legislation is faulty is a matter of concern to the Opposition. I ask the Minister to clarify the matter when he is winding up the debate. If he does not give the appropriate undertakings as to the operation of the section we will have to review our position in the Senate. I am informed that the Australian Democrats share our concern about this section. I therefore repeat my request to the Minister to clarify his intention in that regard.

The basic table is expanded to include the provision of prostheses and surgical implants. These are presently provided by the Government. Yet, under this legislation the cost will be borne by private health insurers. The list of items to be covered under this provision has not yet been drawn up, but will be decided by the Minister. Until it is decided what items are included, it is not possible to know what savings the Government can expect, nor how much additional cost will now be borne by the private funds.

Clause 15 of the Bill requires all health insurers to comply with the requirements of the National Health Act because, according to the Minister, the price of community rating has been 'steadily eroded by cheaper ''risk-rated'' insurance being offered to good risks by insurers not registered under the National Health Act'. This is a typical example of the ham-fisted approach this Government has to health insurance. The Opposition certainly accepts that all insurers, including general insurers, ought to be obliged to abide by the same rules, that is, they should operate under the same Acts of parliament. However, we would approach this matter differently. Whilst requiring insurers to abide by the same rules, we would at the same time move to limit government regulation under the Health Act to the minimum necessary to ensure fair competition and community rating. Instead of increasing regulation, the Opposition will be seeking ways in which to free up the rules and regulations restricting health funds to encourage insurers to extend their range of tables and include optional packages that could inhibit the unnecessary use of services and reduce administrative costs, while at the same time reducing insurance premiums.

I wish to refer to the variation in waiting periods. A number of changes are made to the waiting period for basic table benefits for new fund members. A few former Medibank Private members who are on long waiting lists-especially for prostheses-may return to Medibank Private for private insurance, but this move is unlikely to have major impact on queues.

Many parts of the settlement package require action by the New South Wales Government. In the past, despite undertakings, that State Government has failed to meet its commitments. We shall have to wait and see whether on this occasion it will in fact implement the package or whether it will continue on its destructive course of removing the private hospital sector from New South Wales.

For over a year, health professionals around Australia have signalled that fundamental changes to Medicare are necessary. Similarly, the Opposition has consistently called for such changes to Medicare. But the Government has steadfastly refused voluntarily to review Medicare, despite the fact that the situation for most Australians has become decidedly worse under Medicare.

Doctors in New South Wales have had to drag the Government screaming to the negotiating table to get these changes introduced. Any Minister worth his salt would have realised that Medicare is not working and that changes were required-but not this Minister. The Government is obviously more concerned about ensuring the conversion of health care to nationalised medicine than providing the means whereby those seeking quality medical treatment get it without undue delay.

The Minister for Health has said that 'this scheme is about the less well off in our society', but the less well off in society-those who are most dependent upon the system-are the very people who are hardest hit by the failure of Medicare and they are no better off as a result of these changes. If they could not afford private insurance before, they certainly will not be able to afford it now.

We would, of course, make private insurance more affordable because we are committed to allowing people to opt out of paying the levy if they take sufficient private cover. In this way we would restore choice and stop people from having to pay twice. The Prime Minister promised to make private health insurance more affordable. Instead, he has made it more expensive. The fact is that only those who are able to afford the higher premiums, in addition to the still-compulsory one per cent levy, will be able to insure privately. With private insurance becoming more expensive, even more people will leave the funds, the reliance on Medicare will grow and the erosion of the private sector will continue. The public hospitals already are unable to cope with the demands of Medicare, and as the queues continue to grow, the poor, the elderly and the disadvantaged will go on bearing the brunt of this Government's health policy. So much for the Government's promises.

Finally, I note that the Government has, at the last minute, withdrawn clause 9 of the Bill which sought to establish a Medicare schedule fees tribunal to provide for automatic annual review of fees in the Medicare schedule. This is yet another example of the hopeless administration of the portfolio by this Minister. Not only had he failed to consult with the AMA on this proposal but also he relied on a recommendation of the Penington report which this Bill, by seeking to remove section 18, makes irrelevant. The Minister has yet again been forced to back down. Medicare is not working and these changes do not go far enough. Therefore I move the following amendment to the second reading motion:
That all words after ''That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
''whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that-
(a) the long and unnecessary delay by the Government in implementing the changes to Medicare embodied in the Bill has caused intolerable pain and suffering, and
(b) the amendments fall short of the urgent and fundamental changes required to Medicare to restore a high standard balanced private and public health delivery system''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: — Once again we have heard the Opposition bleating concerns about the poor, the elderly and the less well off. It seems that not long ago those people had very little access to private health insurance and, except for the very wealthy, this Government provides a much cheaper possibility. Honourable members opposite, even within their election policy, are committed to a universal scheme, which is the basic premise of the Medicare legislation and something which under their administration was not available to the people of this country. Opposition members talk about cost increases. One finds it very difficult to understand how they can do so when one remembers that the cost of pharmaceuticals increased by 167 per cent in the years of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the greatest myth that Opposition members talk about is gap insurance and the wonderful possibilities that that makes available for the people of this country. The report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, and the Australian Medical Association concurred on this point, and suggested that gap insurance was merely an inducement for doctors to overcharge. It is impossible to make a rational and cogent case for the implementation of gap insurance. It is interesting to look at the statistics. In the first year of Medicare the average Australian paid $16.15 out of his pocket for extras. Of that, $11.76 represented gaps and the other $4.39 represented the excess over the scheduled fee when doctors chose to charge an excess. It is estimated that the introduction of gap insurance would cost the average family insurer $3.00 a week, or $150 a year. Some 84 per cent of the population paid $20 or less in gap insurance last year and 42 per cent paid nothing. The only place where people are likely to be hurt through not having gap insurance is where a considerable number of procedures may be performed in a hospital over a short period. This legislation provides for the implementation of gap insurance within the private insurance sector and covers that possibility. Gap insurance is really an unnecessary and added burden and a costly waste of money for the vast majority of families. Indeed, the premiums very often amount to much more than the benefits.

The amendments proposed within this package of legislation, which goes to the solution of the doctors dispute in New South Wales, are something that the Government has worked upon over a period. It was always indicated, and it was always our belief, that the implementation of Medicare would have an impact and that it would be necessary for us to respond accordingly. Unfortunately, a small minority of surgeons in New South Wales-procedural specialists-chose to take a very vitriolic approach, and their action has caused a great deal of suffering and pain to people in New South Wales. The Government resolved to negotiate and consult with the medical profession and I am sure that, but for the hysterical and impractical actions of those people, this dispute would have been resolved long ago.

Fortunately, the AMA, the representative body of the doctors in this country, a group which represents over 30,000 practitioners and certainly is not the ideological bed partner of the Australian Labor Party, understood the right of the Government to implement the mandate it received at two elections. We saw a very vitriolic set of circumstances come about within the profession. It ranged to the point of personal abuse of the President of the AMA, Dr Thompson. The position of the profession on this issue, which was supposed to be one of great principle, certainly deteriorated in many ways. The President, Dr Thompson, was quoted in last Sunday's Sun-Herald as stating:
My profession is supposed to be a highly educated one. And this dispute was not supposed to be a personal matter, but rather involving concerns of great principle.

Unfortunately, this dispute deteriorated to the degree where this was not the case. Where did members of the Opposition stand in all this? They are the people who defended the militant and recalcitrant action of the Queensland Government with regard to the power workers who struck in Queensland. They are the people who said that essential services need to be protected. Yet in relation to this dispute, true to form, they did a complete turnaround and supported a wealthy group which participated in a strike that was really not a strike because the doctors were still able to accrue benefits, through Medicare, for their private practice. The Opposition acted in folly in supporting the militant doctors. Whom did it support? Dr Thompson said last Wednesday:

I am speaking for 30,000 doctors. My opponents, (the surgeons' leaders) are speaking for a few hundred. But they have grabbed the headlines by being sensational, making wild allegations and saying unsubstantiated things. Unfortunately, it's good media stuff and so they've hogged the limelight. But the public are now seeing them for what they are.

The procedural specialists over a period have alienated themselves from the public. The Government and the AMA have been able to negotiate a settlement. Indeed, a national plebiscite in the AMA showed that 75 per cent or more of doctors belonging to that organisation favoured a return to normal services.

This legislation incorporates many of the recommendations of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. There were messages in that report for both sides of this Parliament. The legislative package contains a number of elements and, unfortunately, I may not be able to cover them all in the time available. Perhaps the principal revenue consideration is the provision over three years of $150m to the public hospitals in this country. If that was the intention of the procedural specialists when they embarked on this dispute, I would applaud them. Certainly, that is something this Government had always looked at doing. During the time of the Fraser Government there was a significant capital and equipment rundown, and the cupboard was bare when we came to office.
