It has always been our intention that the public hospital sector should be supported in this way. It is worth while noting that the staff of the teaching hospitals worked tirelessly to keep the system working during this dispute. I think this element of the package is very worth while and will certainly benefit the public of this country.

Perhaps the most symbolic element of the dispute concerned section 17 of the principal Act. This has become a very much misinterpreted symbol and a weapon of the militant doctors, who used it on occasions to whip up hysteria. It required that approved agreements should exist for private practice within public hospitals. Indeed, this did not represent a problem in the vast majority of States. In my home State of Western Australia such agreements were already in place, but there were particular difficulties in New South Wales. The provision of this aspect of section 17 led to the schedule fee compliance for pathology and radiological services. It has been shown over the time of the Medicare legislation to have been largely complied with. As such, the Government is satisfied with the situation and is pleased to be able to revoke that section.

I suppose that the remuneration aspect is at the heart of this dispute, and I think there was a legitimate concern as to the position with regard to remuneration. Within the package we are now providing for fee-for-service for public patients in all but teaching hospitals, and indeed, modified scales according to the staffing levels in those hospitals will be available in the metropolitan and country areas. Of course, it was always thought to be necessary that, with the change in the private to public mix, sessional fees and the numbers of sessions available for practice in public hospitals would have to change. It was always intended, and again in Western Australia negotiations were underway with regard to this. What has happened is that we have seen the funding base for visiting medical officers in New South Wales brought on to a par with that which exists in other States. Therefore, this legislation puts right the difficulties that existed in that regard.

There are other aspects of the legislation which improve the attractiveness and flexibility of private health insurance, and in many ways this will have an effect on and go to the concerns which have been expressed during this dispute. The growth in commercial funds was threatening the community rating principle to which we are committed. Indeed, the legislation will make changes in that respect, which will make the commercial funds risk-rated under the same conditions as the registered funds. The hand-over of regulatory control over private hospitals is another element of this package which is under consideration. Indeed, the principles and guidelines of that categorisation are being negotiated. This dispute would still be continuing if the confrontationist approach of the procedural specialists had been allowed to continue. It was resolved by negotiation. I commend the Minister for Health for his work and I commend this Bill to the House. I hope that we will be able to focus our attention in the health area on other areas that are deserving of concern, rather than this one which seems to have consumed our time over so long a period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two small points on insurance on which I would like the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to respond in his reply. First, it is not clear what will happen with ancillary benefits. The Department of Health has not taken a very close interest in ancillary benefits, such as for chiropractic or dental treatment, because they have not formed part of the community rating system. I would like to know, in respect of the transfer of business from the commercial insurers under the Act, how the ancillary benefits will be dealt with. My second query relates to companies which are currently insuring for their employees with commercial insurers and which may not wish to continue those arrangements under the new regulated system. Presumably, they would be able to cover their employees' health costs as an accepted cost without coming under the Act, and would be able to opt out in that sense by carrying the insurance themselves. I assume that that would not be prevented under the terms of this legislation, but I would welcome clarification of that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Mostly tonight I want to say something about this Health Legislation Amendment Bill in broad prospective. In September 1983 the Minister brought down unworkable, unfair legislation. He made a major political and administrative mistake. Instead of admitting it, he has, with the assistance of the New South Wales Government, tried to bully his way through and to tough it out. This legislation today represents the admission of error, but it comes 20 months after the initial misguided act-20 months of anguish for patients, 20 months of damage to the medical profession, and 20 months of decline in our once excellent health system; a decline that will take years to reverse. If this legislation is necessary, then it was necessary from the beginning. The fact of this legislation proves that the Minister and the Government unnecessarily and wantonly threw our health system into dangerous turmoil for no good reason. We told them at the time, but they would not listen. They proceeded to make the people suffer.

The Minister began by trying to avoid the clear lessons of history, quite apart from the requirements of fairness, common sense and sound administrative practice. At the beginning he appeared deliberately to mislead the medical profession as to his intentions, thereby activating its instinct for survival. As Dr Sidney Sax points out in his recent book A Strife of Interest:

. . . during his campaign in connection with the unsuccessful 1944 referendum on federal powers, Chifley stated that a full-time salaried medical service would be established. Ever since-no matter what has been said to the contrary-any Labor policy for the expansion of government activity in health care services has been criticised and described as the 'thin end of the wedge' which would lead to a socialist system of medical care.

Thus, Sax described the views of the doctors. The present Minister for Health explained Labor's now more sophisticated Fabian approach of gradualism in a speech when he was still shadow Minister in 1982. I quote:

The Party has put aside any primary emphasis on salaried or capitation systems in pragmatic recognition of the prevailing culture and attitudes in this society and in its efforts to secure widespread community support for its programme. Private fee-for-service medicine is deeply entrenched in Australian society, strongly defended by the medical profession, and favourably evaluated by the population at large. This is a fact of life and whatever changes may be desirable in that system will have to take place gradually and incrementally.

Those were the words of the honourable member Bonython (Dr Blewett) when he was shadow Minister for Health. When in September 1983 the Minister armed himself with Federal powers over doctors' contracts in public hospitals under the now notorious section 17 of the Health Insurance Act, which, incidentally, this Bill now removes, visiting medical officers, led by the procedural specialists, saw his action as a first step towards fully-salaried medical practice in the public hospitals, replacing the fee-for-service system then applying to privately insured patients in these hospitals. The Minister claimed that his intention was merely to curb the excessive increases in diagnostic costs, such as pathology and radiology. However, the legislation covered all services and, to the Minister's discomfiture, it was subsequently found that he had already signalled his intention of extending the controls. In a speech to the Doctors Reform Society in August 1983 he said:

It was agreed at the July Health Ministers' Conference that attention to these problems should be initially directed to the area of diagnostic services, with the intention to move more broadly in due course.

Thus, the Minister's claim to be concerned only about diagnostic services was quite misleading and, taken with his 1982 remarks, removed any basis of trust that might have been built up between the Government and the medical profession.

The Minister's standing was further eroded by the publication of the Penington report in September 1984. Professor David Penington led a Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals, set up by the Federal Government following the doctors strike early in 1984. Penington found that, contrary to the Minister's claims at the time of the section 17 debate, diagnostic services in public hospitals had not grown at an alarming rate. Embarrassingly, Penington proved that figures submitted by the Department of Health in support of the Minister's case were false. The Department had claimed increases of 105 per cent in pathology and 55 per cent in radiology over a seven-year period. Penington found that pathology utilisation had risen by only 40 per cent over nine years, and that radiology had actually declined by 14 per cent over the same period. Further, because of improved technology, pathology costs had increased by only 13 per cent in nine years. So it was not 105 per cent and 55 per cent increase respectively; it was actually an increase of 13 per cent on pathology and a decline of 14 per cent in radiology over an even longer period.

The dimensions of this scandal were hidden from the general public by tabling the report with a mass of other material on the last parliamentary sitting day before the last election, and allowing only 15 minutes for debate. However, the medical profession read the report in detail and was outraged. It also found it difficult to understand why, given this and other findings, refuting the Minister's case, Penington recommended the retention of section 17 of the Act. I am pleased that the Minister has now rejected that recom- mendation.

In New South Wales, because of its historically greater proportion of private medical practice within the public hospital system, and also because of the doctor-baiting inclinations of former State Health Minister, Mr Laurie Brereton, matters came to a head more rapidly than in other States. The likely end result of the Federal Minister's salami tactics, cutting up private practice slice by slice, could be glimpsed from a perspective much closer to the blade and, appropriately, those closest to the cutting edge were the surgeons. Fortuitously they were led by two men of courage and determination, Dr Bruce Shepherd and Dr Michael Aroney. At the public hospital work face, surgeons found that the proportion of their patients paying fees via insurance declined substantially following the introduction of Medicare. They happily treated 30 per cent of patients either free or for nominal sessional fees, relying for their income on the remaining 70 per cent of insured patients to pay the fee for the individual services rendered. Under Medicare the Minister promised free public hospital treatment to everyone, regardless of his or her means, but he had overlooked the question of who was to provide the treatment and on what basis. Eventually it became clear that the doctors were to be forced to provide their services on the same basis as they did to pensioners. Thus, as more and more people dropped private health cover to take up the Minister's generous offer, the number of non-paying patients on the surgeons' lists increased.

Action by the New South Wales Labor Government further expanded the lists of non-payers. Brereton's admissions clerks were instructed to carry out a form of body snatching. Unless insured patients specifically requested the services of a particular doctor-that is difficult if one is admitted, for example, unconscious-they were to be admitted as hospital, not private, patients and were thereby added to the free list. This astonishing provocation by Brereton's machine came on top of draconian State legislation prohibiting doctors from even discussing insurance matters with their patients.

Almost overnight procedural specialists found that fewer than half their patients paid fees and their incomes dropped by 30 to 40 per cent. More importantly for their future and for the quality of medicine in the public hospitals, they could see the gradual extension of this process to the point where, instead of acting as independent professional entrepreneurs serving individual patients, they would be fully employed by the Government within an hierarchical structure. Professional and financial incentives would be diminished and the frustrations so clearly evident in the British National Health Service would push our excellent public hospital system towards mediocrity.

Given the Minister's professed commitment to gradualism, his and Brereton's thuggery in New South Wales was a major tactical blunder. Comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) comparing the New South Wales specialists with the Builders Labourers Federation of Australia none of whose members, to my knowledge, has been forced to take a 40 per cent pay cut to provide free housing for anyone-served merely to reinforce the doctors' opposition to the two governments. Mr Wran's subsequent attempts at bullying, the seven-year exclusion of doctors who resigned and the attempted recruitment of overseas doctors further cemented resistance. The doctors' case, advanced by the exposure of the facts about what had been done to them by this Minister and this Government, was strengthened by their decision to resign rather than go on strike.

As this Bill has been brought in 20 months too late, what is the balance sheet? The balance sheet is this: The Medicare scheme is still unworkable. Free hospital care will not work. It will starve the system of essential private funds. Bulk billing for non-welfare patients cannot be sustained without corrupting both patients and the profession. These amendments do some necessary but not sufficient things. They have been extracted under duress from two bullying, incompetent governments by the actions of Dr Shepherd and Dr Aroney. Without the determination and courage of these much maligned people and their colleagues there would have been no 75 per cent vote from the profession urging the specialists to resume their public hospital work.

The limitations of umbrella bodies such as the Australian Medical Association have been demonstrated once again. It is a pity that acrimony developed between the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Lindsay Thompson, and the procedural specialists. Dr Thompson is a fine, decent and intelligent man who has been given an almost impossible job. I applaud his work. I am very unhappy that it ended in acrimony between him and the procedural specialists. I acknowledge the extent of his work and his sincere determination to try to prevent the profession from being dragged down into the gutter with this Government. However, because of the diverse constituency of the AMA it cannot prevent outrageous things being done to selected, targeted segments of the profession. It took the steel of Shepherd and Aroney to force this Government to this partial admission of its outrageous behaviour. Let us hope that the professionals in the system-doctors, nurses and others-will fight grimly to maintain standards, despite the system, until a coalition government can come in and clean up the mess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have heard from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) in his role as an apologist for people earning hundreds of thousands of dollars a year. As we listen to the Opposition members we hear words such as 'arrogance', 'believes he is infallible' and 'outrageous claims' when they are talking about the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). These ring strange to me as one who has known the Minister for six years. I think better words to use are 'attentive', 'considerate yet firm', 'careful and factual in his claims'. and 'one who is always prepared to talk and negotiate with the industries with which he deals'. I believe that the Opposition is continuing in its role as an opposition with its attempt to use personal abuse where logical argument fails. This is not Medicare mark 2. It is Medicare full stop.

SPEECH.PARA: As with any new system, the basics can be amended by a government which, unlike the Fraser Government, is not afraid to admit the need for improvements. The Opposition wants Medicare mark 2. It wants a return to the outrageous systems of the Fraser years, to the various proposals born in panic and too expensive for ordinary people. Its opponents fail to mention that millions of Australians would have no health cover at all without Medicare. Honourable members opposite should talk to breadwinners on below average and average incomes and they will see who made the major political and administrative mistakes. It was the Fraser Government.

I do not propose to deal with the various amendments which have been mentioned, as they have been outlined fully by the Minister and the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who spoke previously. I put it to the House that the changes put forward in this legislation are all sensible and rational changes to health insurance policy. The basic principles of the Medicare program have not been altered. All Australians are still entitled to the 85 per cent Medicare benefit for private medical services and to free accommodation and treatment in public hospitals. However, the Medicare arrangements with the States will result in extra spending of about $16m a year in New South Wales for increased remuneration to visiting medical officers and $150m, which is to be spent over three years, for upgrading the facilities and equipment in Australian teaching hospitals. With funding for capital works limited in a tight economy, the Hawke Labor Government is still committed unshakably to upgrading our public hospitals. The Government is moving amendments to assist in resolving a dispute which has become stalemated at great and often tragic human costs to patients in New South Wales.

In line with the recommendations of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals, negotiations are being conducted with the States to amend the Medicare agreements so that privately insured patients are automatically classified as private patients unless they specifically opt to be Medicare patients. This will reduce administrative problems in hospitals. One of the difficulties in dealing with the doctors has been that the Australian Medical Association has been hampered in negotiations by the existence of an elite group of procedural specialists who have the political aim of destroying Medicare and the economic aim of holding on to their high income, their macadamia nut plantations and their aeroplanes. For example, acceptance of the demands presented to the Commonwealth Government would have completely changed the way Medicare functions and would have destroyed Medicare. This Government was elected at two elections on its promise of a universal health scheme-Medicare. I believe that we have to stick to that principle: The people expect us to stick to that principle.

The medical practitioners reacted not only to the proposals of this Government but also to a proposal of a conference of Health Ministers in 1983 which provided that Medicare benefits would be payable for services to private patients in public hospitals only if certain conditions were met. How did some medical practitioners react to this agreement of State and Federal Ministers? Some, but not all, reacted through the strike weapon. People wanting treatment came up against obstruction, vague directions and refusal of treatment on some occasions. They found their allies in the anti-strike coalition parties in this Parliament-the people who have supported these few recalcitrant procedural specialists. In contrast, this Government pursued the policy of consultation and consensus with the medical profession, just as it did with the trade unions in Queensland. It is evident that the Queensland Government has failed in its negotiations with the unions by not pursuing that policy of consensus.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During yesterday's debate on the National Health Amendment Bill 1985 the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), the shadow Minister for Health, and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) called into question the credibility of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) on a number of counts, and did so very well. I want to take up tonight a few points that also concern the Minister's statements both since he has been Minister for Health and when he was shadow Minister for Health over the past several years, because his words came back to haunt him in yesterday's debate, and they have come back to haunt him in tonight's debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a case of the Government having broken promises, promises and indeed more promises. If we look at the record of the Government, particularly over the past few months since its re-election on 1 December, we find that it is a government riddled with factionalism, a government that lacks direction and cohesiveness and a government that has broken promises on numerous occasions. Indeed, one could say that it is a government akin to a rudderless ship. The Minister has stated on previous occasions-indeed, he so stated in a speech on 6 September 1983-that Medicare is very similar to Medibank, which was introduced by his colleagues during the term of the Whitlam Government between 1972 and 1975 when the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden) was Minister for Social Security. I want to quote one or two passages from the Minister's speech on 6 September when he introduced the Medicare legislation. I think his second reading speech lasted about one hour. I will quote what he said about Medicare:

Medicare will be substantially self-funding through the one per cent levy and a re-arrangement of existing health insurance subsidies, whereas Medibank placed a considerable strain on Consolidated Revenue.

The honourable member for Barker pointed out to the House earlier, very effectively I believe, that the estimates made by the Minister, and no doubt prepared by his Department, have proved to be very wrong and that we have seen a massive increase in the cost of Medicare. This side of the House, the Opposition Liberal and National parties, warned when in opposition, when again in government between 1975 and 1983 and in opposition again now that any basically free service will be abused and the costs will go through the roof. That is exactly what has happened. We advocate in our policy that there be an option for people to be part of a government scheme or to have the freedom to opt out of that into private insurance. I hope that eventually we will see people looking after themselves instead of being looked after wholly by government.

The predictions of the Opposition parties have come true: The costs of Medicare have burgeoned. I ask the Minister whether he will give the House and the nation some explanation as to why the costs have burgeoned to the extent they have. Apart from in that speech of 6 September which I just quoted, the Minister maintained in his second reading speech last week the position that Medicare would be substantially funded by the one per cent levy. I quote from that speech of last week:
The additional cost of the Medicare program remains substantially funded through the fair, income-related levy.

As far as I am concerned, that statement and his statement of 6 September 1983 are misleading. That is not the situation at all. If one looks at the 1984-85 Budget Papers one will see that the levy is expected to raise $1.191m or 58 per cent of the estimated $2,050m expenditure on Medicare this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much will it be next year?

—The honourable member for McPherson, who represents the Gold Coast area, asks how much it will cost next year. I think the Minister ought to address that question during his summing up of the debate in a few moments because it is a serious situation when the Minister in his second reading speech when introducing the original legislation can make the blunt statement, which he repeated in similar terms in his second reading speech last week when bringing these amendments before the Parliament, that the levy will substantially fund Medicare. It is not substantially funding the expenditure in Medicare. There is a massive shortfall of $859m or 42 per cent of the estimate. This is unacceptable. This is not in keeping with the Minister's statements or, to put it bluntly, this is a broken promise.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a deception of the Australian people. This is a scheme which is and will remain a financial millstone around the neck of the Hawke Labor Government. If the levy is to substantially self-fund Medicare it ought to be increased to somewhere around 1 1/2 per cent. Now hundreds of millions of dollars are being taken out of Consolidated Revenue to fund Medicare to make up that shortfall as a result of the one per cent levy being inadequate. The Government's estimates were grossly in error. The one per cent levy did not cover the cost of Medicare initially, it is not covering it now and it certainly will not cover it in future. I repeat: I hope that the Minister will answer that question because I think the public of this nation deserve to know why he has not kept that promise and that figure is so deficient as to cause a shortfall of $859m or 42 per cent of the estimates in this financial year.

I have a time constraint on me tonight, but I want to make one or two other points relative to this scheme. I will not go into a lot of the detail that the honourable member for Barker so adequately handled, but I ask the Minister to explain why he has broken a further promise relative to gap insurance. He was quite adamant on 6 September 1983 when he talked about the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. Earlier in this debate the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) also mentioned the Jamison report and the report of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals, as did the Minister in his second reading speech last week. Firstly, let me see what he said on 6 September 1983. He talked about gap insurance not being of any real benefit to the public. He said:

This would be in addition to the insurance premium for the gap cover, so overall most people are financially better off without gap insurance. It is only doctors who would be financially better off if gap insurance were permitted. For all of these reasons the Government will not allow gap insurance to be offered. In this way doctors will be encouraged to limit their charge to a level around the schedule fee and this will be important in containing Australia's overall health bill.

That was quite a positive and definite statement by the Minister that there would be no gap insurance. Yet we find that gap insurance is being introduced at least in part. I ask the Minister: Why would he want to stop there? If it is not good enough to have it in general, why have it in part? In his speech last week on 15 May he said:

Both of the recent substantial examinations of aspects of health care in Australia-the Jamison and Penington reports-have been clear in their opposition to the introduction of a general form of 'gap' insurance. It is viewed as undesirable because of its effect both on the utilisation of medical services and on doctors' billing practices.
The Minister had the gall to go on to say:
The authors of the reports would no doubt be less opposed to 'gap' insurance if it could be guaranteed that doctors would abide by a set level of fairly arbitrated fees.

I ask the Minister: On what basis would he make the assumption that the authors of those reports would adopt a different attitude? I refer to his impertinence, because that is what it is, in making that sort of assumption. On what grounds would he make that statement? A little later he went on to say:

For these reasons this legislation only permits 'gap' insurance for medical services provided in hospitals, and the Government would strongly oppose its further extension to cover all medical services.

I ask: Why? Why not have the extension of gap insurance to cover all the differences between the amount of the Commonwealth benefit, and the fee which the doctors charge? It is a pretty fair question. The Minister has seen fit in one instance to allow it, and then he has the impertinence to make the statement that the authors of these reports would have had a different attitude. I do not know on what basis he makes that assumption.

I have run out of time. I made an agreement with the Deputy Government Whip to speak for only 10 minutes. I repeat that there are questions which I believe the Minister ought to answer. Obviously the Government has had a change of heart in some respects. Its attempts to defeat the doctors in New South Wales, I think, have failed. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), as a former Health Minister, has handled that subject very fully. I ask the Minister to give consideration to the introduction of gap insurance across the board. I sincerely hope that he will give people more freedom of choice. I commend him on his move in the community rating area to ensure that the ordinary insurance schemes which cover the well Australians-they are usually young Australians-are required to be registered under private health insurance organisations. I also congratulate the Minister on his move in the area of front end deductibles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner and in the last few minutes we have had a debate which has been characterised by a series of what can only be described as rather mindless demagogic comments with very little reference to the specific Bill at all. I call much of this demagogy mindless because it simply reveals that the Opposition has learnt nothing from its period in government. Firstly, it has not understood the type of system it is having to deal with-I will give some instances of that in a moment-and, secondly, it is simply ideologically blinkered, partly, I think, by its commitment to those vested interests in the health field who do well out of it but also because it has a set of preconceived notions that it is not prepared to apply to the present situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the case of what can only be described as one of the most contemptible industrial disputes that has ever disfigured this country-that is, the activity of the militant surgeons in New South Wales. The proposals that are embodied in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill have been on the table for months and have been rejected by the intransigent leadership of that group. They have never agreed to the package that was offered. Indeed, what finally happened was that there was a resolution between, on the one side, the Australian Medical Association and the Government against this minority group backed by the Opposition. One of the most hypocritical things that I have ever had to listen to in this Parliament occurred in the speech by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) where he applauded the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Lindsay Thompson. Yet the honourable member for Mackellar did everything within his power to disrupt and undermine the compromise that had been made and backed by the great bulk of the medical profession to settle the dispute in New South Wales. He aligned himself then, as he aligned himself tonight, with the likes of Dr Shepherd and Dr Aroney. Let me say that I think the distinction between the Government and the AMA on one side and the militant surgeons and the Opposition on the other is that we were prepared to search for a real compromise on this issue because we did not take the position occupied and explicitly stated by Dr Shepherd that he was willing to see people die in order that he could win his war against the Government. That is on the record.

Of course, one great benefit has come out of the debate tonight and that will be invaluable when we next go to the people. This Opposition is prepared to align itself with the likes of Dr Aroney and Dr Shepherd against not only the Government but also the AMA and the bulk of the medical profession. I make one further point: In early July we will be publishing the annual earnings of the medical profession from Medicare by category and by State. We will see how false is the allegation which was made again tonight that somehow surgeons in New South Wales have lost between 30 and 40 per cent of their income as a result of Medicare. The figures and the statistics will be there for the people to make the judgment.

The second issue illustrates what I describe as the kind of mindlessness of the Opposition, although in this case it is more illogical. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) said that I, the Minister, was proven wrong on every count by the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals in relation to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. He did not bother to go on to explain to the public why practically all of the major proposals by the Government were either accepted by Penington as desirable or proposed, in a somewhat modified form, to the medical profession. I believe there is a need for the Opposition to come to grips with the problem of accountability in the public hospital system. In an effort to solve the dispute we have taken the action of removing section 17. The reasons for that are partly that on increasing evidence which we have had from the hospital system about the charging practice of doctors, we are more confident that that legislation is not required. Secondly, the medical profession itself has indicated a willingness in the public hospital system to observe, as far as possible, the schedule fee arrangement. There is a lot of evidence from the information we are now getting that that has been observed in the hospital system. But again, let me say, even after the section 17 imbroglio, that I think there will be a long term gain to health in this country. I believe that because of this debate, the quality of the Penington report and the attitude of most State governments to that report, many of those recommendations which are not implemented in this measure will be implemented over time by responsible State governments concerned with effective accountability of their hospital systems.
Let me come to the question of waiting lists which is no doubt the latest tactic to be used by the Opposition in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only since Medicare came in.

—Only since Medicare came in. If the honourable member for Barker had done his homework he would have realised that in the public hospital system for over 10 years there has been a mounting problem with waiting lists, exacerbated above all by the reduction of funds by the previous Government. That major reduction in 1981 contributed to an escalation of these waiting list problems. I am glad that at last the Victorian Government has been prepared to put on the table actual waiting list figures which are not, as the honourable member assumes, comparable with the figures for two years ago. If he bothered to look at them he would see that those figures have been constituted in a completely different and much more thorough way. He would begin to understand the real reasons for the waiting lists and begin to address and cope with the problem.
—Are you suggesting that there has not been a rapid increase?

—As the Minister in Victoria pointed out, the waiting list problem in Victoria and the increases that have occurred over the last 12 months are due primarily to two factors. One is industrial disputes in Victoria, unrelated to Medicare. There has been no industrial dispute relating to Medicare in that hospital system. The second factor is the shortage of nurses. Having got the figures and examined them, the Victorian Government was able to make an assessment of the real reason. Again, the South Australian Government recently has done what I regard as the best analysis of patient waiting lists in public hospitals yet produced in this country. I will provide a copy for the honourable member for Barker because, again, it will help to educate him to the real problem. I will give the conclusion from that study in South Australia. There is no direct evidence to support the contention that Medicare, by adding greatly to the in-patient load, has contributed to the situation of lengthening waiting lists. I believe it is worth while that these detailed waiting lists should be put on the table and examined so that we can find the real reasons for them and begin to address the particular problems. It will not be helped by the simple, demagogic claptrap that it is all a Medicare problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to some of the more specific problems raised by honourable members, and firstly to the issue of 'attractive and affordable'. We have tried to present a much more attractive private package by providing a coverage for prostheses, and for full gap cover for medicals bills for private patients in both the private and public hospital systems. We have also made provisions for day surgery. Those were efforts to make the package more attractive. Of course, in some ways providing that more attractive package will mean some increase in the contribution rates. I point out that when we look at the individuals concerned, the overall cost to the patient may well be less than is the present situation because, for instance, medical services in hospitals will attract benefits representing 100 per cent of the schedule fee, whereas currently patients must meet the cost of all gaps. In the case of complex surgery involving diagnostic services, the cost can be substantial. As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) pointed out earlier, that is why the Government has agreed to the gap proposals in relation to the hospital situation because one is likely for a single operation to have a series of procedures and a multiple collection of gaps. Secondly, private patients with basic insurance at present are required to meet the full cost of prostheses involving hundreds of dollars or maintain additional health insurance. These will now be covered in the basic package.

We believe that the same day hospital benefit should assist in reducing the cost of health insurance. I notice that the one word of praise from anywhere on the Opposition benches was from the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) and concerned the enforcement of the community rating principle for the whole of the health insurance arrangements which will ensure an adequate pool of good risks in the system and should result again in lower contribution rates than would otherwise be the case. So, there are a number of pressures designed to reduce the contribution rate. Even though there is some expectation that the rates will go up, on the other hand there are those greater benefits emerging to the patient. In addition, there will also be the choice of a front-end deductible scheme whereby if a contributor is willing to accept a certain proportion of the overall bill he or she will be able to get much lower contribution rates.

The honourable member for Barker raised the particular issue of his concern over the phrase 'occupies a bed' as somehow stifling the development of day care. Again, if he looks at the facts he will see that that is a most unlikely occurrence. If a private hospital wants to admit day care patients-it has that choice-it has three options open to it. It can admit day care patients up to the limit of its existing approved bed capacity. Currently, most private hospitals are operating at occupancy levels of around 65 per cent, which are very little changed from pre-Medicare levels. There is therefore plenty of space and bed capacity and the new day care benefit will encourage people to make use of that bed capacity. Secondly, the hospital can build a separate free-standing day care facility and seek state government approval for it as is already the practice, I understand, in one private hospital in South Australia. That seems to have worked well over the Medicare year. Thirdly, the hospital can apply to the appropriate authorities for an increase in its existing bed capacity. With those options open to the hospital it is difficult to see how the development of day care will be stifled. A further point is that it is necessary to have some safeguards at this stage in the development of day care surgery, which is a new development. It is important at this stage that day care benefits are paid only in legitimate cases. We do not want people walking in and out of hospitals without receiving a service or procedure and being able to claim benefits. We believe that the term 'occupies a bed' provides that safeguard. The honourable member for Mackellar raised two specific questions. One related to employers providing their own insurance for their workers. The legislation will not affect or disturb employer self-financing or self-insuring health benefits for employees. I give the honourable member that assurance. His other question asked to what extent ancillary benefits for commercial insurers will come under the National Health Act. They will come under the Health Act. They will be able to offer tables covering ancillary benefits, as defined in section 15 of the Bill, on the same terms as existing registered insurers.

Quite clearly, I will be dealing with the costs of Medicare in the Budget session so I will not deal with that now at any length. I must point out that as much nonsense is talked on this issue as on most of the other issues that have been raised tonight. If the honourable member for Petrie read my 3 September speech fully and most of the statements I have constantly made, he would see that they have indicated that there are three sources of funding of Medicare. One is the levy itself. The second is the very substantial saving to revenue by the ending of the tax rebate. I must say that every Opposition member is only too willing to attack the Government for doing that but never willing to admit that that is a major part of funding of the Medicare program. Thirdly there is the cut in the reinsurance pool. It is estimated at the moment that the net cost of Medicare is some $220m above what would have been the cost of the continuing and unsatisfactory Liberal scheme.

In conclusion I make one other point clear. One of the main aims of the Bill is to ensure the maintenance of community rating for health insurance. The Bill requires that if commercial insurers wish to continue in health insurance they will need to register under the National Health Act. Thus they will be required to comply with all provisions of the Act, including participation in the reinsurance arrangements, which is an essential feature of community rating.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Porter's) amendment stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment regatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.
Motion (by Dr Blewett) proposed:
That clause 9 be omitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) explained earlier in the day why he is seeking the Committee's support in amending the Health Legislation Amendment Bill by removing clause 9. Clause 9 is a provision which sets up a tribunal to review schedule fees. The matter was not previously discussed by the Government with the Australian Medical Association and when the AMA received information that this matter was in the legislation it expressed concern to the Minister about the detail of that proposal. The Opposition also has expressed some concern about clause 9. Therefore, we are not opposed to the amendment which deletes this clause from the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just point out that the issue was discussed with the Australian Medical Association. If the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) looks again at the Bill he will see that clause 9 occupies some two pages of the Bill. There is a lot of detail there and some of those details have concerned the AMA. We admit to that. In an effort to get a satisfactory solution, the Government is prepared to have further negotiations on that detail with the AMA.
