DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL INDUSTRY AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:WOOL TAX (Nos. 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1985 concurrently with the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1985. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will assure the passage of the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1985 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills which propose amendments to the Wool Industry Act 1972 and Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 5) 1964. These pieces of legislation are very important and they affect a very important Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bills is to allow greater flexibility in the apportionment of wool tax receipts and to provide for the apportionment of wool tax receipts amongst wool market support, wool research and the general purposes of the Australian Wool Corporation, namely, wool promotion and market administration, as part of the Wool Industry Act 1972. They provide for the apportionment to wool market support to be varied between a maximum of 5 per cent and a minimum of 4 per cent of the gross value of wool sales. The Bills allow the balance of the wool tax receipts to be apportioned between the Corporation's general purposes and wool research at a total rate of up to 4 per cent of the gross value of the sales of wool. Finally, they remove from the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1 to 5) 1964 the provision for apportionment of wool tax receipts among wool market support, wool research and the general purposes of the Corporation.

The Opposition supports the aims of the provisions in the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1985 and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1985. The Opposition also supports the provision for the actual figure within this range to be determined by the recommendation to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) of the Wool Council of Australia. At present the Wool Tax Acts provide for a levy on wool growers of 8 per cent of the gross sale value of wool. In 1984-85 the tax is expected to yield $171m. Receipts from the wool tax are apportioned under the Wool Tax Acts. Five per cent is allocated by the Wool Tax Acts for market support. The support fund finances any losses from the operation of the floor price scheme.

The remaining 3 per cent is allocated under regulations, with 2.5 per cent going to wool promotion and market administration expenses and 0.5 per cent going to research. Under the existing legislation, the 3 per cent levy is a maximum rate. It is not a fixed rate. The rate is determined by the Minister with the concurrence of the Australian Wool Corporation. The new arrangements will not alter the total levy on wool growers-that point needs to be stressed-which will remain at 8 per cent of the value of wool sales. They will change the apportionment of 8 per cent.

The levy for market support will be able to be varied between 4 per cent and 5 per cent. The actual percentage will be set by the Minister. The levy for promotion, administration and research will be variable up to a maximum of 4 per cent, corresponding to variations in the levy for market support. Wool industry research, which is a very important program, is funded by a 0.5 per cent levy on the gross value of wool sales and is matched by a Federal Government contribution on a dollar for dollar basis. This has been so for some time. This year the total amount for wool research will be around $20m.

Promotion and market administration expenditures are funded by a 2.5 per cent levy on the value of wool shorn and a Federal Government contribution on a $2 industry to $1 Government basis. The levies are set as part of the current five-year plan for the wool industry. In 1984-85 the Commonwealth's share of the $102.4m for research, promotion and other expenditures will be around $38.3m. That amount includes $26m for wool promotion in 1984-85.

The wool industry is a very big Australian industry. Wool exports are expected to earn $2.5 billion this financial year. They represent a sizable proportion of Australia's export earnings. In fact, around 10 per cent of Australia's export earnings will come from wool. There are very few industries in Australia which are more important to the well-being of Australia's standard of living than the Australian wool industry. I must declare a pecuniary interest in this because I happen to be a wool grower. I am proud to be a wool grower.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have very woolly ideas.
—The Minister said that I am very woolly around the ears. I am proud to be woolly around the ears.
—You are woolly between the ears.

—The honourable member, who represents a metropolitan electorate, is very woolly-especially on the showboat. These figures demonstrate the tremendous importance of the wool industry in the overall export earnings of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry is based largely upon the magnificent merino sheep. The Australian merino is undoubtedly the best wool producer in the world. My family has been involved in wool production for four generations. As a wool grower, I have every reason to be proud of the enormous contribution that the industry has made to the standards of living of all Australians and the development of this nation since earliest settlement. So wool growers and their families can take a bow. I hope that they are all listening to this debate tonight, wherever they might be. I pay a tribute to those great parent stud masters who have done so much to maintain the standard of the merino animal. The merino is one of the wonder animals of the world. It is a proud animal-even prouder than the most proud Minister sitting in this Parliament, and I notice that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is about to leave the chamber. Merino wool is still playing a very important part in the overall stability of the economy at the present time through its important export earnings.

This would not have been the case today without the Fraser Government's drought assistance schemes. Breeders of merino sheep were preparing to let their flocks face the drought unaided because of their inability to maintain the expenditures necessary to feed them through the extended drought. The fact that they did not have to let their stock become victims of drought ensured the continuation of the wool industry's vitally large export earnings and the industry's contribution to rural recovery.

There are few industries in Australia that are less assisted or protected. It is interesting to note that 95 per cent to 97 per cent of the industry's product is sold on the world market. Eighty per cent of Australia's clip is exported as greasy wool and 15 per cent is processed to varying degrees locally and then exported. The outstanding export performance of the wool industry has been due in large part to its aggressive market promotion and research and the comparatively high productivity gains in the industry. I have just been asked by way of a little note from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether I want a job as a stud master. I wonder what he has in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has indicated to me that the honourable member should not elaborate on that question any further.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for your help. I do not know what we would do without you, sir. One of the most outstanding contributions made to this industry has been the aggressive market promotion and research and the comparatively high productivity gains in the industry. Wool's research and promotion effort is a model for other industries. Export earnings have continued to rise during a period of falling resource prices generally and on markets characterised by fast-changing consumer demands. The Australian Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation must be given full credit for the excellent export performance of the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of us in this House will remember the financial crisis that faced the Australian wool growers in the late 1960s when the so-called free auction system failed the growers and failed the nation because of certain activities of vested interest groups. Some of us can recall the great debate within the wool industry leadership-between the factions seeking a single selling authority and other mechanisms to ensure a fair return for the fleece and others who clung ideologically to the so-called free auction system. In 1970 I became very much involved in this controversial issue because it was my firm belief that the so-called free auction market was being manipulated by certain vested interest groups to bear the resource market in their favour.

On Saturday, 21 March 1970 I helped organise a wool growers meeting in Moree. The meeting, which was attended by over 3,000 growers, was one of the biggest gatherings of its kind ever held in this nation. Speakers at that meeting, which I chaired, included people such as Sir William Gunn, to whom I pay a great personal tribute, Mr Bryce Killen, Mr Ronald Hunter, OBE, and Mr Claude Renshaw, OBE. Mr Hunter moved the main motion at that great meeting in the following terms:
That a single marketing authority be established with the necessary powers to administer the efficient marketing and distribution of the entire wool clip.

That is where and how the Australian Wool Corporation began. The Corporation was born at that meeting at Taylor Oval in Moree, New South Wales. That meeting was followed by other such meetings throughout Australia. The rank and file wool growers had become impatient with the warring factions at the leadership of the industry organisations. They had become tired of government inaction, although government was also awaiting an agreed policy position from the industry.

From the Moree meeting a wave of support for a new authority grew and ultimately the wool leaders read the signs clearly. The Liberal-Country Party Government of the day set up a peak council of the Australian Wool Industry Conference. The Government acted. The then Minister for Primary Industry, Doug Anthony, who can claim great credit for the part that he played in this process, introduced the first Bill to establish the Australian Wool Commission headed by Sir William Vines. That body is now known as the Australian Wool Corporation and is headed by its excellent Chairman, Mr David Asimus. The Corporation is one of the greatest success stories in Australian agricultural and pastoral history. However, events have moved on. I might add that I believe Mr David Asimus, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation and the International Wool Secretariat, is probably the most outstanding man in the field. I do not think anybody has done more for the Australian wool industry than he has. David Asimus has said:

A major effort now centres on the creation and promotion of new products to expand wool demand, and marketing projects which will fully exploit the international presence of IWS to identify growth markets, improve the share of IWS sponsor countries' wool in the total demand for wool and move new products faster into consumption.

The Australian Wool Council two or three years ago foresaw the possibility of future problems in meeting commitments to the International Wool Secretariat. The Council saw the need for flexibility in the apportionment amongst the end users of receipts from the wool tax levy. The Wool Council of Australia fully supports the introduction of some flexibility in the allocation of the wool tax proceeds and the Council will, of course, recommend the actual allocations.

As a result of the depreciation of the Australian dollar, the Corporation would be looking at a deficit of around $20m in its commitments to the IWS in 1985-86. It is important that the flexibility provision of the Bills be in place before the 1985-86 selling season. The Opposition congratulates the Government in responding to the requests of the Wool Council of Australia. The Opposition parties offer a speedy passage to this very important legislation which I am sure will be of great value to one of the most important industries, if not the most important industry, in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has expressed his justifiable pride as a wool grower and as a participant in the Australian wool industry. It is a pride which all Australian wool growers and every other Australian ought to echo. The Australian wool industry has an extraordinary history. Within ten years of colonisation the first of the merino sheep of Spanish origin had been brought into this nation, and from 1860 to 1930 the export component of what was a new industry grew from 27 kilotonnes to 425 kilotonnes of wool. The industry had etched itself indelibly into Australia's history.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of wool growing in Australia is the history of farmers jealously guarding their independence and their right to be profitable and productive as Australian men on the land. These Bills are another step in entrenching the capacity of this industry to develop its own character, to be a little more flexible, and to open up and pioneer its own new markets.

The Wool Industry Amendment Bill and the Wool Tax Amendment Bills reflect the fact that 8 per cent of growers' gross product is contributed by growers through the wool tax to the wool industry. That is no mean undertaking for individual Australians to commit themselves to. These Bills have bipartisan support, but it is widely enough recognised in our community just how independent the wool growers have been prepared to be.

The urbanised legislators opposite have failed to appreciate that the urban image of the Australian wool grower is not the Australian wool grower at all. The Australian wool grower personified by a popular cigarette advertisement, which has him astride a well-groomed horse, wearing his R. M. Williams, with a wide-brimmed hat and smoking that popular brand cigarette is far removed from the reality of growing wool in Australia. So is that image of a wide verandahed house set in spacious grounds with idyllic surroundings. In reality, the wool grower of Australia today is a man who is struggling in the face of the chill wind of economic competition. Furthermore, if honourable members will pardon the pun, were it not for the fact that he is dealing with the wool industry, he would be frozen in that chill wind. In fact, this wool grower faces the gale of competition from alternative products but has continued nonetheless to further develop a unique and natural product.

After two hundred years we have a wool industry that is not only innovative and productive but whose production is reflected in the statistical fact that, whilst this nation has only 14 per cent of the world's sheep, it produces 27 per cent of the world's wool. From the years 1900 to 1970 our flock grew to a maximum of 180 million sheep. That represented a threefold increase in flock numbers but a fourfold increase in the amount of wool produced. Those figures illustrate just how innovative and productive Australia's wool farmers have been.

The purpose of the Bills before the House tonight is to allow the 8 per cent contributed to the wool industry by Australia's wool growers to be broken up a little more flexibly. As the honourable member for Gwydir has said, the previous allocation of funds for wool promotion and marketing, which was previously 3 per cent, will now be up to 4 per cent and the market support levy will be variable up to 5 per cent. This greater flexibility will allow Australia's wool industry to be a more effective marketer overseas. This proud and unique industry which, as the honourable member for Gwydir has said, has survived in Australia with less protection than any other industry, and whose product is unique and unrivalled as a garment fibre, is now able to market more effectively because these Bills are before the House and more funds will be made available to it for the purpose of wool promotion and marketing research.

I am very conscious of the time limits that are placed upon us tonight by the Labor Government, which is not prepared to have this issue debated as it deserves. Because time is short, I need to trim-perhaps I should say shear-my remarks in order not to go unduly over time. I close by referring, as did the honourable member for Gwydir, to the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr David Asimus, who is currently Chairman of the International Wool Secretariat. He said that one of the greatest areas for expansion in the wool market and for wool exports currently exists in the Chinese market. All of the innovation and productivity that has been characteristic of Australian wool growers will be needed if we are to move effectively into that market. The Bills before the House will mean that greater resources can be directed towards market expansion. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Wool Industry Amendment Bill and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills, I, like the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), have to declare a pecuniary interest. I can also match him and say that I am a fourth generation member of a wool growing family. In supporting these Bills I endorse all that has been said by the honourable member for Gwydir and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). One of the reasons this industry is so great is that it has worked in harmony with so many people who have supported it. I mention in particular the shearers and the wool classers, because it is only through the combined efforts of the growers, the shearers and the classers that this industry has become such a great industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Acts which the Bills deal with mainly revolve around giving the industry the opportunity of taking up to one per cent of the wool tax-that is tax on the gross proceeds of all wool growers-away from the reserve price scheme and to use it for promotion. As has already been mentioned, at present 2 1/2 per cent of the 8 per cent levy on the gross proceeds of all wool is used for promotion in the industry. Research receives 0.5 per cent. At present the remaining 5 per cent is being used to support the reserve price scheme. Under the changed arrangements it will be possible for the industry, with the Minister's consent, to use an extra one per cent of the wool tax in promotion.

The important thing for members of this House and for all people to realise is that this industry has shown a great deal of initiative. It has shown how an industry can support itself and pull itself out of a crisis with self-help. The industry is to be commended. Many other industries in Australia could take a long hard look at the wool industry because it certainly has been a great success. I emphasise to honourable members present in the House tonight that this industry is supporting itself. I also bring up the question of Government support for promotion. At present the Government provides 1.2 per cent of the gross value of wool proceeds for promotion. This works out at something like $26m a year. Some people might ask: 'Why should the Government be providing some support?'. There is plenty of justification for that support. I will quote from a submission made to the Government in December 1983 by the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Ian McLachlan. He spelt out very clearly the justification for the industry receiving some support from the Government. I believe that this money is well spent by the Government. I am sure it reaps it back for the nation many times over in export earnings and, probably for the Government itself, in additional taxes. Why should the Government support wool promotion funding? Honourable members will find the answer in the letter written by Mr McLachlan. He said:

The Government has committed $248 million in 1983/84 to support exports of Australian manufacturing and service industries compared to $20m for the wool industry. The export dependency of the manufacturing sector according to the IAC Annual Report for 1982/83 is 11.8% making 135,600 export dependent employees and is equivalent to the estimated number of employees dependent in the sheep industry. The support per export dependent employee in the manufacturing sector is $1,840 compared to the export support for the wool industry of $165 per employee.

The support for the manufacturing sector is equivalent to about 4.2 per cent of the total export earnings as measured in 1982-83. That 4.2 per cent compares with a figure of 1.2 per cent of export earnings for the wool industry. On any basis of equity the support that the Government at present puts into wool promotion is very small indeed, and certainly it is only a relatively small amount compared with support for exports in the secondary industries and service industries.

Why does the industry need these additional funds? If one looks at the International Wool Secretariat, which is where most of our promotion funds are spent, one finds that the problem facing the Secretariat at present is that we have made a commitment to maintain funds in real terms at the 1982-83 level. But with the fall in the value of the Australian dollar, Australia is finding it more difficult to meet those commitments without this change in legislation. I would add, for the benefit of Government members, that the International Wool Secretariat is, again, a self-help organisation. It has three founding members-they are the wool-growing countries-namely Australia, New Zealand and, would you believe it, South Africa. Two have since been added. Nevertheless the IWS is a great success story.

As the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Asimus, said to the Wool Council annual conference in May of this year, the cost of the fall in the Australian dollar has caused our commitment to promotion to reach a deficit of about 50 per cent, which could be as much as $25m. That is due solely to the devaluation of the Australian dollar. When one considers that in 1984-85 the 2.5 per cent levy on wool growers' proceeds will raise $54m, one realises that a further one per cent taken from the reserve price scheme will give only $22m, so it is more than timely.

I remind the House that wool is one of the great export industries of this country, earning $2.5 billion in the coming year, making it roughly equal to the wheat industry and second only to the coal industry. The wool industry has a very low level of protection, and its success is due very much to its self-help in getting out and promoting its product. I have great pleasure in supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Wool Industry Amendment Bill, which has already been eloquently supported by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). The National Party of Australia and our Liberal coalition partners are prepared to support this Bill tonight on the basis that existing wool taxes are not increased. This condition is important because government taxes and charges and costs of production are already helping to deny the wool industry and indeed agricultural industries throughout Australia the opportunity to develop fully the potential of profit and the potential for a viable and enduring future in our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years farmers' terms of trade have slowly been eroded. Costs of production have increased at a far greater rate than the consumer price index. Indeed, the costs associated with farming have risen by a far greater amount than any of the prices received by farmers for their products. The farming organisations throughout Australia, spearheaded by the National Farmers Federation, attempted to draw to the Government's attention at the so-called farm costs summit held recently here in Canberra the fact that costs are increasing at a rapid rate. Not only did the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) not listen but the Government did not listen to the needs and demands of the farming community of Australia. The farm costs summit proved to be a sham. It proved to be the political ploy that members of the coalition parties suggested it would be during the recent election campaign. The Federal Government is slowly losing credibility in the farming community. It is important for any Government to maintain credibility if it is to stay in office. If the Government wishes to regain some of the credibility that it has lost in recent months it must try to give to the farming sectors of Australia the importance that they so richly deserve.

The Australian wool industry laid the foundation-stone of our economy. It used to be popular to say that Australia rode on the sheep's back. Although it perhaps rides on the sheep's back to a lesser degree now, that is still the case to a great extent. The wool industry produces $2.5m, or some 10 per cent, of Australia's export income. In fact, 95 to 97 per cent of all wool produced in Australia is sold overseas. The responsibility for marketing and promoting wool and for managing our wool industry rests broadly on the shoulders of the Australian Wool Corporation. Of course the National Party and its coalition partner, the Liberal Party, can take a great deal of the credit for the Australian Wool Corporation because without us and, as mentioned by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, without the assistance of the former Leader of the National Party, Mr Doug Anthony, the Australian Wool Corporation would not exist as it does today. Certainly it would not be able to provide the more than adequate support that it now gives to the industry.

It would be inexcusable of me to talk about the wool industry without mentioning the electorate of Gilmore, which I have the honour of representing in this Federal Parliament. Within the boundaries of the electorate of Gilmore we find some of the best wool growing areas in Australia. I mention, for instance, the areas around the city of Goulburn and towns such as Crookwell, Boorowa and Gunning, all of which are renowned fine wool growing areas. They are not just renowned for producing fine wool; they are also renowned for producing some of the best breeding stock in Australia. When I think of some of the more notable wool growers and breeders in the electorate of Gilmore my mind immediately goes to the Picker family at Bigga, who until recently held the world record price for a bale of wool. I also think of the famous Merriman family from Boorowa who own and operate the Merriville stud. The Merriville stud was established by Sir Walter Merriman and is now owned and operated by Mr Bruce Merriman and his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! Great family.

—Certainly a great family. Goulburn is the centre of the Gilmore electorate and we find there one of the largest wool handling centres in Australia. The wool industry provides a great deal of employment, not only to shearers and others connected with the shearing industry, but also to all those people in Goulburn who work within the wool handling industry. It was a great honour for me this afternoon to be host in Parliament House to the former long-serving Mayor of Goulburn, Mr Ernie McDermott, and the former State member for Goulburn, Mr Ron Brewer.
—Two gentlemen.

—They are both great gentlemen. Both recognise the importance of the wool industry to the city of Goulburn. They have done all they can to ensure that it is a strong and viable industry for Goulburn and have thus helped to give that city a much needed impetus for development.

SPEECH.PARA: My hope that Bills of this nature will continue to be introduced by this Government is unparallelled, but the legislation which this Government has introduced into this Parliament over recent months does not give me great confidence. The fact that fuel prices have increased dramatically, by nearly 11c a litre in the first six months of 1985 with further increases to be introduced during the rest of this year, gives me no great hope for the future of Australia's agricultural industries. However, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their comments during this debate on what is basically a series of machinery measures which will give the wool industry more freedom in the use of its funds. The comments made by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and by most of the other honourable members opposite are shared by the Government. We all well know how important this industry is to Australia. Wool is about the only commodity for which we are a price-maker on world markets. That is why it is so important for the public to back this industry with respect to wool promotion funds.

SPEECH.PARA: I first came into this Parliament after a stint in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I was in the wool marketing section and was engaged in the Australian objective measurement project, which enabled me to visit sheep properties throughout Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and to get a very good hands-on feeling for this great industry. When I entered the Parliament I represented the electorate of Macarthur, which was named after John Macarthur. I made the comment that the electorate of Macarthur was named after one of the greatest rogues in Australian history and had always been represented by rogues-Jeff Bate, John Kerin and Michael Baume. I think I will leave out the present honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). Maybe that description is not too apt now, in later years, for Colin Hollis and the present honourable member. Recently a book has been brought out on the Macarthurs, about the Saxon strain of sheep and all the rest of it. I think we owe a greater debt to Elizabeth than we do to John. But that is a matter for the historians to argue.

The Australian Wool Corporation has been a success in terms of selling, its market support measures, and the way it handles research. The Government will still put pressure on the Wool Corporation in various ways, and in discussion, to continue to be a market innovator, to continue to research the effectiveness of its wool promotion and also to go through constantly the exercise of looking at the way it should set the minimum reserve price. Quite frankly, with floating exchange rates and the way world commodity markets are, in recent periods there have been times when South Africa and New Zealand have really had a bit of a feed at our expense. At other times we have had a feed at their expense. But there is a need to go through this exercise constantly.

I think the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) talked a lot of nonsense. The wool industry has always been very much a bipartisan sort of issue in terms of what governments from both sides of the House have done. A lot of effort certainly went into the industry through the late 1960s and into the 1970s when Mr Anthony negotiated and argued with this industry against a lot of opposition. He told it that it should get itself into better shape. The actions of Sir William Gunn at Hamilton have gone down in the annals of agricultural politics in this country as a bit of folklore. It was extremely hard to get this very conservative industry to face up to the necessity to change. Eventually it did change and that is why we have what we have today. Before the Labor Government came into office in 1972 the previous Government had had a deficiency payments scheme. There was a great slump in the wool industry in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It was a very tragic time.

To go through the dates, 1964 was the first time the wool tax was introduced. There was a 3 per cent tax in 1964 for promotion research. In 1970 the Australian Wool Board initiated the flexible reserve price system. During 1971 the former coalition Government introduced the fixed floor price at December 1970 levels, as I recall. It was not a formal procedure. It was limited to a single season. In 1972 the Wool Industry Act established the Australian Wool Corporation. The legal mechanisms were put in place when the Labor Government came into power.

In 1974, under the Labor Government, with Ken Wriedt as Minister, the Wool Tax Acts were amended. The tax was increased to 8 per cent, and 5 per cent of that went into the market support fund. To finance it, there was a government loan of $150m to kick off the whole system of a minimum reserve price, which has since been repaid and the industry has kept on, basically, on its own funds ever since. Ken Wriedt set up the corporation structure as it is now. It is the structure which I would like to give to the Wheat Board, but of course the Wheatgrowers Federation and the wheat growers are still far too conservative to accept what I think would be very much in their own interests.

When I say that the honourable member for Gilmore has talked a lot of nonsense, I am not trying to make a partisan point; it is to point out that the ongoing way that both the Liberal Government and the Labor Government have handled the wool industry has been a credit to all of us and has involved quite a lot of discussion.

I have already touched on the question of promotion-what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said at Deniliquin when he announced that the Government was going to move to a more predictable and equitable way of financing wool promotion than allowing the fiscal fiends to come into the matter at every Budget time. As the growers contribute on the basis of percentage of proceeds, we thought that the Government should also contribute on that basis. Instead of freezing this, as Mr Fraser did, at $20m, we moved to the 1.2 per cent formula. Honourable members may not be aware of it, but I have just received the clip forecast. On the latest figures the sheep flock is tipped to reach a 150.6m-that is going up by some 12 per cent-and we will get a clip estimated at about 785 kilotonnes. We can look at all sorts of predictions for price. We cannot determine exactly how much the wool promotion figure will be, but calculations can be made of anything up to $33m this year. I think that the figure will be about $30m; but it is certainly a great improvement on the $20m that went into wool promotion but was then frozen. I think that this Government has again shown that it can act in the real interests of the wool industry in a very constructive sense. As I said earlier, wool promotion and the funding by the public through the Government is the best demonstration possible of the public's faith in this great industry, because we still depend so much upon it.

Other comments were made about the farm costs conference. I do not suppose that I should go through that, but it has been a very useful exercise for the National Farmers Federation to get some understanding of the complexities of the budgetary problem that the Government faces-in respect of wage fixation, secondary industry tariffs and protection, and how we should be handling that by way of industry packages rather than engaging in the sterile debate about free trade and protection. Even though the Press, in my view, has very much misreported the first farm costs conference, shall we call it, I think that a lot of constructive good came out of that. Even today, one of the matters that came out of it was that we have set up a working party with respect to the fisheries industry.

Quite frankly, at the first meeting, when we found that the estimates of the load per farmer were so divergent, from $6,000 to $19,000, it was very sensible to put that matter into the hands of officials to see whether we could get agreement. Now we have narrowed that agreement down to something between $6,000 and $9,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is your figure?

—It does not really matter what the figure comes out at. We know that the theory is right and that the order is something between $6,000 and $9,000. That is certainly not of the order of $6,000 to $19,000. So we have agreement on that. In terms of the budgetary considerations, specific requests by the National Farmers Federation will be taken into account in the budgetary discussions. I have to go into a Cabinet meeting in a moment to discuss some items relating to these matters. I do not really want to carry through this idea that the farm costs meeting was somehow a bad exercise. I think it was a very good exercise in getting the NFF to understand the complexities of the budgetary decisions that we have before us, the need to preserve the trilogy, the need to bear down on costs, and the need to take macroeconomic decisions in the interests of the rural sector as a whole, because getting the economy right, getting inflation down and keeping interest rates down are by far the most important things that any government can do for the rural sector as a whole. I thank honourable members opposite for their comments on this most important legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — While the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 is an all-inclusive Bill covering 19 separate Acts, it does not provide much problem for the Opposition, except inasmuch as we have given notification that we will be opposing certain aspects of it in Committee. It has been described as an ordinary machinery Bill, but in some respects the full information that would properly reflect the nature of the changes has not been included in the outline, in the explanatory memorandum or in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). I will deal with those as we come to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill in fact covers three ministerial areas-Social Security, Community Services and Veterans' Affairs. I would like to dwell on some aspects of the amendments to the Social Security Act before I deal with the assets test and the amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. In respect of not only the Social Security Act but also other Acts, the Bill provides for the payment of reduced pensions and allowances under the new enterprise incentive scheme, but we find a difficulty here in that it has been impossible to date to find out details of that scheme. I understand that legislation is not required by the Department in this regard, but the only assurance I as shadow Minister have been able to receive is that payments under this scheme will be provided by way of income support, whereas at one time it was suggested that there might be capitalisation of funds and they would be payable in a lump sum. Based on the fact that they will be paid as income support, the Opposition sees no problem with the amendments suggested to both the Social Security Act and some of the other Acts.

I say to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, that I do not believe it is good enough to bring legislation into this House when a program relating to that legislation has not been properly put to the Parliament, which I believe to be the case. Whilst some States have agreements with the Commonwealth in connection with this program, they have not yet been signed; and other States have yet to agree. I believe it is almost a contempt of the Parliament not to have that scheme available for scrutiny by all members of the Parliament before this Bill becomes an Act.

The Bill also clarifies, in a context which will not be misleading or from which a mistake will not be made, matters pertaining to the custody of children. Apparently in many cases it is very difficult under the Family Law Act actually to determine custody, and the Bill goes some way to clearing that up. There is also a four-year rule which provides that the benefit, pension or allowance can be payable to a parent for a dependent child is overseas provided that that child is likely to return to Australia within a certain period. That is an adjustment of something that was not clear in the past.

There is also a 10-year rule under which it is necessary for a person to prove 10 years of residency in Australia, preferably at the one time. However, providing a person has been in Australia for five years on a continuous basis and for another broken period of five years, he will now be eligible to the various entitlements.

The social security amendments also pick up aspects of the Redlich report in relation to summary hearings. This is expected to improve the basis on which charges can be laid for overpayment or fraud and enable the matters to be dealt with more quickly. Of course, this highlights the difficulties not only in the social security legislation but also with many other Acts of the amount of reported and unreported fraud under the various programs. I have heard estimates of as much as $300m per year being taken from the Commonwealth, from taxpayers, by fraudulent applications and payment of benefits and allowances. Perhaps this will be a means by which quicker action can be taken to recover such overpayments.

As I have said, while the amendments deal with a new enterprise incentive scheme, I believe there is some need, particularly with unemployment benefits, for legislation to clarify the situation of a self-employed person who is able to work outside at certain times of the year but, because the Act at present deems such people to be underemployed and not unemployed, they do not receive the benefit. Under the new scheme, those people will not be eligible for the benefit because they are established. These people are mainly in the rural industries. I have seen cases in which commissioners on a tribunal dealing with unemployment benefit for farmers have indicated that the legislation is a bit fuzzy and needs clarification. This is an area which should be looked at.

One of the 19 Acts amended by this legislation is the Social Security and Repatriation (Budget Measures and Assets Test) Act of 1984. The amendments just clarify the situation of payments before and after the starting date. However, I believe that many pensioners who have been affected by the assets test expected that when the first available opportunity to amend the legislation arose the opportunity would have been taken to include in the legislation the changes that have been mooted, and recognised by both the Minister for Social Security and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to correct the anomalies and the difficulties faced by elderly people on farms in rural areas. This would have been an opportunity for the Minister to bring forward such amendments. We understand that these matters have been taken to Cabinet. I am not sure how much they were pressed in Cabinet. We have not seen a statement made in this House and we certainly have not seen any amendments to this measure. As I have said, this would have been a wonderful opportunity for the Government to incorporate those changes acknowledged as necessary by pensioners, elderly people, rural industries, the National Farmers Federation, the Queensland Country Women's Association and of course the Opposition.

The Opposition has been pointing out from the time the assets test was suggested that there would be hardship and anomalies. Yet nothing has been done. Either the Government is deaf and does not hear these complaints about the anomalies or it is pigheaded about them. It is time that those changes were made to relieve the distress and discomfort of many of those elderly people who are suffering as a result of the assets test. I will not say that it is widespread but the number of applications being made at the moment under the hardship provisions-from 2,000 to 3,000 people-indicates that a minority is being affected and that relief is required. The quicker this relief is provided the better because, if it requires legislative change, it cannot be done until August. This will put many people in a continually disadvantaged situation. They will have no idea of what the changes should be or could be and, worse still, whether they will be applied retrospectively to the date of the commencement of the Act. The Opposition believes that a wonderful opportunity was missed by the Government in this regard.

I now deal with the third and most important area. The Government seeks to amend the provisions of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1977. The Opposition has read of the discontent within the private and public sectors about the escalating cost of workers compensation. Any employer would realise that the effects of these compensation payments are being felt in workers compensation premiums right around Australia. Any change to the Act at this stage which would make it more generous is not something that the Australian people would tolerate. I draw the attention of honourable members to some statistics in this regard. A report in the National Times dated 6 to 12 July 1984 stated:
Compensation claims paid by private insurers mushroomed from $261m in 1977 to $647m in 1982-a rise of 148 per cent. Over the same period, the CPI rose by only 57 per cent.

I have taken some figures from the annual reports of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation. The figures cited are from Table 1. According to the National Times, compensation claims paid by private insurers mushroomed. The Commonwealth's payments in 1977 amounted to $25m, but in 1982 the figure for that area of Commonwealth responsibility had risen to $75m, or a rise of 200 per cent. If the National Times was complaining about the 148 per cent rise in the private sector, I wonder what it would have done if it had realised that there had been a 300 per cent increase within the public sector under the Commonwealth's own scheme. Those figures were for the years between 1977 and 1982. It is interesting that from 1982 to 1984 the figure increased from $75m to $121m. That is an increase of about 60 per cent. Certainly the consumer price index has not increased by that extent.

Let me give the House the basic comparative figures for the last 10 years. In 1974-75 there were 35,000 claims costing $15m. In 1983-84 there were 54,776 claims costing $121m, or eight times the amount 10 years before. I believe the Opposition has a legitimate concern. The National Times and the Press of Australia also have a legitimate concern, as do the employers who have to contribute to private insurance schemes. To recapitulate, I quote from the Australian Financial Review of 9 January 1985. Under the heading 'Serious deficiencies in compo office' it states:

Serious weaknesses in the operational of the Federal Employees Compensation Office are being reviewed by a team of consultants and officers from the Public Service Board and Department of Social Security.

Government sources expect the review, which has been running for some months, to go to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, next month. This has led to soaring administrative costs as well as overloading of an antiquated administrative structure for processing claims.
The final paragraph states:
The 1982-83 annual report shows a 33 per cent increase in expenditure on compensation claims from $75,610,000 in 1981-82 to $100,665,000 in 1982-83.

As I have said, this reached $125m in 1983-84. The Opposition has looked at these changes. Very little mention was made in the second reading speech of the major changes to which the Parliament should be addressing itself. There are three changes. We have given indications that we will be amending clause 34 and opposing clauses 35, 36 and 37. I believe it would be of interest to the Parliament to understand what the situation is. Clause 34 gives, for the first time in compensation history-I have checked three of the States in this regard-a privileged position to a trade union official.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!

—It is not only shameful, but also typical of the manner in which this Government has gone down the trade union and the Australian Council of Trade Unions line. It has not had the gumption or the guts to say in this House: 'This is what we are doing'. I understand this is a break with tradition in that the Government has not only introduced the definition of trade union into the Act, but it is also prepared to give an employee of the Commonwealth, who is also an official of the trade union, cover for work done after hours where it is said that he is employing himself in the interests of the members of his union. If a trade union meeting is held after hours, travel to and from home is now covered. What is the position of such an employee who pickets against his employer? Is that activity covered or not? I have checked with three of the States to confirm that this legislation is breaking fresh ground. None of the States have separate compensation requirements for their employees; they are covered as part of a private insurance scheme. In view of the figures I have mentioned, the Commonwealth has obviously provided a very generous scheme. It appears to be so generous that the trade union movement wants to move in. At the moment, if a trade union wants to take cover on a voluntary basis, it is allowed to do so. The Government, in a most secretive way, has included its compensation provisions in amongst a lot of amendments to other Bills. It has not made known what it is doing. We will be seeking an alteration to clause 34.

SPEECH.PARA: While the legislation does not define an ordinary recess-I understand this has been established legally as meaning a lunch hour break-a lunch hour break, apart from certain exceptions, will be covered. So an employee who goes about his business in his hour off to have dinner outside, have a run around or whatever will be covered. The legislation in the States does not cover this point specifically because there have been enough legal precedents to determine that a person who is engaging in this type of activity, with the knowledge of the employer, is covered in the event of an accident. Not covered in the legislation as an exception is a person who wilfully and deliberately engages in high risk activity. Would someone injured in a football match during the lunch hour be covered, even though it is not a requirement of the employer that he play sport during the lunch hour? Again, I think this is putting a person into a privileged position. This does not already exist, for the right purpose, in the State Acts. In this legislation we do not find the exemption we feel is necessary to exempt those activities undertaken by a person who wilfully goes looking for trouble during a lunch break. That is my second point.

My third point relates to tables which I have cleared with the Minister for incorporation in Hansard. The tables are taken from the Department of Social Security annual report for 1983-84 and make a comparison between benefits available from unemployment and sickness benefits and those available under the Commonwealth employees scheme. I seek leave to have the tables incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
