TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As I said, those facts and figures have been taken directly from the report. The last aspect about which the Opposition complains is that which allows a person who is partially incapacitated but available for work and who cannot find work and who has undertaken certain schemes to try to rehabilitate himself, to be treated as a fully incapacitated person and to continue to be compensated as such. That is a unique situation applying only to a Commonwealth employee. The two tables I have just incorporated indicate that a single person paid compensation on this basis will have had available to him $149 a week as at 30 June 1984. However, somebody who is in exactly the same situation who has had to leave employment, who receives compensation, who undertakes rehabilitation courses and who is available for work but is unable to find work, would necessarily, if he were 85 per cent incapacitated, have to go on an invalid pension. Obviously that person would not be 85 per cent incapacitated because he could still work. I understand that such a person normally would fall within the unemployment benefits provision. Such a person in the private sector who is 18 years old and without dependants would be entitled to $78.60 a week compared with the other benefit of $149 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: No wonder the people of Australia not only complain about the growth of the private sector compensation, but also must be concerned about the figure that we were talking about earlier-the tremendous eight-fold increase over the last 10 years in payments by the Commonwealth. People must wonder why these payments have taken place. At the moment this Government is deliberately going out of its way to cut expenditure yet it has introduced a Bill, practically within the week, that will increase, certainly not curb, the rate of expenditure. I believe it is hypocritical of the Government to say one thing and next week make favoured allowances to the trade union movement and its own employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —When has this Government ever worried about hypocrisy?

—The Government probably has never worried about hypocrisy, but it should know the meaning of the word by now. This is not the only example of such hypocrisy; there have been thousands over the years. We have the situation of the Government cutting costs in one week in connection with local government and in a lot of other areas that we have a concern with and yet treating its own employees to conditions of privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the Bill. The amendments to the Act have been introduced without the Government addressing itself to a review of the whole service, which obviously was to come out earlier this year. The Minister for Social Security has not addressed himself to the administrative changes required in this regard. I believe the Opposition would agree with the other amendments because basically they dovetail more closely with arrangements but also because they accept the principles available within other workers' compensation Acts within the States. We will go into Committee on these matters at a later time.

I know that it is all very well for an Opposition to be critical in here, but people will want to know our position in this regard. Having examined both the private and public sectors and bearing in mind the fact that there must be a review, I believe that it would be part of our policy to review the existing Commonwealth employees compensation scheme with a view to contracting it out to the insurance market in order to reduce the high administrative cost currently incurred by the scheme. If we are contracting out, we would possibly contract with one of the State instrumentalities where the benefits would be greater and the cost would be cheaper. It is time for a proper review of this Act. I wish the matter would come before the Parliament for a full debate so that the Opposition could expound its views in this regard. Mr Deputy Speaker, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst reiterating the Opposition's intention to abolish the ''assets test'', the Government be rebuked for not providing within the Bill, the amendments required to remove the anomalies and hardships provided within the present test so as to effect the review of the assets test as promised by both the Minister and the Prime Minister'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill contains a number of amendments which simply update and simplify the legislation dealing with the Government's responsibilities to those who receive welfare and repatriation benefits. This is an area of high priority for a Labor government. Our first priority is to those who need government help and that leads me to talk tonight about the issue of poverty in this lucky country in 1985, and particularly the issue of women in poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition claims of hypocrisy astound me when we begin to talk of benefits for those in need. Some of their claims that pensioners and beneficiaries are worse off under the Australian Labor Government are just not true. Senator Messner has made some of these claims and in so doing has used figures that are deliberately slanted. Instead of making a proper comparison of the last full quarter under the Liberal Government, December 1982, with the December 1984 quarter, he took figures from May 1983, just after Labor had granted its first social security rise, and March 1985, just before the latest rise under Labor. The real figures of course show that the position of people receiving social security has improved by up to 19.5 per cent relative to the poverty line. That is still not enough, but at least our Government has its priorities right. It is committed to providing income support first to those who need it, unlike honourable members opposite whose priorities commit them to providing income support to those who have their own wealth to support themselves whether the Government can afford them that benefit or not.

Honourable members on this side have a genuine concern for the real poor in Australia. The Opposition has no understanding of poverty. For the last three weeks we have listened to Opposition members talking about the poverty of farmers who have assets and about their need for Government help. How many times have members of the Opposition talked about the poverty of those who have nothing at all, except the support that government gives them? Do they give any thought to the fact that 800,000 children in Australia are dependent on people who are receiving pensions or benefits and most of whom are women? Labor's first two Budgets meant a 40 per cent increase in additional payments for children of people on social security. This year some 420,000 families are receiving additional payments for children at a cost of $420m. Another $50m is being provided for children in low wage families through the family income supplement. But there is still a great deal to be done. Since the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty almost nothing has been done to implement the recommendations coming out of that Inquiry. Ten years after the completion of the Poverty Inquiry's main report the problem of persistent poverty in Australia apparently remains as intractable as ever. This is recognised by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and our Government. Dr Bettina Cass, in her recent paper 'The Changing Face of Poverty in Australia' pointed out that the face of poverty in Australia is female. The majority of people who run the risk of being poor in Australia are women, especially women living alone or unmarried mothers.

The Institute of Family Studies showed that from 1978 to 1982 the number of sole parents in poverty-93 per cent of those parents were women-grew by more than 38 per cent. One in four income units in Australia is headed by a woman but women comprise one-half of all income units in poverty. A single parent with three children and receiving $165.65 a week is 20 per cent below the poverty line.

One of the most moving experiences for me since I became a member of parliament was meeting a delegation of women from the Council for the Single Mother and Her Child. They told members of the Caucus welfare committee about the terrible plight of single parents and their children. In 1972 the allowable income for a single parent was $20 per week, plus $6 for each child. In 1985 the allowable income for a single parent is $30 per week and still only $6 per child. In 1972 the consumer price index figure for the September quarter was 40.2; in September 1984 that figure had increased to 134. Twenty dollars in 1972 would be worth $67 in 1984 dollars. Similarly, $6 in 1972 would be worth $20 in 1984 dollars. So just to restore the allowable income to the value it had in 1972 it would be necessary to increase the means test free area to $67, plus $20 for each child.

As it stands now, a single parent with one child loses 50c in every dollar earned over the sum of $36 per week. This represents an effective marginal tax rate of 50 per cent. So on that meagre income these women enter that very high marginal tax rate area. Since the supporting parent's benefit and widow's pension for a single parent with one child is only $115.90 a week this effective marginal tax rate comes into operation when the family's total income is only $151.90 per week. In addition, there is also a means test on the supplementary rent allowance for which the allowable income is only $6 a week. The combined effect of such severe means tests is to lock single parents out of the work force or place intolerable economic pressure on them not to report their earnings.

The income tests and the taxation system operating together lock single parents, who are already on low incomes, into a poverty trap. The more they struggle to climb out of the trap by their own labours, the more they slip back into poverty. In other words, as a result of the combined effect of the income tests, taxation, costs of child care, transport and other costs incurred in participating in the work force, a person may be worse off by working.

The single parent is caught between fear and poverty. Often he or she has nowhere to turn but to the unscrupulous employers in the underground labour market. Some of these employers actually seek out single parents as potential employees and encourage them to work without reporting their earnings. One of the women from the Council for the Single Mother and Her Child told the committee that she was preparing to hand over her child to the State because she could not cope any longer on supporting mother's benefits. The cost to the State of supporting her child in the care of foster parents would be $350 a week, twice the amount of the supporting parent's benefit. Single parents who have the double task of rearing children and earning money in order to survive should not be penalised in this way and we in the Government must find a way to redress this highly regressive situation, particularly as it relates to women. Dr Bettina Cass stated:

The explanation of women's over-representation among the poor must be sought in women's discontinuous employment history-their relatively low pay when in work and the periods which married women and mothers spend at home providing services which give little financial reward. Measurements of women's poverty do not end, however, with the identification of poverty in women-headed income units. In aged couples and large, married couple families, in families with unemployed, sick and incapacitated male breadwinners there are also many poor women, very often taking up the burden of managing and stretching the family's inadequate resources.

Dr Cass points out how many women fall into this terrible trap of poverty. The unequal distribution of wealth in Australia places too heavy a burden on too many women. Our Government will work, through the social security legislation and through taxation reform, to relieve that burden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in the debate on the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which covers a whole range of social security and related issues. I must say that I was very interested in what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), had to say. In her speech she expressed concern about the poverty that is experienced by many people in Australia, particularly women. I think she is right. In percentage terms, women suffer a greater degree of poverty than perhaps do men. Nevertheless, there is still an all too large group of men who suffer from poverty also. In her speech she focused on the problem of the incomes of people in poverty. I bring to the attention of the House that it is not merely income deficiency which causes poverty. Sometimes poverty for an individual is a reflection of that individual's lack of economic independence. A woman, or indeed a man, can be living within a household that, viewed as a household, is affluent. Yet that individual can experience some, if not all, of the attributes of poverty, one of which is a lack of personal economic independence.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been concerned over the years about how members of the Government and the Australian Labor Party have failed to understand, when they look at the tax system and the effects and implications of the spouse rebate in the tax system, one of the features of the benefits conferred on families through the spouse rebate. It is true that the spouse rebate is a benefit to the taxpayer of the household, who is mostly a man, but who increasingly in many households is a woman. The benefit is provided by recognising the reduced taxable capacity of the taxpayer because the taxpayer is supporting not only himself or herself but also other members of a household-in the case of a spouse rebate, a husband or wife.

Some could argue-I support the view-that there are strong reasons why consideration should be given to cashing out the spouse rebate and paying it as a cash benefit to the person who would otherwise be the dependent member of the household, be it a woman or a man. Our social attitudes have changed over the years. This Parliament needs to recognise that that change has occurred. As a result of our social behaviour, all of us, for many years of our lives, live in households and in many economies where we contribute to and draw on the income of that household. Notwithstanding that fact we have come through a family household life experience in which we have been taught to be independent and we want personal economic independence.

It is interesting that when men and women reach the age of retirement we do not ask them whether they live in a single income household and, if they do, pay the pension only to the nominal bread winner of that household. When they reach the age of retirement and, through age, become eligible for the age pension, we pay them each an age pension and give to each some degree of economic independence. I think that is an issue that needs to be addressed and understood more fully than it is. I also recognise that what the previous speaker had to say about the level of benefits is an important matter that needs to be considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —To single parents.

—And the position of the single parent is an important one. I was fascinated to hear the previous speaker talk about the marginal effective tax rate and the implications of putting a means test, whether it is an income test, assets test or both, on top of a tax test. I think we need to look at it in a wholistic way and we should not try to delude the Australian people by making them believe that pensioners are well off because they have withdrawal rates through the means test on incomes of 50c in the dollar, when in fact large numbers of them have withdrawal rates higher then those of the highest taxpayers in the land. When we put on top of the incomes test the tax liability of so many pensioners, the withdrawal rate, in some cases of two parent households, can be in excess of 80c in the dollar; for others as high as 65c in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are concerned about helping people in greatest need, we need to ask ourselves what is the effect on social behaviour of imposing upon pensioners or prospective pensioners a tax effective withdrawal rate at the highest marginal tax rates in the land. I am glad that members of the Labor Party are beginning to look at the combined effect of income tests which they so readily support with the liability that is imposed by another test on income through the Income Tax Assessment Act. I believe that we need to integrate our social security and tax systems and reduce the effective marginal tax rates imposed upon low income individuals and low income households in a way that does enable them to lift themselves off the poverty line.

It is true that the system does provide poverty traps that prevent people getting out of poverty. It is not only the tax effect of the combined implications of the income test and income tax that does it; it is also the effect of providing to children of social security beneficiaries income entitlements or child benefits-not because they have children but because they are unemployed or because they are supporting parents. If they become employed or if they cease to be supporting parents, they lose the child benefits. This creates yet another poverty trap.

The previous speaker drew attention to the fact that a child in public child welfare care might cost governments hundreds of dollars per week. If the social security tax system is to acknowledge the cost of dependent children and if we are to prevent those costs occurring, we need to recognise the cost that all families-be they those of supporting parents, two-parent families, low income, middle income or high income families-incur in supporting other individuals who, if they were not supported, by private sector social security, would become a burden on the State. So we need to address that question too as we approach the issue of tax reform.

I have been greatly concerned that as this taxation debate has proceeded there has been little comment from members of the Government as to the reform that might be needed within the income tax system itself. The debate has focused upon the possible switch of the mix between direct income taxes and indirect, sales and other similar taxes. Little attention appears to have been given by the Government to the need to reform the income tax system. This Parliament and Government must ask whether income taxes should be imposed on the basis of capacity to pay, and, if so, what are the factors that will be brought into account in determining capacity to pay. Is it merely a function of the income of the individual or are the individual circumstances to be looked at in terms of the income or lack of income of the household of which that taxpaying individual is a member? Is it also to take account of or to ignore the extent to which the taxpaying individual is supporting children and a dependent spouse or are they going to be regarded by the Labor Government as mere indulgences and luxuries that the person who marries and supports a totally dependent spouse must pay for 100c in the dollar, the same being true of their choice to have children?

I happen to believe that we need a tax system in the personal income tax area that is far more sensitive and which recognises more fully the role discharged by people in the private sector in supporting individuals who, if they were not supported by individual taxpayers, would fall back and have to be supported by the taxpayer in general through the social security system. The more people we can encourage to support themselves and reward for their efforts in trying to support themselves, their spouses and their children, the more there will be available to direct to those who are in real and genuine need. But the tax and social security systems we have today destroy all those incentives and in so many areas of their operation encourage family breakdown, encourage people to dissipate their assets and encourage current day spending rather than providing for future possible needs. I hope that some members of the Labor Party will take up what the previous speaker said and be concerned about those who are genuinely poor. But in expressing that concern I hope they recognise that the people who are genuinely poor can be more greatly assisted if others are encouraged and rewarded for providing for themselves. The fact that they provide for themselves and others should be recognised through the tax and social security systems. This can be done only by reducing and in some cases by abolishing income tests which have the effect of increasing the effective marginal tax rate about which the previous speaker spoke and expressed her concern.

There are two elements of the Bill unrelated to social security that I want to bring to the attention of the House and about which I express my concern. I am deeply worried about the extension of the compensation legislation that will confer rights upon Commonwealth employees who, if they are members of unions and go to a meeting in what they claim to be the course of their union responsibilities, can still be regarded as being on duty in the Public Service. The Bill does not spell out the limits for those sorts of meetings. Will it enable union officials who, out of their own interest join the Labor Party, for example, and attend Labor Party branch meetings and who, upon returning home after such meetings, are involved in an accident, then to be entitled to workers compensation when other members attending that meeting are not so benefited?

The second area with respect to which I want to express concern is the circumstances in which invalidity pensions are to continue to be available. Increasing proportions of our population are employed by the public sector, a trend which I think needs to be reversed. Even if it were reversed, there would still be a substantial number of public sector employees. This legislation seeks to give an entitlement to an employee who is partially incapacitated. I assume that that means that the employee is not 85 per cent incapacitated, which is the test that the average Australian invalid pensioner has to satisfy before being entitled to a social security pension. A partially incapacitated employee who cannot find work is entitled to continue to receive a full pension.

I believe that the test that should be applied to eligibility for such a benefit is the test that would be applied to the whole community. I do not believe that public servants administering the Social Security Department should be in the position of saying to the average Australian citizen who, as a result of accident, applies for an invalid pension: 'You are not incapacitated to the extent of 85 per cent. Therefore, go out and find a job.' So many people in that position cannot find jobs in today's employment market. They cannot go back to the Department of Social Security and say: 'I know I am not 85 per cent incapacitated for work. I have tried to get a job but every employer I have approached knows that I have an injury and no one will employ me. Please give me an invalid pension.' Unless the Government is prepared to look at that position and say that those people should be entitled to a full invalid pension, I do not believe that Commonwealth employees should be entitled to greater concessions in terms of invalid compensation pensions. I think those people, like every other Australian, should fall back on the generalised social security safety net and get the benefits that are available in that area. I think it is unfair that the taxpayer should be required to pay additional benefits to Commonwealth employees when presumably the Government does not think the nation can afford to make such benefits available to everyone.

I conclude my remarks by referring to means tests in general, and I wish to make some points of principle. Means tests, in my view, are counter-productive. They rarely, if ever, provide greater help to those in need than would be available under a universal pension scheme. Because means tests destroy incentive and penalise those who strive for self-reliance, more and more become victims of what are, in effect, the wealth tax imposed by the assets test, or the supertax on income imposed by the income test, and the poverty traps inherent in all means-tested pensions. Means tests distort individual choice and actions in ways far more significant than many will concede. They affect people's patterns of expenditure and saving. They distort rational economic behaviour.

There is no doubt that means and assets tests cause people to reduce their savings effort; to dissipate assets and the present and future income potential of such assets, to purchase housing or fast-depreciating consumer goods; and to use up their savings or potential savings on consumption expenditure at levels they would not incur if there was a reward for deferring expenditure, perhaps for use in their old age. It is clear that people adjust their affairs to their best advantage. The expectation of or entitlement to a non-contributory universal age pension would, in my view, eliminate the disincentive to save caused by the operation of means tests on income and assets.

Choice and individual responsibility go together. They are intrinsic to the philosophy of a truly democratic society. When an individual is free to choose the directions he wishes to follow in his future life, most recognise that with this freedom goes the desire and responsiblity to strive for self-reliance. These ideals of choice and individual responsibility must be tempered by compassion. Compassion properly dictates that society must accept responsibility for ensuring that no Australian falls below the basic minimum standard of living. It is, however, important that society's compassion be expressed in ways which maximise rather than minimise the freedom of choice and the capacity of individuals to achieve self-reliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested in some of the views put by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), particularly in relation to income tax. He expressed some personal views, which I think should be canvassed more widely. Certainly, he would have that opportunity if only his Party leader would accept the invitation extended to him to come to the tax summit and put the Liberal Party's views on taxation. It is a pity, in my view, that the Liberal Party will not take up that offer. If it really wanted to make a constructive contribution to the tax debate it would have the opportunity. I agree with the honourable member for Sturt that there is a need for an overhaul of the social security and taxation systems. The Government is addressing directly the taxation system with the tax summit in July. We have to deal with social security in a piecemeal fashion, mainly because we cannot rely on bipartisan support from the Opposition to look at the provisions in the Social Security Act in any rational manner. We have seen in the past that Opposition members are nothing more than political opportunists who will try to scare anybody if it will get a vote for them.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Sturt also said that means tests and assets tests destroy incentive. He is right. Any pension scheme with an assets test or a means test does. The system that we have now destroys incentive. There is absolutely no incentive for anybody to make provision for his retirement if it excludes him from the pension paid to everybody else. We have had that system since 1951. Prior to that we had the embryo of a national superannuation scheme to which the honourable member for Sturt alluded but that changed in 1951 when the present pension system was introduced. It was a safety net for those people who did not have the capacity to make provision for their retirement.

We have not changed that system. The assets test was a feature of the system in 1951. In fact, it was in force from 1908 until 1976. It was an easy political decision to abolish the assets test in 1976. To bring some integrity back into the pension system it has to have an assets test; otherwise we have the spectre of which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) told us with millionaires receiving the pension. They get money at the expense of people who are living on nothing more than the pension, who have no assets and are forced into the private rental market with nothing more than their pensions. There is something obscene about that. The honourable member talked about a national superannuation scheme. I agree with him that there is nothing more urgent in providing for our future retirement schemes than a national superannuation scheme. Only one government in recent times has looked at that matter and it was not a Liberal government.

The Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill before us tonight makes a few significant advances in the field of social security. I will touch on some of them. The new enterprise incentive scheme is designed to encourage and assist unemployed people in creating and developing business initiatives which will generate permanent employment. It is an excellent employment creation initiative by this Government which aims to provide incentive and support for unemployed people who have the capacity and drive to organise themselves into a small business. It is an employment creation scheme based on the principle of promoting and encouraging self-sufficiency. It is a rational and efficient use of public money.

The scheme was endorsed in principle by the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs, which recognised the need for income support to be provided during the establishment of self-generating business projects. A constituent of mine has sought alternative solutions to the problem of unemployment. I know that this scheme will be of assistance to her. As a graduate from a tertiary institution she was unable to find work. She was not satisfied with simply receiving the unemployment benefit fortnightly and began to consider ways in which she could productively use her time and generate an income for herself. Since then she has set up a small store selling clothes and craft goods which she designs and makes herself. The capital and ongoing costs of running the business are a drain on her limited savings. Because it takes time to attract customers there is a delay between setting up and making an adequate profit. For the first couple of months she ran at a loss.

The catch-22 situation comes in because she is not now unemployed. Because she has started a business she is considered to be employed, although she is not earning an income. As I said before, in setting up the business she is running at a loss. However, she is considered to be employed and is not entitled to the unemployment benefit. Because she needs an income, she faces the prospect of having to close the business in order to requalify for the unemployment benefit. It would be a great pity if this initiative and potentially successful enterprise were strangled.

This Bill will allow an income supplement to be paid to people like my constituent who, having been receiving the unemployment benefit, are now establishing a small business concern for themselves. I am sure that many other people in Australia will be assisted by that measure. Many people in receipt of the unemployment benefit at the moment can show the initiative to start small businesses, whether they are cottage industries or any other initiative that they might like to turn their talents to, and make themselves self-sufficient. Certainly, I welcome that part of the legislation before us tonight.

Another aspect of the legislation complements some of the legislation we brought in last year. It refers to the payment of Commonwealth nursing home benefits during periods when patients are temporarily absent from nursing homes. I know from experience that elderly people in my electorate who are confined to nursing homes like to get away from the nursing home for holidays with their families. Until last year, if they left the nursing home the Commonwealth benefit that was paid to them was stopped, and therefore they had to pay for the shortfall in Commonwealth benefit as well as for the additional benefit to the nursing home. They faced the cost of going out of the nursing home and also the cost of the Commonwealth supplement. We have now overcome that difficulty to the extent that those people can get away from the nursing home and have a holiday with their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sensible amendment.

—It is a sensible amendment, as the honourable member for Stirling said. It is complementary to the amendment we made last year for the respite care bed subsidy, which was introduced at that time to encourage the provision of respite care in approved hostels. That was an initiative to help those who care at home for elderly family members and who at times need a break. Those people can now have their relatives looked after in a nursing home and at the same time people who reside in nursing homes permanently can spend some time with their families. So this aspect of the legislation is very complementary to the legislation we brought in last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to touch on something which I believe we will need to address with much urgency. I refer to the projected costs of social security in the future. I have with me some figures that were given to me by the Parliamentary Library Research Service based on a projection of the population in the year 2001 and the costs therein of providing the services which are currently provided under the Social Security Act. A couple of assumptions are made in these figures. The first assumption is that the percentage of the aged in the population will remain constant. We know that that is wrong because the number of aged in our community is increasing. On that criterion these figures are quite conservative.

The second assumption is that the percentage of unemployed, which is currently about 8 per cent, will remain constant. We hope that that does not happen but, for the sake of the argument, we will assume that the amount expended on the unemployment benefit in 2001 is the same as it is now. The total estimated expenditure this year for the age, invalid, family allowance, widows', supporting parents' and unemployment benefits is $13,687m. If we project that forward in current value to the year 2001 we see that $17,140m will be needed. That is an increase of about 25 per cent on what we are currently spending. The total number of people of pensionable age is currently 1,380,000; in 2001 it will climb to 1,840,000. The total number of social security beneficiaries this year is 2,614,000 and my projected figure for the year 2001 is 3,325,000. The cost of providing social security services will escalate quite rapidly, and it is for this reason that in the last Parliament the Government introduced an assets test to limit the amount of payments going out.

There is also the question of social equity which I touched on before. We think it is obscene that millionaires should be receiving pensions and competing for scarce resources with pensioners who have nothing but the pension cheque to provide for their day-to-day living. There is only one alternative if the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is dinkum about repealing the assets test. It should be remembered that in the current financial year we will save about $105m. We do not know what the figure will be in three years time, but it will be significantly more. If that assets test is scrapped, one of two things will happen; taxes will have to go up to provide the pension for those millionaires who do not need it, or the pension will have to go down for people who are living on nothing more than the pension and do need it. That is the choice which will confront the Opposition. I would be interested to hear any answer it might put up at any time as to which of those two choices it will present to the people when next we go to the polls. Certainly the Opposition has gained some political mileage out of the matter, but it has not based its argument on any sort of social equity or economics. It is purely political expediency that has forced the Opposition to adopt the tactics it has, and the fact that it still adopts those tactics does it no credit.

I conclude by saying that the Labor Government has, since its re-election in December 1984, attached a great deal of significance to reforming the social security system. I am a little disappointed that we cannot do it in a comprehensive way, but that would need the support of both sides of this House. I do not think we will get it; therefore the system will have to be changed by the piecemeal provisions that we are bringing in. I hope that the Opposition, when it does get a new leader, gets a leader who has the guts actually to recognise the problems and to recognise a bit of economic reality and who will say to the Government: 'Let's sit down and talk about the serious problems that are confronting our nation'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill contains a provision, amongst others, which will ensure that veterans who had the right of appeal to specified bodies under the original legislation will now have rights of appeal to corresponding bodies under the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1984. It will also allow the Repatriation Commission to delegate powers, similar to those granted to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, to the Public Service to act as its agent. These provisions in themselves are welcome. However, in the context of a package affecting veterans entitlements, we can see an entirely different picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) gave what were thought by ex-service organisations to be gilt edged guarantees to consult fully, those organisations were destined to be disappointed once again. The promised talks never took place and yet another solemn undertaking went by the board. Never mind the Minister's repeated assurances, never mind the Prime Minister's confirmation. Yet again his word and the collective word of the Government have been broken by the introduction of this Bill and other Bills this week. No one should have been surprised that yet another promise was broken, but many lived in the hope that even this Prime Minister would not break his promise of full consultation before the benefits of those who have served their nation were materially changed.

When we think of the length to which the Government goes to consult with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the captains of industry on matters which they are not elected to speak about on behalf of the wider community, we begin to learn something of the Government's priorities. Its great deception lies not only in its failure to consult as promised but also in the separation of the provisions of this Bill from the as yet unseen Veterans' Entitlements Bill. Ex-service organisations had every reason to expect that the entitlements Bill would include, but not necessarily be limited to, the measures in the Bill before the House tonight. That was the reasonable expectation of and the promise given to the elected representatives of Australian ex-service men and women. What did they get instead for their trust in what they mistakenly thought was the solemn word of the Prime Minister and his Minister? They were double-crossed. It is as simple as that. Honourable men and women who served their country in times of armed conflict have been double-crossed by a government that once pretended to govern for all Australians, and all for what? It has happened for want of a chance to consult and, if warranted, present a case.

Australians could be forgiven for thinking that the unilateral disarmers in the mad Left of the Australian Labor Party have not just been successful in going a great part of the way towards destroying our contemporary defence capabilities; they want to make it retrospective. They want ex-service men and women who have already served Australia to be deprived of a say even in the recognition this Government gives to their sacrifices and to the sacrifices made by their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are specialists in retrospectivity.

—They are specialists in retrospectivity, but they have sunk to new depths in this case. The ex-service men and women of Australia do not demand to be put in the privileged position of the ACTU, although they deserve to be treated much better. They cannot go on strike and would not do so if they could. That is probably why they will not be given the privileged treatment the trade unions enjoy under this socialist Government. The reward for moderate and reasoned behaviour is the double-cross. On top of that, what must surely be the final and ultimate insult to our ex-service personnel. It is that this bill is to be part of the Government's so-called cost cutting mini-Budget. According to the rationale offered by the Government, the Bill is not before us because it is right or equitable or, primarily, because the existing legislation is over- generous. What then is the catalyst for the Bill? It is part of a cost cutting program. Most decent Australians would think that if extravagant government spending is to be cut many billions of dollars could be cut before touching ex-service and war widows' pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is more to the Government's reasons than cost cutting, why does it not consult? After all, the Government has made much of its consultation with the unions on the prices and incomes accord. It has made a big deal out of its consultation with the union and corporate gentry at the National Economic Summit Conference. It has made a feast out of its consultation with the ACTU on the 1983 and 1984 Budgets. No doubt, this will happen in respect of the 1985 Budget. The Government has made a virtue out of consultation with the Aboriginal people on the issue of land rights. It has made a feast out of relationships with Uncle Tom Cobbleigh and all on all sorts of less worthy causes. Under this mob we can forget consultation, promised or not, with ex-service organisations on matters integral to the very reason for the existence of those representative organisations.

One can be forgiven for wondering about the priorities of this Government. It seems that with this Bill, with Medicare and with means and assets testing of pensioners, those who served their country well are being singled out for more than a fair share of attention. It is not that the Government is wrong on every score, because it is not. The concentration-the volume if you like-of benefit cuts culminates in a transfer of wealth not from the rich but from the elderly, the retirees and those on fixed incomes to others who are not, in many cases, worse off.

To go even further, as the Government does in this Bill, without the promised consultation is to give further emphasis to the uncertain and unclear intentions of this Government. Given the repeated-albeit at election time-utterances by this increasingly pathetic Prime Minister, one would have thought the assault on the elderly would have finished with the means test on the pensions of those aged 70 and over. After all, the Prime Minister's promise was not to take money out of pensioners' cheques. But it did not stop there. Next came Medicare, and then the assets test.

Now, we witness the attack on the benefits of ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen. That attack has been spread over four or five separate Bills brought into this Parliament in the last couple of days, as distinct from one Bill in the promised form of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill-a Bill which we have not even sighted. It is true that the provisions in the Bill that is now before us are mild and unobjectionable in themselves, but we must look beyond that if we are better to understand the duplicity of the Government in its deliberate avoidance of consultation with ex-service organisations. This is but one separate Bill of four or five, each of which in total or in part makes inroads into the long-accepted standards of assistance which successive Commonwealth governments have given to those ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen who have proudly and honourably served Australia.

In the past few days we have seen an omnibus Bill, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, amending repatriation law and veterans' entitlements; the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill; and the Defence Re-establishment Amendment Bill. However, we have not even seen the Veterans' Entitlements Bill which, it was promised, would be available over the winter break to permit study and consultation with ex-service representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did that happen?

—No, of course it did not. However, we still have less that 24 hours and something might come in at the last minute. The Government will certainly stifle debate on that Bill and stifle any preconsideration of it in this Parliament, as it has done with a number of measures. There are about 50 reports outstanding that will not be debated this session-and those reports are for the year ending 1983-84. Honourable members will not even get to talk about those reports until the Budget session some time after August, if we get to debate them at all. We have not seen the Bill to which I have referred because most of those provisions have been hived off. They have been hived off and salted away in a multiplicity of Bills, in a deliberate attempt to divert attention from the Prime Minister's 'solemn' undertaking to consult representatives of our ex-service men and women.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not necessarily complain at the provisions of this Bill as they affect veterans. Our complaint is that the Government has failed to consult, despite repeated promises by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) who is very conveniently flipping away somewhere overseas and having a marvellous time. The Government has failed, despite the Prime Minister's undertaking, to give that consultation the attention that it deserves. We might agree with all or most of the provisions in each of those Bills affecting veterans which have come before this Parliament, or will do so. But we will never agree to a broken undertaking given to ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen or representatives to consult. We will never agree with that sort of behaviour, although we are used to it following the 100 or more broken promises of the Prime Minister since the 1983 election. He has already built up a formidable tally of broken promises since the last election but we will never agree to cop the Government taking that sort of attitude towards the representatives of the people who have served this country proudly. For those reasons I support the amendment. I only wish that I had the opportunity to debate the other measures-particularly the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill-that last night were guillotined through the House so crudely and without due regard to the wishes of this Parliament.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Braithwaite's amendment) stand part of the question.

I mentioned in the speech I made on the second reading why we take this view. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my earlier speech I referred to the fact that for several reasons we find these three clauses objectionable. One is, again, that they seek to give a privileged position to Commonwealth employees over the course of an ordinary recess. There are enough legal precedents in the States and the Commonwealth to indicate what is an ordinary recess, and to indicate that, where the master-servant relationship exists, accidents within that ordinary recess have been covered, as far as cases heard and decisions given are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there is no definition of 'ordinary recess', there is a series of exemptions, but those exemptions do not cover problems that we find within the amendment. For instance, anybody on an ordinary recess without his master's approval at this moment could take an unacceptable risk, or even an extreme risk, or could even wilfully expose himself to danger during that recess, and no matter what that risk was, he would be covered because there is no particular exemption in the legislation.

As to clause 35, we go further. the reason we object to the definition of trade union is that, again, trade union members are given a position of privilege under this clause. An employee of the Commonwealth who is also a union official can go about the work of the trade union, attend a meeting of the Australian Labor Party, or even perhaps, where it is in the course of his duties relating to the representation of the interests of one or more of the employees, actually take part in a picket line out of hours, and any damage or accident that occurred would be covered under the legislation. As far as I am concerned, trade unions should be responsible for their own compensation by way of what is available to them under normal circumstances in the private sector and should not have to rely on these provisions. One must ask: Now that trade unions are in it, who else will infiltrate this grand and generous scheme, expenditure on which has gone up eight times in the last 10 years? So, we object to that aspect.

Clause 36 causes no great problem because, if the clause is taken out of the amending Bill, we will revert to the principal Act and, as far as we are concerned, the principal Act can stand on its own two feet. If we treat partially incapacitated persons who cannot readily find work as totally incapacitated we will be allowing them, because they are in Commonwealth employment, to claim compensation which is basically twice the amount available by way of invalid pensions or unemployment benefits to people in similar situations outside that employment. We believe again that there is no case for putting further privileges in the way of the Public Service and that the compensation available to such employees should be related to what is available in the public sector. For those reasons, we will oppose clauses 35, 36 and 37.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, as the hour is late, I want to speak on clause 81 of the Bill and my comments will go right through to clause 98. These, effectively, are the amendments to the Repatriation Act. Last night in this House I made the point in the debate on the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill that this Government had broken a firm and solemn commitment to consult with the Returned Services League and the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council on any substantive amendments involving entitlements. I now find that--
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Unless I am mistaken the honourable member is not talking to the present Bill and I ask that his attention be drawn to that fact.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Denison is speaking collectively to the clauses that he has mentioned.
—I am speaking to clauses 81 through to 98. If the honourable member for Barton would like me to read the headnotes I will do so. The first states:

SPEECH.PARA: PART XIII-AMENDMENTS OF THE REPATRIATION ACT 1973
That relates to clauses 81, 82 and 83. The next headnote states:
PART XIV- AMENDMENT OF THE REPATRIATION (FAR EAST STRATEGIC RESERVE) ACT 1956
That relates to clauses 84 and 85. The next headnote states:
PART XV-AMENDMENTS OF THE REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT ACT 1984
That relates to clauses 86 to 96. Last but not least, the next headnote states:
PART XVI-AMENDMENT OF THE REPATRIATION (SPECIAL OVERSEAS SERVICE) ACT 1962

That relates to clauses 97 and 98. If I am not speaking to those clauses, I am not here. The honourable member for Barton ought at least to look at the Bill before he takes points of order which have no substance at all. The point I make is that today I found out to my horror that in addition to this Government breaching a solid commitment to consult with the RSL and the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council in relation to the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which was rushed through this chamber at midnight last night, with barely 45 minutes in which to debate the welfare of 650,000 Australian veterans, there has been no consultation in relation to these clauses.

What do we find when we look at these clauses? There is some magic stuff in them. I give honourable members an example. In some cases the clause will backdate provisions to 1973. I made an inquiry a few moments ago as to how many members of this chamber were members in 1973. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested to know that the number is fewer than 30. As I have said, clauses are going through which are backdating provisions to 1973. Mr Deputy Chairman, you were a member of his chamber in 1973, but there are quite a few who were not. I wonder whether this Government has completely taken leave of its senses. The plain fact is that, for the second time in less than 24 hours, the Government has betrayed 650,000 Australian ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen. For the second time in 24 hours it has broken a solemn commitment given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to consult with the RSL and the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council on substantive amendments affecting their entitlements. Over the winter recess every member of every RSL club in Australia will come to know that this was the Government which, in 24 hours, broke a tradition of 65 years. The Government has betrayed the men and women and their dependants of $1.4m in all.
Government members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite think it is funny. I can say that their days are numbered. The Government is already being called the Nescafe Government-43 beans in every cup. Forty-three per cent is about its proper rating, but the rating will drop much lower. Shame on the Government for the fact that for the second time in 24 hours it has betrayed 650,000 Australian ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen.

SPEECH.PARA: Last but not least, I remind members of the Government that last night the Government destroyed section 47 of the Repatriation Act which was the famous Evatt amendment-a 30-year campaign by Dr H. V. Evatt which in turn honoured commitments by true Labor Prime Ministers, the late John Curtin and the late Ben Chifley. I think the people in the community will realise that the Government is quite hypocritical in relation to repatriation matters. It will betray again and again until it is thrown out of office, and that will be at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received the following message from the Senate acquainting the House of a resolution concerning the Commonwealth Parliament's continuing participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate, recognizing the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:
(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention-

(a) a Delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament take part in the deliberations of the Convention, and comprise 12 members of the Parliament of whom 5 shall be members of the Senate and 7 shall be members of the House of Representatives;
(b) the 5 members of the Senate comprise 2 members of the Australian Labor Party, 2 members of the Opposition and one member of the Australian Democrats.
(2) That-
(a) 2 Senators being members of the Australian Labor Party, nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 Senators being members of the Opposition, nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one Senator being a member of the Australian Democrats, nominated by the Leader of that Party in the Senate,
be members of the Delegation.
(3) That the Prime Minister or his nominee be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition or his nominee be the Deputy Leader.
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if-
(a) he ceases to be a member of the Commonwealth Parliament;
(b) the House of Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

(5) That where, because of illness or any other cause, a member of the Delegation is not available to attend a meeting, or part of a meeting, of the Convention, the Leader or senior available member of that member's Party may nominate an alternative member and the member so nominated shall be a member of the Delegation for that meeting, or that part of that meeting.

(6) That, in the event of a member of the Delegation ceasing to be such a member, the Leader of that member's Party in the House from which that member was drawn may nominate another member (being a member of the House of which the first-mentioned member is or was a member) to replace the first-mentioned member.

(7) That the Leader of the Delegation from time to time make a report for presentation to each house of the Parliament on matters arising out of the Convention, and that the Deputy Leader of the Delegation may make an accompanying report.
The Senate requests that the House of Representatives reconsider the Resolution transmitted to the Senate by Message No. 111.
