SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled 'The Inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission: Final Report'. The report incorporates a dissenting report. I also present a copy of the minutes of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.
Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave-proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report presented by the Standing Committee on Expenditure is a final report of the inquiry which the Committee undertook into the Aboriginal Development Commission. I guess in compiling this report the Committee had to consider a number of matters which one could say go to the heart of the role and function of parliamentary committees. I suppose that if one looks at those things in abbreviation one could say that committees can either set out to scapegoat or to cause reform. I would come heavily down on the side of committees setting out to cause reform. In the Committee's first report-our interim report-we made 35 recommendations for changes in the activities of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I understand that the Government will accept those recommendations. I believe that the Committee, in making those recommendations and the Department, the Commission and the Government in their responses have shown that parliamentary committees can do a lot to cause reform of both bureaucracy and the bureaucratic system.

SPEECH.PARA: During the course of the inquiry a number of rather wild allegations were made on a number of matters by various people. A number of witnesses pointed out to the Committee that in the area of Aboriginal affairs backbiting seems to be as endemic as it is in political parties. Indeed, I guess that there might even be more backbiting, calumny and detraction in Aboriginal affairs than there is in political parties. The Committee then had to decide how to weigh the evidence that was before it. We had come to some fairly broad conclusions on the administrative changes that should be made in the Commission but we had to look at the allegations that were made against individuals. To assist the Committee in doing that we sought the advice of a Queen's Counsel, Mr John Coombs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wouldn't you follow his advice? Why did you ignore the QC?
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher will cease interjecting. That is the second time I have had to speak to him.

—Members of the Opposition seem interested in what Mr Coombs had to say. Of course, the honourable member for Fisher was a member of the Committee and he is well aware of what Mr Coombs said. Mr Coombs made a number of recommendations to the Committee and in considering his advice-what the Committee sought from Mr Coombs was advice; not direction, not a solution, but advice on how some matters should be handled-the Committee had to decide whether it would give people against whom allegations were made the chance to rebut those allegations. Many honourable members opposite may think that one should not bother to give people against whom an accusation is made the chance to rebut the allegations. Most of the members of the Committee were not of that view.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members need to be aware that some of the allegations were rather flamboyant and the Committee decided that the best way to approach those allegations was to hear them in camera. As members who have served on parliamentary committees will know, we then came across difficulties with the Standing Orders of the House in that if a committee hears an allegation against a person in camera, the committee and the members of that committee, both severally and individually, are unable to communicate to the accused person what the accusations are that are made against him. So the Committee decided that there had to be a mechanism to ask the people about whom allegations were made whether they had in fact done what they were accused of doing. I think that is what any fair-minded person would want; in fact, it seems to be at the root of law in Australia. It also seems to be what a lot of people have said things about. For the benefit of the House I would like to quote from a book called Parliament and the Bureaucracy which is edited by J. R. Nethercote. In that book the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) had this to say about parliamentary committees:

I find myself in agreement with those who have long expressed concern about parliamentary committees with powers of an inquisitorial brand over citizens. What the New South Wales Bar Council said ten years ago remains correct today and recent debates on the inquiry by the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations into the Asia Dairy Corporation have reminded us of it.
The honourable member then went on to say:
The Bar Council said:

It is the view of the Bar Council that this type of investigation is not a proper activity of a parliamentary committee. Investigation of public scandals, the collapse of large financial enterprises, the procedures and organisation of occupational, political or social groups should be placed in the hands of persons with adequate training in the exercise of the judicial function. In such investigations, persons whose future credit is endangered should be given the rights of an accused person under the law. Those rights, in the view of the Council, should be given by Statute and should not be dependent upon the goodwill of any investigating body. If, however, Parliamentary Committees are, in the future, to perform tasks such as those given to the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange, the Bar Council is strongly of the opinion that adequate safeguards for persons called before such committees should be ensured by Statute.

That is what the honourable member for Wentworth had to say about giving natural justice to those who are accused before parliamentary committees. However, it is interesting to see that some of his colleagues on the Committee were not of that persuasion. One could go further and see what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) had to say about giving a person who is accused the chance of natural justice. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, in a debate in this House on 28 February 1984 in relation to the Cross Special Commission of Inquiry into Certain Allegations by the Rt. Hon. Ian McCahon Sinclair and the allegations made against the then Deputy Leader of the National Party, said:

. . . where a person exercises the kind of duties that His Honour was exercising and who proposes to criticise or to make adverse findings of a substantial nature against a person in the position of Deputy Leader of the National Party, he is bound by the rules of natural justice to put the substance of what he proposes to say to the person who will be affected and get that person's answer.

If it is good enough for that rule to apply to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair)-I believe most emphatically that it should-it is most certainly good enough for it to apply to any and every person who is accused of anything before a parliamentary committee. It is unfortunate that some of the members of the Committee did not believe that that basic element of justice should prevail. I mentioned the Leader of the National Party. It is interesting to have his view on this matter, I say again that I support the contention of the Leader of the National Party. In an essay in the same book Parliament and the Bureaucracy, the right honourable member for New England stated:

Certainly in considering parliamentary privilege the making of unsubstantiated allegations in parliament and the treatment of witnesses without the traditional procedures adopted by courts of law designed to guard against unfairness to a witness are matters of concern.

It was a matter of great concern to the members of the Committee that the people against whom these allegations were made should have had the right of rebuttal. There was opposition on the Committee to that. I am pleased to say that the people who believed that natural justice should prevail were successful. The Committee heard evidence from the people who were accused. The overwhelming consensus of the Committee to that evidence was that any fair-minded person would accept the word of the people who gave evidence and the Committee came to that view.

Some members of the Opposition raised the question of who was responsible. Should we look to see who is responsible in these matters? We should remember that some members of the Committee in a dissenting report called for a judicial inquiry into the whole area of Aboriginal affairs. The honourable member for Fisher was very keen that this should be done. The honourable member for Fisher, as a new member of this House, might not have a great understanding of the system in this House. This Parliament runs on the Westminster system. Last week members of the Opposition accused the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) of being responsible and having to take responsibility for what happened at the National Aboriginal Conference. The Minister stood up in this Parliament and said that he did take responsibility. I put it to honourable members that the close relationship the NAC has with the Minister in regard to his responsibilities is far less of a close relationship than the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has with the Aboriginal Development Commission.

The dissenting report was signed by a number of members of the Opposition, including the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). Surely, in calling for a judicial inquiry, the honourable member for Sturt is not seriously asking this House to inquire into the activities of the portfolio while he was the Minister? That is the fact. The allegations that were placed before this Committee in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission all relate to events which occurred prior to this Government coming to office. The previous Minister, who was responsible under the Westminster system for the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, is the present Deputy Chairman of the Committee who called for a judicial inquiry. Under the Opposition's proposal, he would be the chief witness.

It is rather stupid for us even to consider the trashy suggestion that there should be a judicial inquiry. The Committee has heard and weighed the evidence. The Committee has attempted to give people natural justice. We have tried to adopt what the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, suggested should be the rule that applied to the Leader of the National Party. We have adopted the rule that the honourable member for Wentworth suggested should have applied during the Asia Dairy inquiry. At least during that inquiry, honourable members will recall, when allegations were being made against a Minister the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations invited the Minister to give evidence. The Minister declined, but at least the Committee invited him to give evidence.

In the present circumstances some members of the Committee were not the least bit interested even in allowing the people who were accused to know what had been said against them. If we had allowed that situation to continue we would have found that tonight after midnight, this House would have adopted this report and neither of the people against whom the accusations were made would have had a clue what the report was about or what the allegations against them were. If the Committee had not sought the opinions and evidence of the people against whom the accusations were made, tomorrow morning they probably would have woken up to television cameras and a reporter asking: 'Have you heard what a parliamentary committee said about you?' If that is the sort of justice that the dissenters to this report want to give, it is not the sort of justice I want to have any part of. The final word on this matter should go to the gentleman who gave the Committee its advice, Mr John Coombs, QC.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is this? This is a disgrace.

—The Opposition seems very keen to see that the Committee should concur with what Mr Coombs said. Unfortunately, the Opposition will not like what Mr Coombs said. As it was my right to do under the Standing Orders, I circulated to Mr Coombs, who was a consultant to the Committee, a copy of the draft report. Mr Coombs has responded to me today in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr McLeay,--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite should listen to me. This will take the wind out of their sails. I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: At your request I have read, in confidence, the draft of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in respect of its inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission, bearing the date May 1985. Having regard to the further investigations conducted by the Committee and to the convincing explanations and denials given by Mr Perkins and Mr O'Brien, I see no reason to disagree with the Committee's decision not to pursue the various allegations further beyond the current investigations by appropriate authorities in respect of the allegations against Mr O'Brien.
With kind regards,
J. COOMBS, QC
That, most assuredly, should be the final word on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I recognise that emotions are running fairly high on this issue and that tempers are getting a bit frayed. It is also getting late. I request that honourable members restrain themselves and listen to the honourable member for O'Connor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report on the Aboriginal Development Commission by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure has come about because of a recommendation 1.10 of the previous interim report of the inquiry into this matter in which the Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other matters brought to the attention of the Committee have involved serious allegations of mal-administration which in some instances may lead to criminal prosecution.

That matter was not resolved before the election and the Committee, once reconstituted, started to meet on this matter. I think that the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) protests too much. He seems particularly concerned with defending the position of his side of politics. All the final decisions of this Committee were taken by a vote. The Opposition members constantly opposed the proposals of the draft report and of course we were voted down on each occasion. The first words in clause 1 of the dissenting final report state:
Those of us making this dissenting report recommend that there should be a comprehensive judicial inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker-
—That is exactly what the honourable member for Grayndler took half of his time to talk about.
—Will the honourable gentleman resume his seat please. The honourable member for Charlton has a point of order.
—I seek your advice, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—Sit down, Bob. Your are a disgrace. You are as bad as Ros Kelly. Sit down.
—You are going to bash women, are you?
—Shut up. You will do first, you stupid man.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. If he does not heed the Chair, he is going to be in trouble.
—That is not a point of order.

—I do not need the advice of the Leader of the National Party. The honourable member for Charlton will resume his seat. He cannot seek my advice. He must raise a point of order. The House will now be quiet. If it becomes as disorderly as it has been, I am going to suspend the sitting.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask the honourable member to withdraw his comments with reference to me.
—I do not recollect making any statement about the honourable member, but so that we can get the matter straight, during the inquiry and in this report--
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw.

—I will withdraw so that I can continue. During this inquiry a change of evidence was brought before the Committee. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) chose to introduce to the Committee remarks which were not recorded in the letter and which in fact were aimed directly at denigrating a witness who is further denigrated in the report. That is what I was talking about. She knows it. It was a disgraceful act against a person of her sex and it was deliberate. I have read the recommendation of this Committee and pointed out that we sought justice for everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: The Expenditure Committee has a responsibility to protect public revenue. It had a responsibility in inquiring into the Aboriginal Development Commission to protect the rights of Aboriginal people. The Commonwealth spends $400m annually on Aborigines, of which $60m is spent by the Aboriginal Development Commission. If that Committee has not ensured that that money was used for the benefit of the Aboriginal people, it has abrogated its responsibilities. There was substantial evidence, as was admitted in the first inquiry, that called on the Committee to consider these problems. Opposition members on the Committee were prevented from considering them. This happened on occasion after occasion before the engagement of a very expensive Queen's Counsel, who could only read the written evidence. As this report points out, there were grave deficiencies in the means by which evidence was gathered. Therefore, a proper inquiry is required. That is what the Opposition members on the Committee set out to achieve. They were blocked continuously and constantly by the Government members of the Committee. In fact, motions calling for a judicial inquiry were refused by the Chairman. They were not even to be debated. The Chairman refused to accept them and, in so doing, of course they could not even have the privilege--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—You have lied through this whole speech.
—I put the motions and it is not a lie. The fact is that the Committee tried as much as it could to block any further action.
—Why?
—I can tell the honourable member why.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin need not hurry back to his seat. He is still not going to interject.
—I sent a telex to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) saying that I wished to state--
—Well, Madam Deputy Speaker--
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will not interject.
—I ask the honourable member to give me a break.
—I am not interjecting; I am responding to your invitation.
—You are interrupting the speaker, who has the call from the Chair.
—On 16 March 1984, as this inquiry commenced, I sent this telex to the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to state that I consider this appointment is inappropriate at this time-
I am talking about the rumoured appointment of one Charles Perkins-
in the light of the pending inquiry by that Committee into the Aboriginal Development Commission.

As Chairman of this Commission it is imperative that Mr Perkins represent the ADC in that role during the inquiry so that the inquiry is not thwarted by insufficient information and advice which Mr Perkins must provide and for which he must resume responsibility. I am already in receipt of some information which if not an isolated case will raise considerable concern.

Of course that information has been part of the Committee evidence but has now been ignored. It related to the misappropriation by an Aboriginal Commissioner of possibly some $60,000. Mr Perkins told us there was nothing wrong with that. Both he and his Director put out a Press release on it. That Press release is well known to the Chairman of the Committee. It had to be withdrawn. Of course the eventual Auditor-General's report put forward to the Committee showed that all those things that had been suggested in the correspondence had occurred. But that, too, has been whitewashed by this Committee. The Expenditure Committee has been put into a position where it has abrogated its duties. Its first duty was to protect people, as the Chairman has said, who had allegations made against them. The fact is that this report now carries their names because at all stages the Committee rejected the moves of Opposition members on that Committee for a judicial inquiry. That is what we wanted-a judicial inquiry-because that was the only way we could get to the bottom of the serious maladministration which the Committee admitted to itself in its first report, signed by all the members. The problem is that the Minister has a problem in all of this.

The situation is this: Mr John Coombs has been quoted. Is it not interesting that suddenly he finds all the conditions? By the way, Mr Coombs was the only Queen's Counsel whom the Committee was allowed to appoint. Although a large list was provided, there was only one we were able to have. That was another case of where caucusing occurred in a committee which is supposed to be bipartisan. Mr John Coombs, QC said in his report that Perkins was generally an evasive and unhelpful witness from whom the Committee's attempts to seek answers were probably a waste of time. Yet we find in this report, as honourable members will see, that his word is chosen over that of another witness who, to my mind, gave excellent evidence. The fact that the Committee chose to change that evidence in no way affected the substantive situation. As I said, it is surprising that that witness, the core witness, the one whom Mr Coombs said was most to be believed and whose evidence should be put to the Australian Federal Police, was the same witness whom the honourable member for Canberra deliberately tried to discredit by saying that she had reported to her that all her actions were only because they were vindictive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—The honourable member should look across there when she says that is a lie.

—Order! The honourable member for Canberra will resume her seat. The honourable member for O'Connor must not cast aspersions on other members of the House. I would also appreciate it if the honourable member for O'Connor would not suddenly start roaring.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. It is interesting to note that when this report was first brought to the Parliament I made similar statements regarding the credibility of Mr Perkins. I was reported as saying that on 6 October in the Sydney Morning Herald. The evidence that the Committee received was a continuous list of maladministration and matters of great concern. They can be resolved only if a proper judicial inquiry is held. The report of the dissenting members is quite clear. For instance, although the QC and the Committee failed to raise the matter of pecuniary interests, we did so. Considerable evidence was given of certain members acting in breach of the pecuniary interests provisions of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. This is in the report. However, that matter was never even touched upon.

SPEECH.PARA: But all these matters were not for us to decide. Our job was to decide whether there was a problem and, if so, to put it in the proper hands. The Minister may remember that this is not the first time since this Parliament has reconvened that I have drawn his responsibilities to his attention. There are pages of Press reporting on these matters. We have seen headlines such as 'Loans questions raised' and 'Aboriginal funds misappropriated'. These are headlines in the Canberra Times. Why did the Minister have to wait until tonight to take some action? The smoke has been pouring out of the chimney for long enough for him to find the fire. The situation is that the dissenting members have requested a judicial inquiry. We have asked for a judicial inquiry so that we can protect those persons who have been accused and so that we can see that witnesses are properly cross-examined. That is what has been rejected. Having had advice from a QC who said that certain matters should be referred to the Federal Police, the Committee conducted a form of kangaroo court and decided to vote them innocent. The vote was 7 to 8. Of course, that is no way for a committee that had-and I repeat 'had'-the reputation of the Expenditure Committee to act.

Committees of this kind are supposed to protect the public money; they are supposed to protect all the people concerned. In this case, the people concerned are the Aboriginal people. We wish to protect the Aboriginal people from the avaricious few. Plenty of evidence was given to the inquiry that it has cost a large amount of money to get the avaricious few out on the ground to help Aboriginal people. This whitewash is to protect the Minister and the Government. It is not the appropriate way in which we should be going about our affairs.

A suggestion was made that some previous Ministers might be discredited. No ex-Minister on this side of the House is concerned about that. The concern seems to be for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The ex-Minister referred to is not frightened of the position.

The amount of time available to us has been limited. I wanted to go right through the report and identify all the problems. All the allegations listed in the report simply need to be read. Those allegations are serious. What is more, as we say in the report, we had no opportunity whatsoever to inquire properly into these allegations. The decision to be taken in this Parliament tonight is whether we walk away from those allegations or have them properly investigated. If they are not properly investigated, the Parliament will never know whether the $400m that it provides for Aboriginal people-and I repeat 'provides for Aboriginal people'-is being provided to them. It is an absolute whitewash.
Let me spell out the position again. The Committee has been forced to vote on party lines on every occasion it has met on this matter-

TALK.START.PARA: —Two divisions; there were only two divisions.

—How many more does the honourable member need? The point is that Opposition members of the Committee opposed the appointment of a QC. We saw it as a waste of money. We proposed then that there be a judicial inquiry. We were defeated on party lines, although all the evidence said that was where we should go. The Minister started to have a judicial inquiry under Mr Coombs. Of course, that was strangled because of a lack of cash. Eventually, this became an inquiry into the National Aboriginal Conference. I have a newspaper article which suggests very strongly that in fact when the Minister got the report from Mr Coombs, he asked Mr Coombs to go away and rewrite it. I can give the Minister that article. That is where the inquiry stopped. We have asked many questions about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have read to the House, Mr Perkins is a very bad witness. The QC said it; I have said it.In fact, we could not believe a word he said. In his final evidence to the Committee, he lost his memory as soon as the going got tough. That was what he did every time. The situation is that unless the Parliament accepts the recommendation in the dissenting report and Australia has a proper inquiry into Aboriginal affairs, the Minister will have on his head the public backlash which will result from the waste reported at State and Federal level. It will stop any good that we can do for Aboriginal people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Thursday, 23 May 1985

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to speak on a matter of parliamentary privilege.
—The right honourable member may proceed.

—The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) disclosed in the course of his remarks that a final draft of the report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure which is under consideration by this House was submitted to a counsel who apparently had been briefed at an earlier stage by the Committee. Under the laws of our privilege any paper that is to be presented to the Parliament must be presented to the Parliament first. If it is submitted without the approval of the Committee to any outside person it is a breach of the privilege of this place. I suggest to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that that report, being submitted to an outside counsel should now be considered by you as a matter of parliamentary privilege and referred to the Privileges Committee, wherein it can be examined and considered as a matter which is not in accordance with the practice of this place and a proper censure registered on the person concerned.
—Madam Deputy Speaker--

—There is no cause for the honourable member to speak. I will answer the right honourable gentleman. In accordance with the practice in these matters, I will give consideration to the issues raised by the right honourable member and advise the House of my decision in due course.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker--
—I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I wish to speak to the dissenting report.
—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has the call.
—I desire, as someone who has always been committed to the principles of the Westminster system, to--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite can laugh if they want to. I desire to draw the attention of the House, first of all, to the very serious recommendations that were made by the Standing Committee on Expenditure in terms of the procedures and practices which the Committee found it had to deal with. These raise very serious and pertinent points to be considered by the Parliament in terms of the reforms that seem to me to be necessary in order to protect both public servants and people appearing before committees and to see that parliamentary committees adhere to the basic principles of natural justice which are endemic to our judicial system. The Parliament, under the Westminster system, is regarded as the highest court in the land. I believe that when a committee is acting in a judicial capacity it has a duty, as far as possible, to see that the procedures of natural justice are followed.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable members to deal with this issue quite separately from the evidentiary aspects because it is a matter of important principle. The process that has occurred, I believe, is a matter of concern to all honourable members. Public servants were told to appear before the Committee after evidence had been given in camera. The Committee felt that it was appropriate to hear certain evidence in camera. Those public servants were not provided with any transcript of the evidence. They were given a simple summary of the allegation against them. They were not given the evidence upon which they could reply. They had to appear before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not have to appear; they chose to appear.

—If the honourable member for Deakin knew anything about the Standing Orders he would know that there is a requirement on public servants to appear before this Committee if they are requested to do so. I suggest that he should not make interjections which display his ignorance. It is all very well for honourable members opposite to interject. When Mr Kerry Packer identified himself as Goanna he said that he had been denied the principles of natural justice, and I personally believe that he had been. But when it occurs in this House, when honourable members opposite can actually make a decision about whether natural justice has been applied, there seems to be a marked reluctance to face up to the issues. I do not care which committee is involved; I do not believe as a matter of principle that any citizen or any public servant ought to be required to appear before a parliamentary committee when, basically, from the moment he appears, he is there to prove his innocence. It is an extraordinary procedure. Someone can appear before a committee and make an allegation which has no substance in fact-it may be scuttlebutt; it may be defamatory; it may be entirely false-and the only process that is available is a process whereby the accused person is not given a copy of the transcript of the evidence given before the committee when the allegation was made and the person who makes the allegation is not subject to any kind of cross-examination at all. The accused public servant has to appear before the committee on the basis of his receiving a simple notice saying: 'It is suggested that you are potentially guilty of a criminal offence; we want to hear your explanation'. That process would not live for two minutes within any of our courts and it should not live for two minutes within the processes of this Parliament.
—Give us the judicial inquiry.

—No. I commend the majority of members of the Committee who have drawn the attention of the Parliament to that serious inadequacy in our processes which can place any citizen in that position. That is the first and most important aspect of this matter that I want to address. Secondly, I want to deal with some of the allegations made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The implication of his remarks was that I as Minister was somehow involved in these administrative processes. I point out that all of the material that came before me in terms of the report related to an offence that took place prior to my being Minister.
—They are cover-ups.

—The honourable member can use those sorts of terms if he wants to. Let me just say this, and it is also related to the principle of natural justice: The Ministers who were responsible at the relevant time for the period covered by the examination of the Committee were Senator Chaney, Senator Peter Baume and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). They, of course, were aware of the terms of the legislation. If they were concerned about the administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission, why was no action taken by any of them in respect of any of these matters at that time?
—They may not have known it.

—They may not have known. The point is that a Minister cannot be heard to say that he does not know what occurs within his own portfolio. They may not have known. That might be the truth. I want to deal with one other matter because I believe that it is a very serious matter. During the period of the administration of the honourable member for Sturt, who preceded me as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, it was well known in the Department that he had great difficulty in reconciling his attitudes with those of the Chairman of the ADC. On no fewer than five occasions the honourable gentleman sought advice as to how he could sack Mr Perkins. There was an occasion when he even went to the then Prime Minister with Mr Perkins to call for Mr Perkins's resignation.
—Why do you think he did that?
—I am pointing out to the honourable member that the then Minister was so dissatisfied with the Chairman of the ADC that he sought his dismissal.
—The report says it all.

—I do not mind if honourable gentlemen opposite, by their interjections, show that they have no interest in the principles of natural justice, but what an extraordinary situation we have when the honourable member for Sturt sits on a committee which is examining areas, we are told, of misfeasance and negligence within his own former portfolio, which seeks to indict-

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not want to interrupt the honourable gentleman but I believe there is a Standing Order that requires any criticism of a member of this place to be made in the form of a substantive motion. I suggest that the honourable gentleman's remarks are going very close to falling in that area. I would suggest that the remarks should be terminated.
—Yes. The Leader of the National Party will resume his seat. I call the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

—All of a sudden there is a concern when the facts come out, and the facts are these: What an extraordinary process we have when a Minister sits on a committee and does not disclose to that committee--
—A former Minister.

—He is a former Minister. That is where he began and that is where he will end up, but it is the principle that is important. Here is a former Minister whose administration and his relationship with one of the principal witnesses is under scrutiny. In that situation, did he say to the Committee: 'Look, you are dealing with facts and evidence which relate to my competence as a Minister in the supervision of my portfolio, but, more importantly, I want to disclose to you that I have a relationship bordering on personal malevolence with one of the witnesses and, therefore, I seek to discharge myself from the Committee'? Not a bit of it. If ever there was a cowardly act which I believe belittled this Parliament, it was the situation where the honourable member--
—I raise a point of order.
—You can dish it out, but you cannot take it.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. I call the Leader of the National Party on a point of order.
—I raise a point of order in relation to that remark. I ask that it be withdrawn and suggest that the remarks are now quite outside our Standing Orders.
—The Minister might like to withdraw the word 'cowardly'.

—I will withdraw the word 'cowardly'. I say that it is an extraordinary abuse of the due process when a Minister sits as judge on his own administration and does not disclose to the Committee that he had been in a situation where one of the principal people--
—Madam Deputy Speaker, this is still outside the Standing Orders. I draw your attention to the continued abuse of Standing Orders.
—Abuse, rubbish! You cannot take the facts; that is your problem.

—Order! The Minister will sit down. I point out to the Minister that he is almost going beyond what can be considered as falling within the Standing Orders. He will get back to the point he was making before. He will leave the former Minister out of it.

—I believe this is an extraordinary process and one which should not have taken place within this Parliament. I want to deal with some of the allegations that have been made by the honourable member for O'Connor, who threw around figures like $500m--
—I did not.
—You did.

—Well, $400m; I stand corrected. Of course that has been the subject of a report and in respect of that report actions have already been taken by the ADC and me to deal with that. The particular allegation which the honourable gentleman opposite wants to have an inquiry into relates to the use of an airline ticket from Canberra to Sydney prior to the formation of the ADC. That is the monumental issue about which we must have a royal commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude on this note: It pains me to say it, but I am bound to say that from the outset, from the time Mr Perkins was appointed, he was subject to attacks by the honourable member for O'Connor. I believe that any objective analysis of what has occurred here will show that the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Sturt, a former Minister who had his own motives, set out on a deliberate course to find evidence upon which they could indict a senior public servant--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister must not cast aspersions upon other members of the House.

—It is not an aspersion. I am saying that a conclusion is open to honourable members and I invite them to draw it. It is beyond argument that from the time that Mr Perkins was appointed the honourable member for O'Connor attacked him openly and publicly. The honourable member for Sturt had a relationship with the Corporation which could only be described as difficult and complex. I will not use any more astringent term than that. I believe that both these men set out to seek facts that would enable them to destroy the most senior Aboriginal public servant in Australia.
—Order! The Minister must not cast aspersions upon the honourable members.
—I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I ask that the Minister withdraw those allegations.
—I meant what I said. I will not withdraw them.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask that the Minister withdraw those allegations. They are contrary to our Standing Orders.
—They are not contrary to the Standing Orders.
—Order! The Minister must not cast aspersions upon honourable members of the House. He may detail what he thinks they have done. He may not impugn their motives.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister has not withdrawn.
—I require him to withdraw those remarks, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—The Minister will withdraw the words.
—I say that the evidence is there, and I ask honourable members to draw their own conclusions.
—You have not withdrawn yet.
—He has.

—I think he did withdraw. I find it very interesting that the Leader of the National Party of Australia keeps getting up to tell me about the Standing Orders. I suggest to him that he also abide by the Standing Orders. I have had reason to speak to him about this when I have been in the chair during Question Time. If he is so interested in the Standing Orders, he too must abide by them.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek your advice as to the circumstances in which I have not risen in accordance with the Standing Orders.
—I base it on the number of times that the right honourable member has been asked to stop interjecting during Question Time.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I have just raised within the Standing Orders of this place a series of points of order relating to offensive remarks by a Minister. You asked him to withdraw those remarks, presumably because those remarks are in accordance with my observations and you did so, in accordance with Standing Orders. I ask on what basis you have just made an aspersion against me.

—I made the aspersion on the basis that during Question Time the right honourable member has repeatedly gone against the Standing Orders of this House, but he likes to stand up to invoke them when it suits him.
—You are a disgrace to the Chair.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Ian Robinson called you a disgrace to the Chair.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member for Charlton should use the name of an honourable member's electorate.
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher and the honourable member for Charlton will resume their seats. The Chair did not hear what the honourable member for Page said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, to which was attached a dissenting report. The Expenditure Committee inquiry into the affairs of the Aboriginal Development Commission was set up in the previous Parliament. The first interim report issued by the Committee indicated that there were certain serious matters that the Committee would further investigate. Following the elections, when the Committee was re-established, it set about inquiring into those matters. I am reminded that during the life of the Committee in the Thirty-third Parliament, when some of these very serious matters were raised, members of the then Committee expressed their serious concern as to whether it was the role of a parliamentary committee, once given notice of matters of a serious nature, to investigate them further. Although the suggestion was put to members on the Committee that it might be a matter for a royal commission or judicial inquiry, they rejected that view. The Committee in its report said that it would further investigate the matter. When the Expenditure Committee was re-established, further evidence was taken. The new Committee on the taking of that evidence had on it a number of members who continued to express their concern about serious matters of maladministration and some matters that pointed to the commission of possible criminal offences.
—You were not concerned when you were a Minister. You had a responsibility and did not discharge it.

—Let me deal with the interjection. The Aboriginal Development Commission is a unique statutory corporation. Under the legislation its commissioners are given some of the broadest powers provided by any statute establishing a statutory corporation. The ministerial rights of control and direction are most severely limited.
—Look at section 17 and section 11 of the Act. You could sack the Chairman if you wanted to and you could issue a direction if you wanted to. You did not want to know.

—In what the Minister said earlier this evening he indicated not only that I did not want to know, but that I knew and that, because of my deep and serious concern about the broad questions of the administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission, I was exploring ways and means of remedying the defective administrative arrangements that then existed.
—Did you seek advice to sack Charlie Perkins?

—This Parliament established an Expenditure Committee. That Committee, on which the Government has a majority of members, determined that it wanted to examine the affairs of the Aboriginal Development Commission. It embarked on that inquiry believing that, like other inquiries on which it had embarked, it would examine the programs and the effectiveness and efficiency of the body concerned. Then, when this serious evidence came before the Committee, despite numerous occasions on which suggestions were put to the Committee that it was not its function to conduct criminal investigations, ultimately the time came when the Committee rejected the idea of a judicial inquiry at that stage, but decided to refer the in camera evidence it had received to Queen's Counsel for advice as to what should be done. I draw honourable members' attention to some of the comments contained in the dissent report. We said:

SPEECH.PARA: In examining the efficiency and effectiveness of the ADC the Committee became aware of the possible commission of criminal offences, the occurrence of serious administrative malpractice and gross mismanagement. There were numerous occasions on which the evidence presented to the Committee indicated widespread management inefficiency and ineffective procedures.

In fact, the Committee in its interim report had found just that. When the matter was referred to the Committee, our recommendation in the dissent report that such a judicial inquiry be established was based, first, on the Committee's examination of the evidence it collected, but that view was reinforced by the views expressed by Mr John Coombs, QC, who was appointed to assist the Committee in evaluating the evidence. The Committee believed that it was a parliamentary committee and not a criminal investigation body, not a body with the necessary expertise to weigh that sort of evidence. We who presented the minority report agreed with the view expressed by Mr Coombs that in the light of the Committee's limited powers, its lack of criminal investigatory controls, there were many questions which those with such powers and experience would have wished to ask, but those questions were not asked by the Committee. Those of us who presented the minority report said:

We do not believe that the Committee should have placed itself in the role of a criminal investigator, prosecutor or tribunal. It is not trained or equipped in any of these roles. Once any allegation of a criminal kind is made and supported by evidence which had to be taken seriously, the Committee in our view should in accordance with its procedures take steps to refer the evidence to an appropriate investigatory authority whether it as a Committee accepted the evidence or not.

That recommendation was made to this House on the basis of advice from Queen's Counsel. It was not our view, although we adopted it. The Queen's Counsel said that parliamentary committees are not criminal investigators, prosecutors or tribunals. He made it quite clear that in his general view committees do not have the appropriate powers to protect witnesses, to protect those who make allegations or to protect those against whom allegations are made. We on this side of the House who were members of the Committee were deeply concerned to ensure that those who made allegations and those against whom allegations were made were fairly treated. It was our view that this whole matter should have gone to a judicial inquiry. It was not necessary to name names but the majority of the Committee chose to name them in its report. We made it quite clear that we were deeply concerned at that fact. It is not for a parliamentary committee to conduct criminal inquiries.

To the extent that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) expressed his concern that the role of parliamentary committees, I personally and my colleagues on the Committee share that concern. We believe that when matters of a serious and possibly criminal nature come before a parliamentary committee, the committee should not attempt to evaluate the evidence. Much was made earlier in the debate tonight about whether, following the Queen's Counsel's opinion, witnesses should have been called back or invited back to the Committee to give evidence or explanation. Firstly, I emphasise the fact that they were not called back. They were invited to attend the Committee and it was made quite clear in the letter signed by the Chairman of the Committee that it was up to them to determine whether or not they came before the Committee to comment upon the matters that were contained in the Chairman's letter. It was stated that they could do so if they wished, and they chose to do so. We did not believe that it was correct that they be invited or brought before the Committee again because it was not for the Committee then to further examine or cross-examine them.

It is interesting to note that the Queen's Counsel made it quite clear in his advice that, even if further evidence was taken, the Committee was not competent in assessing questions of criminal law to make an assessment as to the weight to be attached to the evidence of those who were making allegations and those against whom those allegations were made. Our minority report makes no judgment on those questions. What we say is that those matters in which possible criminal offences were committed are matters for an appropriate judicial inquiry to examine and assess and make recommendations to the Government as to whether the matters should be handed to the law enforcement authorities. It is noteworthy that the Queen's Counsel, on receiving and examining the in camera evidence, recommended that three matters be referred to the police.

Queen's Counsel's advice was sought-at not inconsiderable expense-because the Committee did not believe that it was its role to make such a decision. Interestingly enough it was Government members of the Committee who wanted to obtain a Queen's Counsel's advice. When they received that advice and the Queen's Counsel had recommended that certain matters be referred to the law enforcing authorities they chose to weigh further evidence in circumstances where the Queen's Counsel had in his opinion to the Committee made it quite clear that the Committee did not have the competence, the experience or the expertise to make that judgment.

Those of us who have submitted the dissenting report believe that it is necessary for the Expenditure Committee to discharge its reponsibility to this Parliament appropriately. In view of the circumstances placed before the Committee, in our considered opinion there is only one course of action that will adequately protect the position of witnesses who have given the Committee evidence of allegations and the position of witnesses who have given us evidence in answer to those allegations. The only way to determine that matter adequately, fairly and in accordance with what would be described as natural justice is for it to be considered by a proper judicial inquiry where witnesses of both kinds can be adequately represented and where cross-examination can take place under the more appropriate judicial conditions that would apply in a judicial inquiry.

Furthermore, the nature of the Committee's inquiry was such that it indicated that there were serious elements of mismanagement and maladministration by the Commission, an independent statutory authority. There was widespread evidence of that. The Committee believed that it was not the responsibility of the Committee to investigate every such allegation but that the matters were so serious they should be more fully examined by a committee with a wider charter and a more appropriate set of rules under which it could fully ascertain the extent to which such maladministration as was identified by the Expenditure Committee resulted in inappropriate expenditure of the taxpayers' funds. We believe that the only course which can appropriately be taken in all the circumstances is for such a judicial inquiry to be established. We believe that it should be. Only in this way will the functions and actions of this very independent statutory authority be able to be adequately examined.
